questions.text:
A primigravid mother gave birth to a baby having the karyotype shown in the image below. She mentions that a screening test was done in her 16th week of pregnancy, which indicated the possibility of an abnormality in the fetus. Which of the following parameters would not have been measured as part of the screening test?

MSAFP- Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin

PAPPA- Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is not measured in the second trimester (16th week) screening tests. It is included in the combined 1st-trimester screening.

The karyotype in the picture indicates Edward's syndrome or Trisomy 18. Maternal serum MSAFP, beta hCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A
Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Whipple's procedure. 

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

Other options: 

Option B: In Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option C: Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image below.

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presented to the Gynaecology OPD with a fever of 39℃ and lower abdominal pain. On examination, cervical motion tenderness along with mucopurulent vaginal discharge was seen. The lab reports showed evidence of cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhea. A provisional diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease was made. What is the minimum criteria present in this patient along with lower abdomen pain that helped the doctor to diagnose this condition?

choices.text: Lab documentation of positive cervical infection

questions.solution:
Cervical motion tenderness is the minimum criterion for diagnosing Pelvic Inflammatory disease.

The minimum criteria for clinical diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID):

Lower abdomen pain (M/c symptom) + any of the following

  • Cervical motion tenderness 
  • Adnexal tenderness 
  • Uterine tenderness 

CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) criteria for diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) are:

  • Oral temperature >38.3℃ (101.6℉)
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability 
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR 
  • Raised CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with N. gonorrhea or C. trachomatis 

Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy.
  • Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence showing proof of thickened fluid-filled tubes indicating a tubo-ovarian abscess.
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID.

Outpatient management of PID: 

Inj. Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days

In the Syndromic approach for treatment of PID, Kit No. 6 (Yellow kit ) is given to the patient.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient presented with macular lesions on the trunk as shown in the image. On stroking a macular lesion with a blunt object, there is erythema around the reddish-brown macules. Which of the following diseases would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The skin reaction depicted above is Darier’s sign, which is seen in cutaneous mastocytosis.

Cutaneous mastocytosis, the most common among them being urticaria pigmentosa, presents with hyperpigmented macules. The lesions have numerous mast cells. Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. However, Darier's sign is not highly specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

Note: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma, and piloerection of the muscle is responsible for the sign.

Mastocytosis is an acquired condition where there is a massive increase in the number of mast cells in the skin and other tissues. They are further classified by WHO as:

  • Cutaneous mastocytosis
    • Maculopapular cutaneous mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa (most common)
    • Mastocytoma
    • Diffuse cutaneous mastocytosis
  • Systemic mastocytosis

Histopathology of skin lesions in urticaria pigmentosa shows mast cell infiltrates predominantly around blood vessels and skin appendages in the papillary dermis. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules. Stains for mast cells:

  • Toluidine blue
  • Giemsa
  • Tryptase
  • Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase)
  • CD 117

The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.

 

Urticaria pigmentosa is common in 20-40 years age group and is characterized by numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques or nodules. They are in symmetrical distribution anywhere on the body except the palms and soles and seen maximum on the trunk and thighs. The lesions are positive for Darier's sign.

Treatment: Second-generation antihistaminics like cetirizine, fexofenadine, etc are the mainstay treatment. Other therapies include topical corticosteroids and photochemotherapy.

Other options: 

Option B: Cholinergic urticaria appears when the person is sweating after exercise or when the core body temperature is elevated and the patient develops pinpoint wheals. This is mediated by acetylcholine released by the sympathetic fibres of the eccrine sweat glands.

Option C: Chronic idiopathic urticaria: Urticaria with nonspecific etiology, lasting for more than 6 weeks.

Option D: Allergic contact dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with sudden, involuntary movements of upper limbs early in the morning and his EEG findings are shown in the image below. He was started on valproate. The gene involved in this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the EEG showing 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern are suggestive of Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) which is associated with a mutation in the GABRA1 gene.

JME, also known as Janz syndrome typically starts in early adolescence and presents as myoclonic jerks in the morning, which is often perceived as being clumsy or causing patients to drop things. It may also present as generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures on waking up and absence seizures. It may be caused due to mutation in many genes including CACNB4, CLNC2, GABRD, GABRA1, and Myoclonin1/ EFHC1. EFHC1 is the most common gene affected and GABRA1 is associated with more severe phenotypes.

The EEG pattern seen in JME is 4-6 hz in frequency (slower than alpha waves 8-12 Hz). The polyspike refers to multiple brief, high-amplitude spikes in a single discharge. Following a polyspike, there is a slow wave with a higher amplitude than the background EEG activity. This EEG activity is generalized in distribution as it is seen over both hemispheres of the brain. Valproate is considered the most effective medication. Lamotrigine, levetiracetam, and topiramate are also approved for JME.

Other Options:

Option A: CHYNN-1 is related to idiopathic generalized epilepsy.

Option B: CTLA-4: CTLA-4 is associated with autoimmune diseases and immune dysregulation. While mutations in CTLA-4 can lead to immune disorders like autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome or other autoimmune conditions, it is not typically linked to JME or epilepsy.

Option D: IL2RG is linked to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient admitted to the intensive medical care unit with suspected meningoencephalitis is undergoing the procedure shown below. All the following structures are pierced during this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing a procedure of lumbar puncture as shown in the image. All the given structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, except the posterior longitudinal ligament.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/ chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudomotor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Absolute- Infection over the site 
  • Relative-
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Spinal epidural abscess

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

The image given below shows the types of needles used for lumbar puncture.

The below image shows lumbar puncture being performed in the lying as well as the sitting position.

questions.text: A final year medical student comes across a patient with elevated pulsations around the neck and concludes it to be raised JVP. His professor disagrees and says that it is a carotid pulse. What helped the professor reach this conclusion?

choices.text: It did not stop with palpation
It changed with posture of patient

questions.solution:
The consultant concluded that it was a carotid pulse because it did not stop with palpation.  To differentiate the carotid pulse from the JVP, the following key features can be used:

Jugular venous pulse Carotid pulse
Better seen Better felt
Can be obliterated (by pressure at root of neck) Cannot be obliterated by palpation
Two positive and two negative waves (Biphasic wave) One positive wave 
Seen lateral to sternocleidomastoid  Seen medial to sternocleidomastoid 
Changes with position Does not change with position
Changes with respiration i.e. decreases during inspiration  Does not change with respiration
Changes with abdominal compression Does not change with abdominal compression

questions.text:
A 55-year-old post-menopausal lady came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of irregular vaginal bleeding. The doctor took an adequate history and genital examination revealed cervical stenosis. The doctor asked her to get a TVS done. The TVS showed an endometrial thickness of 1 cm. What would be the best next step in management?

[TVS: Trans-Vaginal Sonography]

choices.text: Follow up with USG every 3 months
Give continuous progesterone therapy with tranexemic acid

questions.solution:
The given scenario is a case of post-menopausal bleeding where, on TVS, the endometrial thickness is 1 cm i.e. 10 mm. Therefore, endometrial sampling is warranted as the next step since the overall endometrial thickness is >4 mm. However, given her underlying cervical stenosis, it is better to first do fractional curettage along with hysteroscopy rather than endometrial biopsy.

In-patient procedures for endometrial sampling like Fractional curettage (dilatation and curettage) of the endometrial and the endocervical tissue help to know the site of malignancy, the extent of spread, and also the staging of the tumor. It is the best test to perform if cancer is suspected as the cause of bleeding. This requires general anesthesia. The flowchart below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding in a patient without cervical stenosis:

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) is the first-line investigation that checks for endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of >4mm calls for further investigation by endometrial sampling. Endometrial sampling can be done using:

  • OPD procedures such as an Endometrial Aspiration Cytology (EAC) and methods like Pipelle aspirator/Vibra aspirator are used for aspiration of the uterine cavity. The obtained sample is then sent for histopathological examination. 
  • In-patient procedures for endometrial sampling like Fractional curettage (dilatation and curettage) with Hysteroscopy.

Hysteroscopic inspection & fractional curettage is the gold standard procedure to diagnose focal endometrial lesions. On biopsy, depending on whether endometrial hyperplasia is without or with atypia, we decide on giving continuous progesterone therapy or doing a hysterectomy for the patient, respectively.

Endometrial carcinoma must be ruled out in a post-menopausal woman with irregular bleeding and an endometrial thickness of > 4mm on TVS. If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm in a post-menopausal female, malignancy is rare and hence, can be managed by tranexamic acid.

questions.text: You are working as an intern in the ENT department. A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor in the child. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out in this child?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it can be ruled out in this child with biphasic stridor.

All the other options cause biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: The following image shows the head of a nematode. Which of the following best describes the morphology of its egg?

choices.text: Bile-stained, ovoid with an operculum and a knob

questions.solution:
The image shows an adult nematode with a mouth showing four hook-like teeth ventrally and two knob-like teeth with a median groove dorsally characteristic of ancylostoma duodenale, whose egg is non-bile stained, oval with 4-8 blastomeres.

Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) belongs to nematodes and is a species of hookworm. The adult worm is stout and cylindrical with a mouth directed dorsally which consists of 6 teeth made of a chitin-like substance.

The egg is oval or elliptical, non-bile stained, and surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline membrane that floats in salt solution. While laying the egg has an unsegmented ovum which later develops into a segmented ovum with 4-8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the membrane and blastomeres as shown below.

The head of Necator americanus consists of a smaller buccal capsule with two pairs of semilunar cutting plates instead of teeth. The image below shows the difference in the mouth of Ancylostoma duodenale (A) and Necator americanus (B).

Other options:

Option A- Bile-stained, ovoid with an operculum and a knob is the description of the egg of Diphyllobothrium latum which is a cestode, and whose head (scolex) is spoon-shaped and contains two slit-like longitudinal sucking grooves as shown below.

Option C- Non-bile stained, elongated plano-convex egg is that of Enterobius vermicularis which is a fusiform-shaped nematode with a mouth surrounded by three wing-like curicular expansions (cervical alae) as shown in the image below.

Option D-  Bile-stained, spherical hexacanth embryo is that of Taenia solium which is a cestode with the scolex consisting of 4 suckers 2 rows of hooks (marked by the arrow) as shown in the image.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following determines the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which national health program's logo is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given logo is of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) was started in the year 1997 and aims at diagnosing and caring for TB cases both in the public and private sectors. It undertook a DOTS (Directly Observed Therapy Short course) strategy that ensures a cure by providing and confirming that the most effective medicine is taken. The logo of DOTS is shown below.

RNTCP was renamed National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) on 1st January 2020 with the aim to eliminate TB by 2025, 5 years ahead of the WHO End TB strategy which is the global target. In May 2014, the WHO launched the End TB strategy, which formed a framework to guide countries toward ending the TB epidemic by decreasing TB mortality, and incidence and eliminating the financial burden of the disease. The logo of the End TB strategy is shown below. 

The National Tobacco Control Programme (NTCP) was launched by the government in 2007-08 during the 11th five-year plan, with the aim to generate awareness about the harmful effects of tobacco consumption and smoking. It also aimed to reduce the production and supply of tobacco products and facilitate the implementation of strategies for the prevention and control of tobacco advocated by the WHO framework convention on tobacco control. 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

questions.text: A 24-year-old rape victim was brought by the investigating police officer to the gynecologist. During the genital examination, the doctor obtained a sample from in and around the vagina. Which of the following statements is correct about the vaginal swab?

choices.text: High levels of acid phosphatase are detected even if the accused has undergone a vasectomy
The swabs are taken only after “two-finger test” is attempted
A vaginal speculum should never be used to take the swab
The presence of spermatozoa indicates the time of rape to be within 7 days

questions.solution:
High levels of acid phosphatase are detected in the vaginal swab even if the accused male has undergone a vasectomy. 

High levels of acid phosphatase will be detected in the vaginal swab as the semen contains acid phosphatase originating from the prostatic secretions. Hence, even if the accused male has undergone a vasectomy, the acid phosphatase in the semen will still be present. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in the case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia.

Other options:

Option B: The “two-finger test” i.e., per-vaginum examination must not be conducted for establishing rape/sexual violence and the size of the vaginal introitus has no bearing on a case of sexual violence. Per vaginum examination can be done only in adult women when medically indicated. 

Option C: A sterile vaginal speculum is used to take a vaginal swab from the anterior and posterior fornices of the vagina as there may be semen or saliva present. However, per speculum examination is not a must in the case of children/young girls when there is no history of penetration and no visible injuries. The examination and treatment as needed may have to be performed under general anesthesia in case of minors and when injuries inflicted are severe. 

Option D: The presence of spermatozoa in the vaginal swab of a rape victim indicates the time of rape to be within 3 days (or 72 hours), while semen can be detected up to 96 hours after an assault. This evidence is useful in estimating the time of the assault. Motile spermatozoa in the vagina can be usually detected up to 6–12 hours after intercourse. However, once deposited, sperms may be recovered up to 72 hours from the vagina, but they lose their motility.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came for preconception counseling with a history of anencephaly in her previous pregnancy. What is the daily dose of folic acid that must be given to her during future pregnancies to prevent the recurrence of this condition?
questions.solution:
The dose of folic acid to prevent the recurrence of anencephaly in her future pregnancies is 4 mg.

Women with a history of previous pregnancies with neural tube defects like anencephaly must be given 4 mg of folic acid daily, from 1 month before conception to about 12 weeks of pregnancy.

Other options:

Option B: All women of reproductive age group should be given 400 mcg i.e. 0.4 mg of folic acid daily as a prophylaxis therapy for megaloblastic anemia.

Option C: The government of India provides IFA (Iron and Folic Acid) tablets that contain 0.5 mg ( i.e. 500 mcg) of folic acid and 60 mg of elemental iron to all pregnant women daily from 2nd trimester onwards till 6 months post-delivery for prevention of anemia during pregnancy.

Option D: 1 mg of  Folic acid daily along with iron and a nutritious diet is used for the treatment of pregnancy-induced megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A patient with a urinary tract infection due to enterococcus was found to be resistant to vancomycin. The only FDA-approved drug for this condition acts on which of the following?
questions.solution:
The only FDA-approved drug for a patient with UTI with vancomycin-resistant enterococcus (VRE) is Linezolid and it acts on 50s ribosome.

Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by acting on the P-site of the 50s ribosome. This mechanism of action enables them to act against strains resistant to other agents such as penicillin-resistant streptococcus pneumoniae, methicillin and vancomycin-resistant staphylococcus, and vancomycin-resistant enterococcus.

30S Subunit Acting Antibiotics:

  • Aminoglycosides (e.g., Gentamicin, Tobramycin, Amikacin)
  • Tetracyclines (e.g., Doxycycline, Minocycline)
  • Glycylcyclines (e.g., Tigecycline)

  • Macrolides (e.g., Erythromycin, Azithromycin, Clarithromycin)
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Lincosamides (e.g., Clindamycin)
  • Streptogramins (e.g., Quinupristin/Dalfopristin)

Other Options:

Option B: DNA gyrase inhibitors include fluoroquinolones.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant who was healthy at birth presents with fever, irritability, and vomiting. On examination, icterus and hepatomegaly were present. Investigations reveal boiled cabbage odor of urine and elevated liver enzymes. Identify the toxic metabolite and the drug used for this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of type 1 tyrosinemia and the toxic metabolite in this condition is succinylacetone. Nitisinone is used for the management of this condition. 

Type 1 tyrosinemia (hepatorenal tyrosinemia) is caused by the accumulation of metabolites of tyrosine degradation, such as succinyl acetone, affecting the liver, kidney, and nerve. The newborn is healthy at birth and develops symptoms within 1 year of age. The clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Acute hepatic crisis- fever, hepatomegaly, jaundice, hypoglycemia and elevated transaminases. 
  • Renal involvement- Fanconi's anaemia, hypophosphatemia, hyperphosphaturia, NAGMA, vitamin D-resistant rickets.
  • Neural involvement- peripheral neuropathy like acute porphyria, extensor hypertonia of the neck, muscle weakness and pain.

The boiled cabbage odor is due to the increased methionine metabolites. Nitisinone inhibits 4- HPPD and reduces tyrosine metabolites decreasing the production of offending toxic compounds fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone. In hypermethioninemia also, Boiled cabbage odor is present in urine, sweat, and breath. Dimethylsulphide, a metabolite of methionine, causes the characteristic boiled cabbage smell. People with a genetic deficiency of α/β-methionine adenosyltransferase present with hypermethioninemia and neural demyelination. However, they're usually asymptomatic until early adulthood.

questions.text: A study was conducted with the data represented on the box-whisker plot below. If the total sample size of the study was 400 cases, the number of cases represented by the marked arrow and its distribution would be:
questions.solution:
The marked arrow points to the third quartile of the box-whisker plot i.e., 75% of cases, which would be 300 in the given study. Since the tail of the distribution stretches more toward the higher values, the larger proportion of cases would lie towards the lower values. Therefore, fewer cases would be found in the higher values which is suggestive of a positively skewed distribution.

A boxplot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. Box plots may also have lines extending vertically from the boxes (whiskers) indicating variability outside the upper and lower quartiles, hence the terms box-and-whisker plot. 

It shows the five-number summary of a set of data as shown below.

In the box plot, a simple box extends from the 25th percentile (lower limit of the box) to the 75th percentile (upper limit of the box) and represents the interquartile range. The line through the box indicates the median value (50th percentile).

Interpreting the box plot:

  • When the median is in the middle of the box, and the whiskers are about the same on both sides of the box i.e. when each quartile is of the same length, then the distribution is symmetric or normal (as shown in boxplot-1).
  • When the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right as shown in boxplot-2).
  • When the median is closer to the top of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box, then the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left as shown in boxplot-3).
  • Small circles or unfilled dots are drawn on the chart to indicate where suspected outliers lie. Filled circles are used for known outliers (as shown in boxplot-4).

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the position of dead body and the distribution of post-mortem staining is correct?

choices.text: Vertically suspended - Legs, feet, forearm, and hands
Prone - Back except for shoulder blades, buttock, and calves

questions.solution:
The body when vertically suspended as seen in hanging will lead to post-mortem staining in the legs, feet, forearm, and hands.

In death by hanging, the body gets suspended in a vertical position resulting in the legs, feet, forearms, and hands becoming dependent parts of the body. Hence, blood pools in these parts of the dead body, resulting in post-mortem staining, in a “glove and stocking” pattern.

Postmortem staining/Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. The correct PM distribution based on the position of the dead body is given below:

Prone  Front (ecchymosis,petechiae and bloodblisters present in chest and shoulders)
Vertical as in hanging Legs, feet, forearm, and hands (glove and stock hypostasis)
Inverted (like in drunken persons) Head and neck
Drowning Face, the upper part of the chest, hands, lower arms

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought with complaints of involuntary picking movement of his fingers. He had a blank look on his face and was unresponsive during this episode. He had nausea and epigastric discomfort before this episode. MRI findings are given in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing hippocampal sclerosis is most likely suggestive of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy syndrome (MTLE).

It is the most common epilepsy syndrome characterized by the early onset of focal seizures with impairment of consciousness. The seizure is usually preceded by an aura which may include epigastric sensation, nausea, deja-vu, fear/anger, or olfactory/gustatory hallucinations. The seizure may present as picking movements of fingers, blank staring appearance, difficulty in speaking, automatism such as lip-smacking, chewing, etc. Patients usually experience post-ictal confusion.

The electroencephalogram shows unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes. MRI typically shows hippocampal sclerosis, as seen in the image below: 

 

The condition is refractory to anticonvulsant therapy but responds well to surgical intervention.

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is seen in early adolescence and features include bilateral myoclonic single or repetitive jerks with intact consciousness. The condition responds well to antiepileptics.

Option B: Lennox- Gastaut syndrome is an epileptic syndrome seen in children. It is characterized by generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and absence seizures in children. EEG changes and cognitive impairment may be present in most cases. 

Option C: Gelastic epilepsy is seen in childhood. It is characterized by laughter that feels empty or unpleasant, sometimes followed by features of focal seizures, such as automatism. They might also have tonic-clonic and atonic seizures. The condition is associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

Related Pearl: Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy shows a familial inheritance and begins in childhood. It presents as focal seizures with a remitting and relapsing course. It is associated with:

  • Aura
  • Complex automatism
  • Post-ictal confusion
  • Anterograde amnesia

EEG findings include temporal spikes, and MRI shows hippocampal sclerosis. Management includes anteromedial resection of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in labor was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, there is infraumbilical flattening of the abdomen and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for the progress of labor

questions.solution:
Based on the examination and auscultation findings, the fetus is in occipitoposterior position. The most appropriate management is to wait and watch for the progress of labor. 

In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle, and the baby is born in the occipitoanterior position. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior position is made, labor is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and a favorable pelvis.

The occipitoposterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. 

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Examination findings of OP position:

  • Inspection: The abdomen appears flattened below the umbilicus (infra-umbilical flattening).
  • Pelvic grips:
    • The head is not engaged.
    • The sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not prominently felt.
  • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds are heard maximally over the flanks. However, in direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.

There are three variants of OP position:

  • Left OP position (fourth position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the left sacroiliac joint. 
  • Right OP position (third position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the right sacroiliac joint. It is more common than the left OP position.
  • Direct OP position: When the occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

All three positions may be primary (present before the onset of labor) or secondary (develops after the onset of labor). 

Indications of cesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labor
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest field defect observed in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
A relative paracentral scotoma is the earliest clinically significant field defect observed in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and, and finally the nasal fibers. Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma. 

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient is posted for surgery under general anesthesia.  She has a previous history of postoperative emesis and motion sickness. Which of the following anaesthetic agent is most suitable for this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates that the patient has significant risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Propofol is the most suitable anesthetic agent due to its anti-emetic properties.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient factors 
    • Young age, female gender, non-smoker
    • History of prior postoperative emesis
    • History of motion sickness
  • Anesthetic techniques
    • General anesthesia
    • Drugs: Opioids, Volatile agents, Nitrous oxide(Options B and D)
  • Surgical procedures
    • Strabismus surgery
    • Gynecological surgeries
    • Laparoscopy
    • Cholecystectomy

Risk reduction strategies include:

  • Avoidance of general anesthesia by the use of regional anesthesia
  • Use of propofol for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia
  • Avoid nitrous oxide in surgeries lasting over 1 hour
  • Avoid volatile anesthetics
  • Minimization of intraoperative and postoperative opioids
  • Maintain adequate hydration
  • Use of sugammadex instead of neostigmine for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade

Drugs used in the prevention and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine

Note: Post-operative nausea and vomiting is more common with Etomidate.

questions.text:
A study was performed and the clearance of different substances was recorded on a graph as shown below. Identify the substance represented in curve 1.

PAH - Para-aminohippurate
questions.solution:
The substance represented in curve 1 is PAH (para-aminohippurate).

PAH is freely filtered and partly secreted. Its concentration keeps increasing throughout the length of the nephron due to secretion into tubules. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.  

The given curves basically measure the amount (not concentration) of a particular substance in renal tubules after it undergoes ultrafiltration. It depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and PAH.

Other options:

Option A: Inulin is freely filtered (100%) and is represented by curve 2. It further does not undergo any reabsorption or secretion. It is hence a straight line i.e., its concentration does not change throughout the length of the nephron. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

Options C and D: Substances like amino acids or glucose are represented by curve 3. In normal conditions, they are almost completely reabsorbed. Hence they have a graph that is sloping down. And since they are completely reabsorbed within PCT itself, their concentration is not detected after proximal convoluted tubules. Hence, the clearance is zero. 

In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

questions.text: While prescribing which of the following antidiabetic drugs should you warn the patient about the risk of weight gain?
questions.solution:
While prescribing the antidiabetic drug glyburide, a sulfonylurea, the doctor should warn the patient about the risk of weight gain.

By inhibiting the activity of a specific location on the β cell K ATP channel complex in the cell, sulfonylureas promote the release of insulin. Inhibiting KATP channels results in cell membrane depolarization and the series of events that trigger the production of insulin.

First-generation sulfonylureas: tolbutamide, tolazamide, and chlorpropamide (rarely used now in the treatment of diabetes) 

Second-generation sulfonylureas: glyburide (glibenclamide), glipizide, and glimepiride

Important side effects are hypoglycemia and weight gain. They can induce a disulfiram-like reaction.

Other options:

Option A: Metformin is considered weight neutral. Other advantages of this drug are that it does not cause hypoglycemia and is inexpensive. Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, and lactic acidosis. Prolonged use leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option B: Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor and is known to cause mild weight loss. It also causes blood pressure reduction and does not cause hypoglycemia. They increase the risk of urinary tract infections and can increase the risk of fractures.

Option C: Pramlintide is an amylin agonist. It reduces postprandial glycemia and leads to weight loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with a ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is positive. Which of the following types of squint is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A restrictive squint is most likely in this patient.

The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a squint, with the secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a positive forced duction test is indicative of a restrictive squint.

In strabismus or squint, the visual axes of the eye take up a position other than the regular physiological position, relative to each other.

The squint may be either concomitant, where the amount of deviation in the eye affected remains constant in all directions of gaze, or incomitant, where the amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze. 

The differences between concomitant and incomitant squint are:

Features Concomitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

Paralytic squint is one of the two types of incomitant squint, that results from partial or complete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles. The other type is restrictive squint, where the movement of the extraocular muscle(s) is restricted due to conditions like fibrosis of the muscle.

Forced duction test helps differentiate between these two types. In this test, the patient is first asked to turn his/her eye maximally in the direction in which movement is being tested. Subsequently, the eyeball is moved in the same direction by the examiner, using toothed forceps placed at the limbus.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. This is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. This is seen in a restrictive squint.

The visual axes are parallel in apparent squint or pseudostrabismus, but the eyes seem to have a squint.

    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint

    • Esotropia: Convergent

      • Sensory

    • Exotropia: Divergent

questions.text: A 65-year-old obese woman presented with vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. She had recurrent episodes of such complaints for the past few days. An erect abdominal X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be related to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels, which indicates small bowel obstruction. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of gallstone ileus. Rigler’s triad is associated with this condition.

Rigler’s triad comprises of:

  1. Small bowel obstruction (multiple air-fluid levels)
  2. Pneumobilia (gas in the biliary tract)
  3. Atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gallstone)

Given below is a plain x-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. The most common site of blockage is the terminal ileum before entering the cecum. It usually presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, distention, and obstipation) in patients with a history of gallstones.

Large-sized gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation resulting in a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad.

The patient may have constant pain or recurrent episodic discomfort from the intestinal obstruction which may be incomplete. CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis. This condition is managed by laparotomy and milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction. The stone is tried to be crushed within the bowel lumen or the intestine is opened at that point to remove the gallstone.

Other options:

Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus. It comprises a sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain, recurrent retching with minimal vomitus and inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube.

Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

Note: Obstipation is the failure to pass both flatus and faeces.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with a history of high fever unresponsive to antipyretics for the past five days. On examination, there is congestion of the bulbar conjunctiva and cervical lymphadenopathy. A picture of his tongue and hands are shown below. What cardiovascular complication is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Extensive segmental fibrinoid necrosis of cardiac vessels

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 3-year-old boy with high fever unresponsive to antipyretics with examination findings of congestion of the bulbar conjunctiva, cervical lymphadenopathy and the images showing the presence of strawberry tongue and edematous erythema of the palms, point to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease. The cardiovascular complication associated with Kawasaki disease is coronary aneurysm.

Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a self-limiting illness of infancy or childhood. Coronary arteries are classically involved in this condition. Approx 20% develop complications like aneurysms, MI, and sudden death.

Clinical features include a high spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics. The fever can last between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. 

Diagnosis requires fever for at least 4 days and at least four of the five principal criteria. 

  1. Changes in extremities
    • Acute: erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
    • Subacute: periungual peeling of fingers, and toes in weeks 2 and 3.
  2. Polymorphous exanthematous rash.
  3. Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
  4. Erythema and cracking of lips, strawberry tongue, and/or erythema of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral.

Treatment involves 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin as an infusion over 10-12 hours within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should be administered until the patient is afebrile. 

The image shows an aneurysm of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery due to Kawasaki disease:

Other options:

Option A: Extensive segmental fibrinoid necrosis of cardiac vessels is seen in Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small- or medium-sized muscular arteries that typically affects renal and visceral vessels. It is associated with segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation and luminal thrombosis. Kawasaki disease vasculitis resembles that seen in PAN but the fibrinoid necrosis is usually less prominent than in PAN.

Option B: Thickening of the aortic arch is seen Takayasu arteritis. It is characterised by transmural fibrous thickening of the aorta, especially the aortic arch and great vessels, as well as severe luminal narrowing of major branch vessels.

Option D: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis of cardiac arterioles is seen in Microscopic polyangiitis. It is associated with necrotizing vasculitis that generally affects capillaries as well as small arterioles and venules  It is also called hypersensitivity vasculitis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient underwent a TESPAL procedure for epistaxis that persisted despite nasal packing. The artery that is ligated is a branch of which artery?
questions.solution:
The artery ligated in the transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) procedure is the Sphenopalatine artery which originates from the third part i.e. Pterygopalatine part of Maxillary artery.

The maxillary artery is one of the terminal branches of External carotid artery.

The maxillary artery is divided into three parts .

1st part/Mandibular part

  • Location- Extend from Neck of the mandible to lower border of Lateral pterygoid
  • Common Pattern - All branches from this part enter the bone
  • Branches : [mnemonic: AADMI ]   
  1. Accessory meningeal artery
  2. Anterior tympanic arteries 
  3. Deep auricular artery 
  4. Middle meningeal artery 
  5. Inferior Alveolar artery

2nd part/Pterygoid part:

  • Location - In the infratemporal fossa
  • Common Pattern - All are muscular branches.
  • Branches: 
  1. Artery to lateral pterygoid
  2. Medial pterygoid artery 
  3. Masseteric artery
  4. 2 deep temporal arteries

3rd part/Pterygopalatine part:

  • Location - pterygopalatine fossa
  • Branches [mnemonic: PIGPAS] :   
  1. Posterior superior alveolar artery
  2. Infra-orbital artery

questions.text: A surgeon plans to perform a surgical portosystemic anastomosis for a patient with portal hypertension. To reduce post-operative hepatic encephalopathy, he advises performing a shunt that selectively decompresses esophageal varices. Which of the following surgeries will he opt for?
questions.solution:
The surgeon will opt for a distal splenorenal shunt (Warrens shunt)which selectively decompresses esophageal varices and reduces post-op hepatic encephalopathy.

Selective portosystemic shunts selectively decompress oesophageal varices and do not drain the entire portal blood thus preventing post-operative hepatic encephalopathy and accelerated hepatic failure. 

The selective shunts are:

  • Warrens shunt- distal splenorenal shunt- anastomosis between the distal end of the splenic vein and left renal vein with interruption of all collaterals. The high-pressure superior mesenteric system continues to perfuse the liver. 
  • Inokuchi shunt- anastomosis between the left gastric vein and inferior vena cava.

Non-selective shunts completely divert portal flow and the examples include:

  • End-to-side portacaval shunt- Eck shunt (Option B)
  • Side-to-side portacaval shunt- Mitra shunt (Option A)
  • Proximal leinorenal shunt- Linton shunt (Option C)
  • Large-diameter interposition shunts

The image below shows the various types of shunts.

questions.text: Identify the given image below.
questions.solution:
This image shows Janeway's lesion, which is highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Janeway lesions are nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles. They are more common in acute than subacute IE; histologically, they reflect microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of IE are:

    • Osler nodes
    • Roth spots

Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules mostly on the pads of the fingers and toes, which may also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences. Roth spots are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centers.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with urinary hesitancy and poor flow of urine. On per-rectal examination, a suspicious hard nodule within one lobe of the prostate was felt. Serum PSA levels were found to be elevated. TRUS-guided prostatic biopsy report shows grade 3 prostatic cancer. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment option for this 65-year-old man presenting with grade 3 prostatic cancer is Radical prostatectomy.

Prostate cancer is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years. They usually arise in the peripheral zone of the gland. Most patients remain asymptomatic. Early prostate cancer may be found incidentally following TURP for clinically benign disease(T1a and T1b), T1c due to serum PSA screening, and T2 as a nodule on rectal examination. Symptoms of Advanced cancer include bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain and haematuria, bone pain, malaise, joint pain, and anemia. They may present with renal failure. The workup includes a core biopsy of the prostate gland(minimum 12 cores) and an MRI to evaluate the local extension of the tumor. PSMA-PET (prostate-specific membrane antigen- PET) scan should be done to know the distant spread of cancer. 

Prostate cancer most commonly extends locally to the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the obturator nodes and the para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs mostly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the visceral organs like the liver. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in decreasing order of frequency. 

The Gleason grading system correlates with the pathological stage, spread, and prognosis. Measurement of serum PSA levels is useful to assist with the diagnosis and management. It acts as an important prognostic marker. The staging of prostate cancer is as follows:

Stage Description 
T1 (clinically inapparent)

incidentally found tumors on histological examination of a prostatectomy specimen.
T1a tumor involving less than 5% of the resected specimen
T1b  tumor involving >5% of the resected
T1c impalpable tumors found following investigation of a raised PSA.
T2 The tumor is confined inside the prostate gland
T2a

a suspicious nodule on rectal examination that is confined within the prostate capsule and involves one lobe
T2b

tumor invades more than half of one side of the prostate gland, but not both sides.
T2c

 tumor invades both sides but is still inside the prostate gland
T3 tumor extends through the prostatic capsule
T3a Unilateral or bilateral extracapsular extension of the tumor
T3b The tumor extends to the seminal vesicle
T4

Tumor invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, i.e. levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum, or pelvic side wall.

Management of prostate cancer is as follows:

Stage of cancer Age > 70 , Grade 1/2  tumours Age < 70 ,grade 3/4  tumours 
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2a Active surveillance

Radical prostatectomy: removal of prostate with part of the urethra,
 seminal vesicle
lymph nodes 
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2b, T2c, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy

Metastatic prostate cancer is managed as:

  • First line: Androgen deprivation therapy( Medical therapy or orchidectomy)
  • Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (for hormone-resistant cancer)
  • Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis)

The most important prognostic marker of prostate cancer is the stage of cancer.

Explanation for Other Options:
- Option A: Active surveillance is for low-risk, localised prostate cancer.
- Option C: External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) may be reserved for those who cannot undergo surgery or prefer a non-surgical option.
- Option D: Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) is typically used for metastatic prostate cancer or as an additional treatment before radiation therapy for high-risk or advanced localized disease. However, for localized or intermediate-risk disease, ADT alone is not sufficient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. An X-ray revealed a fracture involving the tibial condyles and the distal femur. Which among the following instruments can be used to stabilize the fracture?
questions.solution:
The fracture involving the tibial condyles and the distal femur is defined as a periarticular fracture of the knee. A spanning rail external fixator is used to stabilize such fractures.

External fixators are used if the fracture is associated with severe soft tissue damage. It is also used if internal fixation is risky due to wound contamination. The spanning external fixator will stabilize the fracture until the condition of the soft tissue improves. The complications of external fixation include over-distraction, damage to soft tissue structures, and pin-track infections. 

Given below is the image of the spanning rail fixator :

Other options :

Option A : Intramedullary nailing is generally used for the fixation of long bone diaphyseal fractures. Intramedullary nailing has become a superior device as compared to the plating because the nail is a load sharing device . Only disadvantage of nailing is that it does not provide rotational stability  but for this modified nails are prepared in which holes are made at both the end of nails for providing rotational stability 

Option C : Steimann pin is used for skeletal traction . Common site includes upper end of tibia , calcaneum , and supracondylar region of femur.

Option D : An Interlocking compression plate is also used for the fixation of long bone diaphyseal fractures. But they are less commonly used as compared to intramedullary nailing. They are also used to fix fractures around prosthesis and also in osteoporotic bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: True statement about the Village Health Nutrition Day (VHND) is:

choices.text: ASHA and AWW workers will mobilize people
Final report of the day is given to the ASHAs
Family planning and reproductive infections is not a part of VHND

questions.solution:
The correct statement is “ ASHA and AWW workers will mobilize people”.

Village Health Nutrition Day (VHND)is held monthly, preferably on Wednesdays. If villages are left out, they can be organized on another day within the same month (Option A). It is organized at the Village Anganwadi Centre (AWC), ensuring easy access for the community.  ASHAs, AWWs, and other personnel mobilize villagers, particularly women and children, to assemble at the AWC. ANM and other health staff must be present for supervision. Otherwise, the villagers may be reluctant to attend the following monthly VHND.

It concerns itself with more than just nutrition; villagers receive basic health services, interact with health personnel, and learn about preventive and promotive healthcare (Option D). Various services are provided under maternal health, child health and nutrition, family planning, reproductive infections, communicable diseases, health promotion, AYUSH, and sanitation.

The Village Health and Sanitation Committee (VHSC), including ASHAs, AWWs, ANMs, and PRI representatives, play a critical role in organizing the event and improving perceptions around healthcare. The final report of the village health nutrition day should be given to the Medical officer (Option C).

questions.text: A chronic kidney disease patient is being prepped for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The patient has not undergone dialysis in the last 3 days. Which muscle relaxant should be preferred during intubation?
questions.solution:
Cisatracurium should be preferred during intubation in chronic kidney disease patients.

Cisatracurium is metabolized by plasma esterases and undergoes spontaneous degradation by Hofmann elimination(non-enzymatic). Due to these alternative routes of metabolism, the  t1/2 of elimination of Atracurium and cisatracurium do not alter in patients with impaired renal and hepatic function. These drugs are safe for patients with renal and liver disease.

Atracurium has side effects of hypotension, tachycardia, and bronchospasm due to histamine release, which are not seen with cisatracurium, so it is preferred over atracurium.

Other options:

Option A: Rocuronium is an aminosteroid nondepolarizing muscle relaxant. The elimination half-life of rocuronium is increased in renal failure because of an increase in the volume of distribution so it is not used in patients with renal disease.

Option B: The short-acting drug mivacuronium is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase. Its duration of action is increased in patients with end-stage renal disease because of a decrease in plasma cholinesterase activity in these patients.

Option D: Succinylcholine is contraindicated in severe renal failure. In patients with CKD, succinylcholine is safe only if the patient has recently undergone dialysis (within the last 24 hours).

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text:
Which of the following indicators are used to calculate child undernutrition while calculating the Global Hunger Index (GHI)?

1. Weight for height
2. Weight for age
3. Height for age
4. Mid arm circumference
questions.solution:
The indicators used to calculate child undernutrition while calculating the Global Hunger Index (GHI) are weight for height and height for age.

The indicators of undernutrition are included to assess diet quality and utilization. Weight for height is used to assess child wasting which is a specific indicator for acute malnutrition. Height for age is a measure of child stunting which is a specific marker for chronic malnutrition.

The GHI has three dimensions which are calculated using the following indicators:

Dimensions Indicators
Inadequate food supply Proportion of the population that is undernourished
Child mortality Under 5 mortality rate
Child undernutrition

Wasting in children under 5 years

Stunting in children under 5 years

GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X Standardized CWA) + (1/6 X Standardized CST) + (1/3 X Standardized CM)

Where,

  • PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished.
  • CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age.
  • CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age.
  • CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age.

The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. 

In the 2024 Global Hunger Index, India ranks 105th out of the 127 countries with sufficient data to calculate 2024 GHI scores. With a score of 27.3 in the 2024 Global Hunger Index, India has a level of hunger that is serious.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of falling in the bathroom 6 weeks back and had sustained a left side fracture neck of femur presents with pain in her left hip and an inability to walk. On examination, the left lower limb was found to be shortened and externally rotated. MRI shows a compromised blood supply of the femur. What is the recommended management for this patient?

choices.text: Fixation of the fracture along with Pauwell’s osteotomy
Closed reduction and Internal fixation with cancellous screws
Reduction of fracture along with vascular graft

questions.solution:
A 40-year-old female patient had sustained a fracture of the neck of the femur on the left side, 6 weeks back and MRI shows a compromised blood supply on the femur. The recommended management is a reduction of fracture along with vascular graft.

Since the age of the patient is less than 65 years and the fracture is more than 3 weeks, the next best step in management will be an MRI of the head of the femur to see whether the femoral head is viable or not, based on which further management is to be done.

In a patient under 65 years of age with a fracture lasting more than three weeks and a viable head of the femur on MRI, the next best step in management is to perform fixation of the fracture along with an osteotomy (either Pauwels or McMurray's osteotomy). 

Conversely, in a patient under 65 with a fracture lasting more than three weeks and compromised blood supply on MRI, the appropriate management step is the reduction of the fracture along with a vascular graft. Two types of vascularization procedures are available: Meyer's procedure, which utilizes the Quadratus femoris muscle, and Bakshi's procedure, which uses the Tensor fascia lata.

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Which of the following measures is best suited to prevent anaphylactic reactions in IgA-deficient individuals?

choices.text: Use of IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components
Preloading with dexamethasone prior to blood transfusion
1L of normal saline administration before blood transfusion.

questions.solution:
IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components can be used to prevent allergic reactions in individuals with Ig A Deficiency.

Patients with IgA deficiency are at risk of severe anaphylactic reactions associated with plasma transfusion. But, usually, allergic reactions during blood transfusions are related to plasma proteins found in transfused components. It occurs following a transfusion of a few milliliters of blood components. The reactions are mild most of the time presenting as rash, pruritus, urticaria, and localized edema. At times it may be severe presenting as bronchospasm, respiratory distress, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, and shock.

Treatment of severe anaphylaxis involves stopping the transfusion. Vascular access is maintained and administration of 0.3–0.5 mg of adrenaline is done. Administration of steroids, antihistamine drugs, and bronchodilators is done. This can be prevented by using IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was prescribed a drug for the treatment of gastroenteritis. However, he complains of severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating whenever he takes alcohol after his medications. What was the drug he was prescribed?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a patient develops symptoms like restlessness and flushing on taking alcohol after his medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, metronidazole is associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

Some important drugs which cause a disulfiram-like reaction are:

  • Metronidazole, Tinidazole
  • Some cephalosporins like cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Procarbazine

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

questions.text: A premature infant weighing 1300g has blood samples reporting decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. The peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW) (<1500 grams) infant with likely Vitamin E deficiency due to low Vitamin E reserves, as indicated by a peripheral blood smear showing spur cells (acanthocytes) and evidence of hemolytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH). 

Vitamin E acts as a lipid-soluble antioxidant in cell membranes. When vitamin E deficiency occurs, lipid peroxidation causes the erythrocyte membranes to become abnormally fragile, leading to hemolytic anemia. Other symptoms of Vitamin E deficiency include acanthocytosis, muscle weakness, demyelination of posterior columns (decreased vibration sense and proprioception), and spinocerebellar tract (ataxia). 

Vitamin E deficiency can be seen in those -

  • Who can not absorb fat (dietary fat)
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Very low birth weight infants (<1500 grams)

Abetalipoproteinemia is caused by a defect in the Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein (MTP) gene. Deficiency in apo B48 and apo B100 containing lipoproteins results in decreased absorption of Chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL. Early manifestations include fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, and failure to thrive. Late manifestations include Retinitis Pigmentosa, Spinocerebellar degeneration, ataxia, and acanthocytosis.
