questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The given image shows persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) and the embryological defect causing this is a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges.

This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Deoxygenated blood goes into the right heart and back into systemic circulation via the aorta. Oxygenated blood goes into the left heart and then back into pulmonary circulation via the pulmonary artery. This parallel circulation gives rise to persistent cyanosis as seen in this patient. 

Since the conotruncal ridges also participate in the formation of the interventricular septum, an accompanying ventricular septal defect (VSD) may also be seen. The persistent truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives mixed blood from both sides. 

 

Other options -

Option A - Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

 

Option B - Anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum gives rise to the Tetralogy of Fallot. It is characterized by 4 cardinal features - pulmonary infundibular stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

 

Option D - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

questions.text: The parents of a 8-year-old boy came with complaints of their son being easily distracted, forgetful, fidgety and restless for more than 6 months. His teachers at school also report that he frequently has difficulty staying seated, blurts out answers, and has trouble waiting for his turn during group activities. What is the stimulant drug that can be used for the treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the 8-year-old boy shows symptoms of hyperactivity and inattentiveness at home as well as school for more than 6 months suggesting the diagnosis of Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder (ADHD) which can be treated using the stimulant drug- Methylphenidate.

Pharmacological treatment is considered the first line for treatment of ADHD. CNS stimulants like Methylphenidate, Dexamphetamine, Lisdexamphetamine are the first-choice agents for ADHD , FDA approved for use in children above 6 years of age as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. 

Methylphenidate and amphetamine preparations are dopamine agonists however, the precise mechanism of the stimulant's central action remains unknown. Concerta, the 10- to 12-hour extended release OROS (osmotic controlled-release extended delivery system) form of methylphenidate, is administered once daily in the morning.The adverse effects include headaches, stomach aches, nausea,and insomnia. In children with a history of motor tics , methylphenidate can exacerbate the tics. 

Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include Atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), Clonidine and Guanfacine ( alpha adrenergic agonist ) and Bupropion. 

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit Hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction, is a neuropsychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its aetiology, and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organisation)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits

questions.text: In which of the following cases should beta blockers be avoided?

choices.text: A patient with raised IOP and optic disc changes in the eye
A patient with acute shortness of breath, pedal edema and orthopnea
A patient on prophylaxis for unilateral headache with visual aura
A patient with history of hypertension, severe tearing chest pain and unequal BP in both arms

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with acute shortness of breath, pedal edema and orthopnea suggestive of acute decompensated heart failure and β-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) as they can worsen the condition. They are indicated only in patients with chronic stable heart failure.

Beta-blockers can worsen acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) due to their negative chronotropic and inotropic effects, which reduce the heart's contractility and heart rate. This can lead to worsened pulmonary congestion due to increased left ventricular filling pressures and tissue hypoperfusion from reduced cardiac output.

In ADHF, the primary goal is to stabilize the patient using treatments like diuretics, vasodilators, and inotropes. These therapies help alleviate fluid retention, improve blood circulation, and support heart function. After stabilization, beta-blockers may be considered for long-term management of chronic heart failure. Only Bisoprolol, Carvedilol, Metoprolol succinate and Nebivolol are approved for treatment.

Common contraindications of beta blocker therapy:

  • Asthma and COPD (do not use in view of bronchoconstriction)
  • Hypoglycemia (of concern in hypoglycemics and diabetics)
  • Acute or chronic bradycardia and/or hypotension
  • Second or third degree heart block
  • Peripheral vascular disease or raynaud phenomenon 

Other options:

Option A: The clinical history of raised IOP and optic disc changes is suggestive of glaucoma and topical beta-blockers (like timolol) are used in the treatment of glaucoma to reduce intraocular pressure.

Option C: The clinical history of unilateral headache with visual aura is suggestive migraine and beta blockers are used in prophylaxis of migraine.

Option D: The clinical history of hypertension, severe tearing chest pain, and unequal BP in both arms is suggestive of aortic dissection and beta blockers are indicated in cases of aortic dissection to reduce heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female known case of coronary artery disease presented with chest pain and difficulty in breathing. On examination, her blood pressure was 140/70 mmHg and SpO2 was 76% at room air. She also had bilateral basal crepitations. A chest X-ray was done which is shown below. Which of the following is not a part of first-line management for your patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient presenting with chest pain, dyspnea, low SpO2, and bilateral basal crepitations along with history of CAD and Chest X-ray showing patchy bilateral perihilar consolidation (bat wing appearance ) is suggestive of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with pulmonary edema.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema occurs commonly following acute myocardial infarction, severe hypertension, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease (especially mitral regurgitation), and heart failure. These conditions result in left ventricular dysfunction, causing fluid to accumulate in the lungs. It presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum production, diaphoresis, and cyanosis. Auscultation reveals rales and rhonchi in all lung fields. Chest X-ray shows increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern. Cardiomegaly might be seen in cases of chronic heart failure.

Treatment of pulmonary edema:

  • Oxygen Therapy: Essential to maintain adequate oxygen saturation (aim for >92%). High-flow nasal cannula is preferred for hypoxemic respiratory failure.
  • Positive-Pressure Ventilation: Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) or mechanical ventilation helps reduce the work of breathing and improve oxygenation.
  • Diuretics (e.g., IV Furosemide): First-line for reducing fluid overload, decreasing preload, and improving symptoms. Higher doses may be needed for severe cases.
  • Nitrates (e.g., Nitroglycerin): Effective venodilators that reduce preload and can be used for acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 mg × 3 every 5min) is first-line therapy for acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • Inotropic Agents (e.g., Dobutamine): Used in cases of severe LV dysfunction with low cardiac output.
  • ACE Inhibitors: For hypertensive patients with heart failure, these reduce both preload and afterload.
  • IV nesiritide, a recombinant form of BNP, is a potent vasodilator that can also help reduce both preload and afterload in refractory cases of cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • Renal Replacement Therapy: Considered in refractory cases with acidosis, hypoxemia, or persistent hyperkalemia.


Other Measures:

Morphine: Can reduce anxiety and preload but is used cautiously due to potential mortality risks.
Physical Positioning: In non-hypotensive patients, sitting with legs dangling can reduce venous return.

questions.text: Below is a graph showing the effect of V/Q on gaseous exchange for a normal subject. A V/Q  ratio of 3 would correspond to which of the following points on the graph?
questions.solution:
A V/Q ratio of 3 will correspond to point 4 on the graph shown in a normal subject.

A higher V/Q ratio of 3 means increased ventilation as seen in the upper lobes of the lung. Increased ventilation leads to improved gaseous exchange, resulting in elevated partial pressure of oxygen (Po2) and reduced partial pressure of carbon dioxide (Pco2). Therefore, a V/Q ratio of 3 would be positioned further to the right on the graph and slightly lower.

The normal average V/Q ratio of the entire lung is 0.8. This value varies within the three zones due to differences in gravitational force, perfusion and alveolar and arterial pressure as shown in the image below. The drop in perfusion is greater than the drop in ventilation from base to apex. This causes a high ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio at the apex. 

The change in the position of v/q on gaseous exchange with respect to the different zones will be as follows:

Related Pearl: Zones of Pulmonary Blood Flow

Zone 1

Zero perfusion

  • Does not exist in normal lungs.
  • Occurs when the Pulmonary arterial pressure becomes less than alveolar air pressure.
  • Pulmonary capillaries become collapsed.

Zone 2

Intermittent blood flow

  • This occurs during systole when the pulmonary arterial pressure raises more than alveolar air pressure.
  • In normal lungs, this zone occurs from apex to hilum of the lungs.

Zone 3

Continuous blood flow

  • Here pulmonary arterial pressure is greater than alveolar air pressure during the entire cardiac cycle.
  • In normal lungs, this zone occurs from the middle zone of lungs to base.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child comes with pain and an intraoral swelling for 2 years. A biopsy of the swelling was taken and is shown below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin and vimentin. The most appropriate diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with pain and intraoral swelling along with an image showing spindle-shaped neoplastic cells with positive markers for desmin and vimentin is suggestive of rhabdomyosarcoma.

Rhabdomyosarcomas are malignant mesenchymal tumors with skeletal muscle differentiation in childhood and adolescence that may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%) and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

It is classified into three subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present. Sarcoma botryoids are a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer. It commonly affects children below 5 years of age.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma has a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults. 

Clinically, the tumor is usually aggressive, with unilateral proptosis when the orbit is involved. Swelling and redness of the overlying skin, diplopia may be present. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases.

Treatment involves surgical resection and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy. The best prognosis is for the botryoid variant while the pleomorphic variant has the worst prognosis.

Other options:

Option B: Neuroblastoma arises from neural crest cells, typically presents in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain, and would not show desmin positivity.

Option C: Synovial sarcoma is a soft tissue tumor more common in young adults, it typically shows cytokeratin or EMA positivity rather than desmin and vimentin.

Option D: Liposarcoma is a malignant fat tissue tumor, usually occurring in adults, and would stain positive for S100 rather than desmin or vimentin.

questions.text: According to NADA's criteria, the presence of which of the following findings alone indicates congenital heart disease in an infant?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the presence of a diastolic murmur alone indicates congenital heart disease in an infant according to NADA's criteria as this is a part of the major criteria. NADA’s criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Major criteria include -

  • Systolic murmur grade of 3 or more
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cyanosis
  • Congestive cardiac failure

Minor criteria include -

  • Systolic murmur grade of 1 or 2
  • Abnormal second heart sound
  • Abnormal X-ray
  • Abnormal ECG
  • Abnormal BP

questions.text: An elderly primigravida presented at 26 weeks of gestation. A 75 gram two-hour oral glucose tolerance test revealed a blood sugar level of 175 mg/dL. A diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus was made. Which of the following hormones is not responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly primigravida in her second trimester with a 75 gram 2-hour plasma glucose level of >153 mg/dL is diagnostic of gestational diabetes mellitus. The reason for developing gestational diabetes mellitus is insulin resistance, in which hCG has no role.

Maternal blood glucose levels increase in the second half of pregnancy to facilitate increased glucose transfer from the mother to the fetus. As feedback, there is hyperplasia and hypertrophy of the beta cells of islets of Langerhans in the maternal pancreas, causing hyperinsulinemia (especially in the third trimester) and a decrease in the levels of glucose available to the fetus. To ensure a continuous supply of glucose to the fetus, the placenta secretes certain hormones that increase insulin resistance in the mother.

Pregnancy being a state of low-grade inflammation is marked by factors like IL-6 and C-reactive proteins that also contribute to insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is seen maximally between 24 to 28 weeks. The hormones responsible for insulin resistance in pregnancy include,

  • Human placental lactogen 
  • Progesterone and estrogen
  • Placental growth hormone 
  • Cortisol
  • Prolactin

The screening method for GDM recommended in India is a 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) irrespective of the last meal timing. A value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2 hours is considered a positive test, indicating GDM. Universal screening is done for all pregnant women. The first testing should be done during the first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy. The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative (as in this case).

questions.text: Which of the following scales is primarily used to evaluate the socioeconomic status based on income and can be applied to both urban and rural populations in India?
questions.solution:
Among the following scales, the one that is primarily used to evaluate socioeconomic status based on income, and can be applied to both urban and rural populations in India is the BG Prasad scale.

Socioeconomic status (SES) is a composite measure that reflects an individual's or family’s position within society, based on various factors such as income, occupation, educational attainment, and material possessions. SES is often used in public health and social sciences to understand disparities in health, access to resources, and quality of life across different population groups. 

Other commonly used scales include: 

  • Modified Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the SES in urban and peri-urban areas and not in rural areas
  • Uday Pareek scale should be used for those in rural areas (option B)

Other options:

Option D: The likert scale is not a scale used for SES. It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: A sample of the clotted blood within the pulmonary artery of a patient who died of metastatic pancreatic cancer showed the following. What does this finding signify?

choices.text: It is only seen in arterial clots
It is formed when the blood flow is stagnant
The dark bands are composed of hemosiderin granules

questions.solution:
The clinical history and the histopathological finding showing thrombus with laminations of pale and dark lines indicate lines of Zahn which signify that the clot was formed antemortem.

The pale areas in the lines of Zahn are due to platelet and fibrin deposition, and the darker layer is the red cell-rich layer (Option D). The laminations indicate that the thrombus was formed when the blood was flowing (Option C) through the vessel i.e. antemortem. Clots formed after death will be plain and bland without laminations.

These are seen in both arterial and venous clots (option B) and it has nothing to do with the source of the clot.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent pregnancy losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions, all of them at <10 weeks of gestational age, and has a history of deep vein thrombosis. The presence of which of the following antibodies is not included in the laboratory criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
The antinuclear antibody is not included in the laboratory criteria for the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

Recurrent pregnancy loss is a term used for three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions of the fetus before 20 weeks of gestation. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. The antiphospholipid antibodies cause inflammation, thrombosis, and abnormal placentation leading to recurrent miscarriage, usually before 10 weeks of gestation. 

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion and must be positive on 2 or more occasions 12 weeks apart.

  • Clinical criteria
    • Obstetric
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular: one or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue 
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Treatment:

  • Low-dose aspirin (60-80 mg/day)
  • Unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin

 These drugs are started at the time of diagnosis and are given until 6 weeks postpartum.

questions.text:

The correct answer is 3, 4 and 5 only. The above image shows elastic cartilage. It is seen in corniculate cartilage, cuneiform cartilage and apices of arytenoids. The given section is stained by Verhoeff’s method in which elastic fibres are stained bluish-black.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium. On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

  • External auditory meatus
  • Auditory tube
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Epiglottis
  • Apices of arytenoids

Thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage are composed of hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long history of tobacco smoking presents with complaints of increasing fogginess of vision, especially in the evening and dull light, making reading and near work difficult. Which visual field defects are most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a 45-year-old male with history of smoking presenting with increasing fogginess of vision, particularly in the evening and under dull light, making reading and near work difficult, has tobacco-induced optic neuropathy and the visual field defect most commonly associated with this condition is centrocecal scotoma. 

Tobacco-induced optic neuropathy is a condition that results from long-term tobacco use, particularly in individuals who smoke cigars or pipes or work in tobacco factories. Patients, usually between the ages of 35-50, may experience a gradual onset of vision problems after years of heavy tobacco use. The toxic agents, including cyanide in tobacco smoke and vitamin B12 deficiency, lead to degeneration of the retinal ganglion cells, particularly in the macula, and affect the papillomacular bundle in the optic nerve.

Clinically, patients complain of increasing fogginess of vision, especially in low light conditions or in the evening, which impairs near tasks like reading. Central vision becomes severely diminished, while peripheral vision remains intact. The visual field defect primarily affects the centrocaecal area, creating a scotoma between the fixation point and the blind spot. 

Treatment focuses on discontinuing tobacco and patients may benefit from vitamin B12 supplementation (hydroxycobalamin), with a good prognosis if these changes are made, though visual improvement can take months.

Option A: Altitudinal visual field defect (VFD) is a condition where visual sensation is lost in the superior or inferior half of the visual field while the horizontal midline is preserved.

Option C: Bjerrums scotoma: presents as an arcuate (bow-shaped) defect extending from the blind spot to the horizontal meridian, characteristic of glaucoma and related to retinal nerve fiber layer damage.

Option D: Peripheral field constriction, also known as tunnel vision, is a visual field defect that occurs when the peripheral vision shrinks or is distorted. Peripheral field constriction is often a side effect of other medical conditions, such as glaucoma or retinitis pigmentosa.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Vincent’s angina (trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing infection of the oral cavity and the oropharynx.

questions.text:
Match the following viruses with their vectors.
Virus Vector
1. Hanta virus A. Aedes aegypti
2. Chikungunya virus B. Culex tritaeniorhynchus
3. Kayasanur Forest disease virus C. Field mice

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B (1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B). The viruses matched to their respective vectors are as follows :

Virus Vector

2. Chikungunya virus A. Aedes aegypti
3. Kayasanur Forest disease virus D. Haemaphysalis ticks

The Hantaan virus belongs to the genus Hantavirus and causes severe hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) in the Far East, North Asia, and Russia. They are a rodent-borne (robo) virus maintained in nature and transmitted by rodents. Hantavirus species are natural pathogens of rodents - field mice (Apodemus agrarius)

Chikungunya virus belongs to the genus Alphavirus. All of the viruses belonging to this genus are mosquito-borne. In India, it caused very extensive epidemics in Kolkata, Chennai, and other areas. The vector is Aedes aegypti. The disease presents with a sudden onset of fever, joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. A maculopapular rash is common, although hemorrhagic manifestations are rare. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1-6 days.

Kayasanur Forest disease (KFD) virus causes a hemorrhagic fever found in the state of Karnataka, India. KFD has an abrupt onset of fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and severe prostration. Some cases develop hemorrhages in the skin, mucosa, and viscera. Infection is transmitted by the bite of ticks, the principal vector being Haemaphysalis spinigera.

Japanese encephalitis is endemic to 15 states including Uttar Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal etc. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus mosquito (which breeds in rice fields) and Culex vishnuii mosquito.  Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. Human infection is a tangential ‘Dead end’. The disease has an abrupt onset with fever, headache, and vomiting. After 1-6 days, signs of encephalitis set in with nuchal rigidity, convulsions, altered sensorium, and coma. The fever is high and continuous. Infection in pregnant women during first and second trimester can lead to fetal death.

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the 24-hour levels of a hormone. Choose the factors which increase its secretion.
  1. Arginine infusion 
  2. Stage IV sleep
  3. Increased free fatty acids in the blood
  4. Ghrelin
  5. REM sleep
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early periods of sleep, indicating that it is the growth hormone (GH). Growth hormone secretion is increased by arginine infusion, ghrelin, and deep sleep (stages II and IV) among the given factors.

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Important regulators of growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone stimulates the production of the hormone
  • Somatostatin inhibits the release of GH
  • Ghrelin increases the GH release (statement 4)

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  1. Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting
  2. Exercise
  3. Infusion of arginine (statement 1)
  4. Protein-rich meal
  5. Glucagon
  6. Deep sleep (stages II and IV) (statement 2)
  7. Estrogens and androgens
  8. Stressful stimuli

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  1. Glucose 
  2. Cortisol
  3. Free fatty acids (statement 3)
  4. Growth hormone and IGF-1
  5. REM sleep (statement 5)
  6. Medroxyprogesterone

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF). The functions which are mediated through IGFs are insulin-like activity, anti-lipolytic activity, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth. Direct actions of GH are sodium retention, decreased insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl came for the evaluation of anemia and mild jaundice. She gives a history of fever with enlarged tonsils and multiple neck nodes a few days back. Which of the following is the cause of anemia in this patient?

choices.text: Binding of IgM to RBCs at 0- 4 ℃
Binding of IgM to RBCs at 37 ℃
Binding of IgG to RBCs at 0- 4 ℃
Binding of IgG to RBCs at 37 ℃

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a young girl with anaemia and jaundice, and a history of fever, enlarged tonsils, and multiple neck nodes, suggesting a diagnosis of immune hemolytic anaemia (cold agglutinin type) due to Infectious mononucleosis which is due to the binding of IgM to RBCs at 0-4 degrees.

Cold agglutinin type of immune hemolytic anaemia is due to the binding of IgM to RBCs at low temperatures (0-4 ℃) but not at 37℃ especially in areas like exposed fingers, toes, and ears. This binding agglutinates the red cells leading to complement fixation by the activation of the classical pathway. 

When the temperature becomes >30℃ and the blood warms and recirculates, IgM is released leaving the red cells with C3b of the complement pathway attached to them. This C3b acts as an opsonin and leads to phagocytosis of the red cells by macrophage and hence hemolysis. Complement-mediated hemolysis occurs predominantly in the liver, spleen and bone marrow after IgM is released leading to extravascular hemolysis.

Thus, although antibody binding occurs at cool temperatures, hemolysis occurs at warm temperatures.

questions.text: A  pregnant woman at term gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements. A non-stress test was done and the cardiotocograph is given below. Which of the following conditions does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The above cardiotocography (CTG) image shows variable deceleration, which indicates umbilical cord compression.

Normal baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 110-160 bpm (beats per minute). Baseline FHR shows a beat-to-beat fluctuation in amplitude and frequency ranging from 5-25 bpm. This is called baseline variability. Whenever the fetus moves, there is a transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm lasting for 10- 15 seconds. This is called acceleration. Acceleration and normal baseline variability (5-25 bpm) is a sign of a healthy fetus.

Deceleration is the decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s. Following are the various types of decelerations seen on CTG and their clinical significance:

Feature Early deceleration Late deceleration Variable deceleration
The pattern of heart rate fall

Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate.

The maximum dip of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the contraction. 

Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate.

Onset, maximum dip, and recovery occur after the onset, peak, and recovery of contraction respectively.

Abrupt fall in the heart rate.   

Decelerations are variable in respect of the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions.
Time taken to reach the maximum dip of deceleration  >30seconds  >30seconds  <30 seconds
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental insufficiency, and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: The muscle in the given image of the gluteal region upon inflammation can compress the sciatic nerve causing pain along the distribution of the nerve which is termed “Sciatica”. Which of the following statements is correct about this given muscle?

choices.text: It is a medial rotator of the thigh in extension
It is supplied by the sciatic nerve
Superior gluteal nerve passes below it
It is a content of greater sciatic foramen

questions.solution:
The muscle in the given image is the piriformis muscle. Piriformis muscle is a content of Greater Sciatic Foramen.

The piriformis muscle is present below and parallel to the posterior border of the gluteus medius and forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. It passes out of the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

The greater sciatic foramen is formed by the sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligament. The piriformis muscle passes through the foramen, dividing it into a supra-piriform foramen and an infra-piriform foramen. 

The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and passes through the muscle fibers or below the muscle. Sometimes, inflammation of the piriformis muscle can lead to Piriformis Syndrome, which is characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the Sciatic nerve, which is also known as Sciatica.

Other options:

Option A: Piriformis muscle is a lateral rotator of the thigh in extension and abductor of the thigh in the flexed position.

Option B: The sciatic nerve does not give any supply to muscles in the gluteal region. 

Option C: The superior gluteal nerve passes above the piriformis muscle through the greater sciatic foramen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has moderate hypertension for the past few years. The given image shows a section of a small blood vessel of this patient. What is the finding seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with narrowing of the lumen is seen in the above slide.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis, which is the thickening of the vessel wall with loss of its elasticity. It has two variants:

  • Hyaline arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in chronic hypertension. Chronic changes in blood pressure damage the vessel wall leading to the deposition of plasma proteins and matrix. On microscopy, it appears as a homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with the narrowing of the lumen. It is also seen in elderly patients (normotensive or hypertensive) and diabetes mellitus.
  • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in severe hypertension. Microscopy shows a characteristic concentric, laminated (onion peel appearance) thickening of the vessel wall with luminal narrowing. It is the characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension.

In medium and large vessels it can lead to degenerative changes and can cause aortic dissection and cerebrovascular hemorrhage.

The image below shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

Monckeberg medial sclerosis is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic lamina. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is usually an incidental finding. 

The following image shows Monckeberg medial sclerosis of an artery.

Atherosclerotic plaque is yellow-tan that is raised above the vessel wall. It occurs due to intimal thickening and lipid accumulation. The lumen appears irregular. The given image shows atherosclerosis:

questions.text: You are an intern at a hospital that has adopted Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). This global initiative aims to:
questions.solution:
The Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) is a global initiative that aims to promote breastfeeding. It is sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund.

It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding.

They are split into critical management procedures and key clinical practice. Integration of all these steps ensures good breastfeeding practices. The implementation guidance for BFHI emphasizes the strategies to promote universal coverage and ensure sustainability over time. The guidance focuses on the integration of the programme in the healthcare system and ensures the implementation of these steps in all levels of health facilities in the nation. 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the surgery department with a complaint of unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Ductoscopy revealed a firm, palpable nodule 3 cm away from the nipple inside a single duct. What is the management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman presenting with unilateral bloody nipple discharge with ductoscopy findings suggests intraductal papilloma and it is managed by microdochectomy.

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It is defined as Localized hyperplasia of the ductal epithelium within the duct. According to the ANDI (Aberrations of normal development and involution of breast tissue) classification, it is an aberration of normal epithelial turnover. It comprises a central fibrovascular core and papillary projections of the epithelium and myoepithelial cells. The papillary lesions in a duct are of three types:

  • Solitary papilloma
  • Papillomatosis: five or more papillomas
  • Juvenile papillomatosis, also called Swiss cheese disease

Intraductal papilloma is commonly seen in premenopausal women. It is the most common cause of spontaneous nipple discharge from a single duct. These papillomas are located close to the nipple and are associated with bloody nipple discharge. Sometimes, a palpable mass under the areola may be present. 

A triple assessment, consisting of clinical examination, imaging, and pathology, should be performed to exclude carcinoma. Ultrasonography may reveal a dilated subareolar duct and a papillary growth within. A ductoscopy shows a firm, palpable nodule inside the duct. Most duct papillomas are located up to a distance of 5 cm from the nipple.

The treatment for single-duct discharge is microdochectomy, which involves making a tennis racquet-shaped incision and removing the papilloma and a single duct involved. Hadfield’s procedure(cone excision of ducts) is used when multiple ducts are involved. 

Note: Hadfield’s procedure is also done for recurrent cases of duct ectasia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who frequently travels barefoot is suspected to have acquired a parasitic infection via skin penetration. Any of the following parasites may be implicated in this case except?
questions.solution:
The mode of infection of Ancylostoma, Strongyloides, and Schistosoma is by the penetration of the skin. Ingestion of eggs containing rhabditiform larva is the mode of infection in Ascaris. 

Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris. These eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva. 

Options B: Ancylostoma duodenale (Old World hookworm) and Necator americanus (New World hookworm) the infective third-stage filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the subcutaneous tissue. Severe itching caused at the site of penetration is known as ground itch and migration of the larvae in the subcutaneous tissue is known as creeping eruptions.

Options C: The third stage filariform larva is the infective form of Strongyloides stercoralis. These larvae can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.

Option D: Schistosoma haematobium, S. mansoni, and S.japonicum are blood flukes that live in venous plexuses. The infective form in these organisms is the fork-tailed cercariae. These cercariae have suckers and secrete lytic substances that help penetrate intact skin. Following the penetration, intense irritation and skin rash develops at the site and is known as swimmer's itch or cercarial dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient was prepared for surgery and anesthesia was induced with ketamine. In which of the following patients is induction with ketamine contraindicated?

choices.text: Rapid sequence anesthesia induction in trauma patients

questions.solution:
Induction of anesthesia with ketamine is contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Ketamine causes significant increases in arterial blood pressure and heart rate. This is due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system and inhibition in norepinephrine reuptake at the nerve terminals. There is also an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and myocardial work. Thus, it should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, congestive heart failure, or arterial aneurysms.  

Other contraindications for ketamine are as follows: 

  • Open eye injury or other ophthalmic disorder with increased intraocular pressure
  • Ischemic heart disease, vascular aneurysm
  • Schizophrenia
  • Known drug hypersensitivity
  • Pregnancy or breastfeeding due to the potential for being secreted into breast milk
  • Intoxication with ethanol

Ketamine is related to phencyclidine that is used for general anesthesia either alone or in combination with other drugs. It produces dissociative anesthesia. It is used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia, sedation, and analgesia. 

It has a fast onset (within seconds when given intravenously and within minutes when given intramuscularly) with a short duration of action. 

Other options: 

Option A - Patients with hemorrhagic shock can benefit from ketamine as it is the only anesthetic to increase peripheral arteriolar resistance. It stimulates the sympathetic nervous system leading to increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. 

Option C - Ketamine is the drug of choice in patients with reactive airway disease as it causes bronchodilation and can be used to treat bronchospasm. 

Option D - Ketamine can be used for rapid sequence anesthesia induction in trauma patients due to its short action and fast onset. It can be used for procedures requiring short-term sedation/and anesthesia in the emergency department.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old pregnant woman with polyhydramnios was denied a vaginal delivery. She previously had a vaginal delivery for her twin pregnancy 7 years ago and had undergone an LSCS for CPD in her last pregnancy 5 years ago. She also had a laparoscopic myomectomy 2 years ago for the treatment of fibroids. Which of the following is a contraindication for VBAC in this patient?

[LSCS: Lower Uterine Segment Caeserean Section

CPD: Cephalo-Pelvic Disproportion

VBAC: Vaginal Birth After Caeserean section]
questions.solution:
A history of laparoscopic myomectomy is a contraindication for Vaginal Birth After Caeserean section (VBAC) in this patient.

Other Contraindications for VBAC include:

  • Previous classical C-Section
  • Previous inverted T-shaped uterine incision
  • History of prior uterine rupture
  • History of myomectomy or hysterotomy
  • Previous more than two LSCS (lower segment cesarean section)
  • Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD in the current pregnancy
  • Presence of other complications in current pregnancy: Obstetric (pre-eclampsia,
    malpresentation, placenta previa) or medical
  • Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)

Twins and Polyhydramnios are not a contradiction for VBAC. (Option A and B)

Selection Criteria of cases for VBAC (ACOG) include:

  • Two previous lower-segment transverse scars
  •  Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section
  •  Pelvis adequate for the fetus
  •  Continued labor monitoring is possible
  •  Availability of resources (anesthesia, blood transfusion, and theater) for  emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of decision 
  • Informed consent of the woman

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has come with a chief complaint of low backache. The CT scan is shown below. What is the name of the sign shown and the likely disease present respectively?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows the Jail-Bar sign, which is seen in Vetebral Hemangioma.

Hemangioma is a typically benign tumor of the vertebral body seen in an elderly population. The most common site involved is the spine >skull> pelvis.  

The CT Scan shows a coarse vertical striated appearance of  the Jail bar/Jail House sign or Corduroy appearance in coronal  sections. On axial CT it will show a classical polka-dot appearance due to thickened trabecular vertebrae. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas.

Other options:

Option A: Bamboo spine - Ankylosing Spondylitis: Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis.

Option B: Rugger jersey spine- Osteoporosis: X-ray shows alternating bands of sclerosis and lucency throughout, resembling a Rugger jersey.


Option D: Ivory vertebrae- Paget's disease: A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity is referred to as the ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

questions.text: A young male presented with recurrent episodes of dyspnea and wheezing for the last 4 weeks. On auscultation bilateral wheeze is present, spirometry shows obstructive pattern and sputum microscopy revealed the following image. Which of the following is seen in the disease he is suffering from?

choices.text: Strong association with IL13 gene polymorphism
Crystals in the sputum made of desquamated epithelial cells

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals, lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils are diagnostic of bronchial asthma, which has a strong association with IL13 gene polymorphism. 

In the given clinical scenario, a young male presented with recurrent episodes of dyspnea and bilateral wheezing for the last 4 weeks with spirometry showing an obstructive pattern and sputum microscopy showing Charcot Leyden crystals which suggests the diagnosis of asthma.

Other options :

Option A: In asthma, Reid Index is normal. It is increased in chronic bronchitis. 

Option C: Charcot-Leyden crystals are made of eosinophilic protein - galectin 10. 

Option D: In Asthma, Th2-mediated IgE response to environmental allergens is seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer who is a known case of asthma presents with shortness of breath and productive cough with golden brown mucus plugs for the past 2-3 weeks. His symptoms began after exposure to plant waste. Since he was not responding to inhaled corticosteroids, a CT was done. Which of the following is not a major criterion to confirm your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical case of an asthma patient with shortness of breath and a productive cough refractory to treatment, along with an image showing ground glass opacities (gloved finger pattern), suggests allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Golden brown sputum is not a major criterion for diagnosing ABPA.

The Rosenberg-Patterson criteria for diagnosis of ABPA include:

Major criteria: (ARTEPICS)

  • Asthma (A)
  • Radiographic: Presence of transient pulmonary infiltrates (fleeting shadows) (R)
  • Skin Testing: Immediate cutaneous reactivity to Af (A. fumigatus) (T)
  • Peripheral blood Eosinophilia (E)
  • Precipitating antibodies against Af (P)
  • Elevated total serum IgE (I)
  • Central/proximal bronchiectasis with normal tapering of distal bronchi (C)
  • Serum A fumigatus specific IgG and IgE (S)

Minor criteria:

  • Expectoration of golden brownish sputum plugs
  • Positive sputum culture for Aspergillus species
  • Late (Arthus-type) skin reactivity to Af 

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis. In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory compromise. 

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough, an increase in sputum production, or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts or developing frank hemoptysis. The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific.

The use of systemic glucocorticoids is the first line in the management of ABPA, but the course should be tapered by 3-6 months. Antifungal agents like itraconazole, voriconazole, and newer azoles can be used for over 4 months to control disease activity. However, this is only after steroids have been initiated to control the symptoms. Monoclonal antibodies against IgE, IL-4, and IL-5 receptors can be used for severe refractory cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came to the hospital with a history of headaches, seizures, memory loss, and mood changes.  The given image is obtained by doing an MRI scan. Which of the following drugs is useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the MRI scan finding are suggestive of glioblastoma. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

Temozolomide belongs to the triazene group of alkylating agents and is administered orally. The oral bioavailability of temozolomide is nearly 100%. It forms a methylating metabolite and kills cells in all phases of the cell cycle.

Glioblastoma is the most malignant astrocytic tumor - WHO grade IV. It spreads along the white matter tracts and crosses the midline via the corpus callosum, giving rise to the so-called butterfly glioma. 

Other options:

Option A- Streptozocin belongs to the nitrosourea group of alkylating agents and has a high affinity of islets of Langerhans. It is used in the treatment of pancreatic islet cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumors.

Option C- Ifosfamide belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and an analog of cyclophosphamide. Ifosfamide is used in germ cell tumors of testes and sarcomas. It has maximum neurotoxicity which can be treated with methylene blue. It has a urothelial damaging capacity like cyclophosphamide which can be treated with MESNA (sodium-2-mercaptoethanol sulfonate).

Option D- Chlorambucil belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and is an orally administered drug. It is almost exclusively used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, chronic smoker presents with persistent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a feeling of fullness in the throat. His CT and biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the base of the tongue. Which of the marked areas contains the lymph node levels that are first to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, when diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the base of the tongue, there is a risk for metastasis to cervical lymph nodes. The lymphatic drainage from the oropharynx, including the base of the tongue, primarily flows into the jugulodigastric (tonsillar) node and belongs to the level 2 group of cervical lymph nodes present in the area marked as 1 in the given image.

Carcinoma of the base of the tongue often remains asymptomatic until cervical lymph node metastasis appears. Early symptoms like sore throat, lump sensation, and mild dysphagia are often ignored. Late signs include referred ear pain, dysphagia, mouth bleeding, and a "hot potato" voice.

The tumour spreads locally to the tongue, epiglottis, tonsils, and hypopharynx. Lymphatic spread is common, with 70% of cases showing cervical metastases, primarily in the jugulodigastric nodes. Distant metastases can affect bones, liver, and lungs, with levels II, III, and IV nodes often involved.

Diagnosis is confirmed with laryngoscopy, palpation, CT scans, and biopsy. Treatment depends on the stage:

  • Early tumours (T1/T2) may be treated with surgery and radiotherapy.
  • Advanced cases (T3/T4) require more extensive surgery (mandibular resection, neck dissection) and postoperative radiotherapy.
  • For advanced or poor health patients, palliative care with radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and supportive measures (tracheostomy, gastrostomy) may be needed.

questions.text: The best parameter for estimation of fetal age by USG in 2nd trimester is ______.
questions.solution:
Biparietal diameter (BPD) is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in the 2nd trimester. Accuracy varies from 7 to 10 days. 

BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field. The best parameters for the estimation of fetal age are-

  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 8 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for her routine evaluation. On performing a bimanual examination, you notice regular rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall. Which early sign of pregnancy is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
The early sign of pregnancy being elicited here is the Palmer's sign.

Palmer’s sign denotes the regular, rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall during a bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks of gestation.

Other options:

Option A- Hegar’s sign is an early sign of pregnancy. At 6-8 weeks of gestation, the lower part of the uterus softens and on bimanual examination, the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers is possible.

Option C- Osiander's sign describes the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity. It is seen around 8 weeks of gestation.

Option D- Goodell’s sign is a sign of early pregnancy which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen around 6-8 weeks of gestation.

questions.text:
As an NGO officer visiting certain areas in Africa, you notice that children have moist, red, ulcerated lesions on their shins resembling raspberries. They report that the primary lesion started as a single firm papule. You suspect it to be a case of Yaws and a PCR test is done from the ulcerated lesion. What is the causative agent likely to be seen?

NGO - Non-Governmental Organization

PCR -  Polymerase Chain Reaction
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and suspicion of Yaws is suggestive that the likely causative agent to be seen is Treponema pertenue.

Yaws is a disabling disease most commonly seen in children of tropical rural populations, where transmission is favored by overcrowding populations.In the primary stage presents with an initial lesion (‘mother yaw’) which is usually a solitary firm papule at the point of entry of the treponemes. This later becomes a moist red ulcer that is covered by a yellowish crust and granulating edge. The lesion is said to resemble a raspberry and is full of treponemes. India is the first country in the world to be officially acknowledged as being yaws-free. The WHO declared India free of yaws on 5th May 2016. Globally, Yaws remains endemic in certain parts of Africa, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific, efforts are focused on its complete eradication.

Mother yaws are most common on the leg and may persist for several months before healing spontaneously to leave an atrophic, sometimes hypopigmented scar Lymphadenopathy and arthralgia may also occur at this stage.

The image below shows a single, non-tender "mother yaw" ulcer of primary yaws.

In the secondary stage, multiple lesions called ‘Daughter yaws’ develop as smaller lesions in successive crops and are often adjacent to body orifices after the initial lesion has healed. The lesions can then evolve into papules, exuberant exophytic lesions, ulcers, and even hyperkeratotic plaques. These secondary lesions heal spontaneously within weeks to months, although relapses can occur. Fever, malaise, and osteitis may accompany this stage. The late tertiary stage is characterized by gummata, most commonly in the skin, bones, and nose. This can lead to bowing of the tibia (Sabre tibia), saddle nose deformities, and destructive lesions of the nasopharynx and palate (Gangosa).

As the organisms are closely related, serological tests used in syphilis are also employed in yaws. As with T. pallidum, T. pertenue is non-cultivable by conventional laboratory methods. Molecular diagnostic procedures, such as Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), confirm Yaws by detecting the T. pertenue DNA in the skin lesions. All cases require antibiotic treatment, typically with parenteral Penicillin or Azithromycin.

Other options :

Option A: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease which is caused by Treponema pallidum.

Option B: Pinta is a rare tropical skin disease caused by Treponema carateum. Presents with marked skin color changes without causing destructive lesions, and manifesting lesions are pruritic papules followed by pintides and finally, dyschromatic macules, which later become depigmented.

Option D: Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It is characterized by infection in the lymphatic system of the genital area.

questions.text: A diabetic patient after sustaining an abrasion wound while working in the field, presented with acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates. Microscopy of the sample from the exudate showed gram-negative bacilli with typical bipolar staining with Wright’s stain,  prompting suspicion of Melioidosis. Which of the following is the best-suited culture medium to grow this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the microscopic finding of gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar staining with Wright's stain is characteristic of melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. Ashdown medium is selective for B. pseudomallei.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. It is an infection acquired by the contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Clinically, melioidosis presents in two forms.

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case-fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining, gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain/ Wright's stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibody, indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. Ashdown medium is a culture selective for B. pseudomallei.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium.

The image below shows gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance.

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Pap smear in 40 year old females
Screening of immigrants in a country
Screening for urine sugar in 40 year old males

questions.solution:
Prospective screening is done for control of a disease and usually for the benefit of others like screening immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis and syphilis.

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection and people are screened for their own benefit like neonatal screening and Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

Testing for urine sugar in men over 40 would also be prescriptive screening.

questions.text: While working on a physiology simulation model to study the pathophysiology of essential hypertension, a researcher observes an increase in heart rate and BP during stimulation of a particular area on the medullary surface. Which of the following structures is he likely to have stimulated?
questions.solution:
Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) acts as the vasomotor/pressor center.

Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is a group of neurons in the pial surface of the medulla, its axons descend down and are present in the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord. It secretes the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate and activates the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. It increases blood pressure and causes tachycardia.

It is negatively regulated by the depressor area/caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) which gets input from baroreceptors.

Remember:

  • RVLM- Rise the HR and BP (pressor area)
  • CVLM- Calms BP (depressor area)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the primary hormone secreted from layer 1 is correct?
  1. Causes Na+ retention
  2. Increases urine acidity
  3. Increases on prolonged standing
  4. Causes hyperglycemia
  5. When in excess, it leads to long-term edema
questions.solution:
The marked layer 1 is zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex and the primary hormone secreted by this layer is Aldosterone. The correct statements about it are 1,2,3.

Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by increased angiotensin II levels and increased plasma potassium levels. It stimulates the reabsorption of sodium from the principal cells of the collecting duct by increasing the expression of sodium channels (ENaC) and  Na+-K+ ATPase activity. It also increases the expression of Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb and the Na+/Cl- symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.(Statement 1)

The reabsorption of sodium generates an electrochemical gradient that facilitates chloride and water reabsorption. Aldosterone also stimulates potassium secretion by the late distal tubule and collecting ducts and secretion of hydrogen ions by the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. There is a loss of K+ lon with H+ ion in the urine leading to increased urinary acidity. (Statement 2)

Though Na+ is retained initially, the plasma Na+ remains normal or only slightly elevated if at all, because water is retained with the osmotically active sodium ions. Consequently, ECF volume is expanded and the blood pressure rises. But at a certain point in ECF expansion, there is the release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) which causes Na+ excretion despite increased secretion of aldosterone. This phenomenon is called the aldosterone escape phenomenon. Due to this, mineralocorticoids do not produce edema in normal individuals and patients with hyperaldosteronism. (Statement 5)

However, the escape may not occur in certain disease states, and in these situations, continued expansion of ECF volume can lead to edema.

Aldosterone secretion is increased by high potassium intake, low sodium intake, constriction of the inferior vena cava in the thorax, standing, and secondary hyperaldosteronism (in some cases of heart failure, cirrhosis, and nephrosis). Standing for >120 minutes leads to a fall in renal perfusion --> increased renin secretion --> increased Aldosterone secretion (Statement 3)

Aldosterone does not cause hyperglycemia; this is the effect of cortisol, which increases blood glucose through gluconeogenesis. (Statement 4)

The adrenal cortex consists of three zones. The outermost zone, zone 1, is known as the zona glomerulosa which secrete mineralocorticoids like aldosterone and deoxycorticosterone. Zone 2 is known as zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids like cortisol and corticosterone. Zone 3 is the zona reticularis, and secretes sex steroids like DHEA and androstenedione. The adrenal medulla, represented by zone 4 secretes the catecholamines epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. Image showing the histological section of the adrenal gland -

choices.text: Mastoid process is narrow and pointed

Orbits are round with sharp margin

questions.solution:
Frontal and parietal eminences are smaller in a male skull; hence, option C is correct.

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest X-ray of the neonate is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of an infant born to a diabetic mother, presenting with progressive cyanosis and tachypnea with an X-ray showing the egg-on-side appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries. 

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers and is more common in males. The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-rays show mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg-on-string appearance) shown in the image below with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. Egg-on-string or globular-shaped heart is due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

An ECHO confirms the transposed ventricular-arterial connection and is diagnostic. A color doppler examination is used to visualize the size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus. It also assesses the degree of mixing, and presence of any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect. 

Other options:

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. 

In supracardiac (TAPVC)  the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below.

Option B: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. 

In the Ebstein anomaly, there is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot as shown below.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented at 29 weeks of gestation presented with a 5-day history of severe, sharp, and constant abdominal pain. An ultrasound scan showed a uterine fibroid. A subsequent MRI revealed changes in the fibroid consistent with the image below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Removal of fibroid at caesarean section
Termination of pregnancy by induction of labour
Laparotomy for removal of fibroid alone

questions.solution:
The given MRI shows a subserosal uterine mass with a peripheral high signal due to hemorrhage. The clinical scenario and the image suggest red degeneration of the fibroid, which is managed conservatively with analgesics.

Myomectomy at cesarean section carries the risk of uncontrolled bleeding and hence is not done except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid.

Red degeneration is a complication (secondary change) of fibroids that often develop during pregnancy or over the age of 40. The myoma becomes tense and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple-red color and a fishy odor.

The image below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration- heterogeneous mass on T2 (a) with peripheral high signal on T1 (b):


Hyaline degeneration is the most common secondary change whereas sarcomatous change is the least common.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with a history of postpartum hemorrhage during labor comes with complaints of failure to lactate and easy fatigability. On examination, She has a heart rate of 120 bpm and BP of 90/60 mmHg. An MRI is done to confirm the diagnosis. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female with a history of PPH with failure of lactation, tachycardia, hypotension, and an image showing empty sella is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome and glucocorticoids should be supplemented first, as life-threatening manifestations may occur due to the sudden onset of adrenal insufficiency.

Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Also, it can present late with the following features:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment:

  • Hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones (somatropin) are given.
  • If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.
  • Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective in these patients.

questions.text: Shown below is the pelvic ultrasound image of a 28-year-old female patient with a positive urine pregnancy test. She gave a history of recent treatment for infertility. Identify the classical radiological finding shown in her right adnexa.
questions.solution:
The image shows the bagel sign seen in tubal ectopic pregnancy.

The bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. It is characteristic of tubal ectopic pregnancy. This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. 

A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

A ring of fire appearance is seen on the colour doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass.  It is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A, Lambda sign: It is also known as the twin-peak sign and is seen in dichorionic pregnancy. The below image shows a schematic diagram of the twin-peak sign. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen insinuating between the amniochorion layers.

Option C: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy, as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below.

 Option D: T sign is a USG finding in monochorionic gestation. It is thin and is T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the intertwin membrane. It is as shown below.
