questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with cough and hemoptysis. There is a history of loss of weight and appetite. On further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with bronchogenic carcinoma. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following sign is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A Golden S sign is seen in this patient.

Golden S sign is a radiographical appearance seen in the right upper lobe collapse in bronchogenic carcinoma. Due to the central tumor mass associated with lobar collapse, the fissure will not be able to move as usual and it thus creates a bulge giving an S shape pattern on the radiograph. This S shape appearance is known as the Golden S sign. However, this sign is not specific to bronchogenic carcinoma and can occur in other etiologies involving lymphadenopathy or primary mediastinal tumors.

Below is the radiograph showing the Golden S sign. (The orange circle denotes the central tumor, and the green arrow represents the direction of expansion while inspiration)

Other options:

Option A- Luftsichel sign is seen in upper lobe collapse. It is the overinflation of the superior segment of the ipsilateral lower lobe that occupies between the mediastinum and the medial aspect of the upper lobe which results in paramediastinal translucency. This is usually seen more commonly on the left side.

Below is the radiograph of the Luftsichel sign.

Option B- Westermark sign is seen in chest radiographs of patients with pulmonary embolism, indicating focal oligemia.

Option C- Hampton's hump is a wedge-shaped consolidation in the peripheral area of the lungs that may indicate infarction in pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the act of vomiting?

choices.text: Starts with salivation and sensation of nausea

questions.solution:
The correct statement about the act of vomiting is that it starts with salivation and a sensation of nausea.

Vomiting is a protective response regulated by the central nervous system. It begins with salivation and nausea, followed by reverse peristalsis which moves material from the small intestine to the stomach. The glottis closes to prevent aspiration, and breathing is held in mid-inspiration. Abdominal muscles contract, increasing intraabdominal pressure, while the LES and esophagus relax, allowing gastric contents to be ejected. The vomiting center, located in the medulla's reticular formation controls this reflex.

The neural control of vomiting is primarily coordinated by the vomiting center and the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the brain. The vomiting center, located in the medulla, receives signals from various sources, such as the gastrointestinal tract, vestibular system, and higher brain centers. It orchestrates the motor responses required for vomiting and  CTZ, located in the area postrema of the medulla, is sensitive to blood-borne toxins and drugs. It communicates with the vomiting center to trigger emesis in response to chemical stimuli.

Other inputs involved include the vagus nerve and sympathetic nervous system, which transmit signals from the gut, as well as the vestibular nuclei for motion-induced vomiting.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in swallowing, a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat, and a burning sensation in his chest over the past month. A barium swallow study is performed, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient presenting with food impaction and dysphagia and barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is diagnosed based on the combination of typical esophageal symptoms and esophageal mucosal biopsies demonstrating squamous epithelial eosinophil-predominant inflammation.

Symptoms:

  • Adults: Food impaction, dysphagia, vomiting, and GERD-like symptoms
  • Children: Feeding intolerance and GERD-like symptoms
  • Patients are usually atopic and may also have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or modest peripheral eosinophilia.

Diagnosis:

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis. Fluoroscopy/barium studies show a small-caliber esophagus, transient or fixed circular rings, or a benign stricture. The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

Treatment:

Patients typically undergo a trial of PPI therapy to exclude GERD. 30–50% of cases respond to PPI therapy.

Children have been effectively treated with allergy testing combining skin prick and atopy patch testing. Both adults and children responded to empiric elimination of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) followed by systematic reintroduction.

Swallowed, topical glucocorticoids like fluticasone propionate or budesonide are highly effective but have high rates of recurrence after discontinuing therapy. Systemic glucocorticoids are reserved for severely afflicted patients refractory to less morbid treatments.

Esophageal dilation is very effective at relieving dysphagia in patients with fibro stenosis but is approached conservatively because of the risk of deep, esophageal mural laceration or perforation in the stiff-walled esophagus.

The below image shows the feline esophagus seen on esophageal endoscopy.

Other options:

Options B - Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles and barium swallow study shows corkscrew appearance.

Option C - Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing. It presents with the characteristic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. On barium swallow, bird-beak appearance of the esophagus is seen in achalasia. Esophageal manometry is the "gold standard" investigation for achalasia.

Option D - Zenker's diverticulum is a pseudodiverticulum resulting from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus. Barium swallow study is used for the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines is not included in the scheme?
questions.solution:
The typhoid vaccine is not included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month. The diseases are:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Polio
  • Hepatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles 

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

 

 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It has been launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

In february 2020, the government launched Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI). The aim is to reach out to partially vaccinated and unvaccinated children with all the available vaccines under Universal Immunization Program (UIP) across 381 districts in 29 States/UTs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male smoker presents with intermittent claudication in his left foot. Physical examination shows normal popliteal pulse and tibial pulses with no associated skin changes.  A doppler ultrasound showed reduced vascularity and CT angiography shows skip lesions in the left foot . What will be the additional management helpful in this patient apart from the cessation of smoking?
questions.solution:
A 35-year-old male smoker presenting with a history of intermittent claudication in the left foot and skip lesions on angiography suggests Thromboangiitis obliterans. The additional management helpful in this patient apart from cessation of smoking will be  Cilostazol therapy.

Cilostazol is a PDE inhibitor used in early cases to improve blood flow in the affected area. This will be beneficial in this patient since his doppler shows reduced vascularity and this drug can improve the circulation

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease affecting small and medium-sized vessels. It affects arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities. 

 The disease is common in young smoker males less than 40 years old. This includes a triad of: 

  • Intermittent claudication of the affected limb
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Migratory superficial vein thrombophlebitis 

Doppler ultrasound and CT angiography help in making the diagnosis.

A vessel biopsy shows segmental inflammation with luminal thrombosis. The thrombus contains tiny microabscesses composed of neutrophils surrounded by granulomatous inflammation.

Characteristic angiographic findings show disease confined to the distal extremities, usually distal tibial and radial artery. The occlusions are segmental and show “skip” lesions with extensive collateralizations, called corkscrew collaterals.

The only specific treatment to arrest the progression of thromboangiitis obliterans is complete abstinence from tobacco. It does not reverse the disease. Patients with absent pulses with an absent doppler indicate critical limb ischemia, which needs to be amputated because of nonviable tissue (absent doppler).

Other options:

Option A:  Revascularization with Arterial bypass surgery has a very limited role in managing Buerger's disease, primarily because suitable target vessels for bypass grafting are absent. Additionally, the use of autologous vein conduits is restricted because of the concurrent presence of migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option C:  Lumbar sympathectomy was previously used to treat lower limb ischaemia, but it has since become obsolete.Also, it is contraindicated if patient haves symptoms of intermittent claudication as it causes cutaneous vasodilation and precipitates rest pain. 

Option D: Conservative amputations are done when there are signs of advanced disease/ critical limb ischemia like rest pain, ulceration, gangrene formation with absent vascularity. 

Note:

1. Anticoagulation does not address the underlying inflammatory nature of the disease and has not been shown to be effective in treating Buerger’s disease.

2. Berger disease, also known as IgA nephropathy, is a type of acute glomerulonephritic syndrome characterized by the deposition of IgA in the mesangium.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is a known case of cirrhosis presents with fever, ascites, abdominal pain, and confusion. Diagnostic paracentesis reveals an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of 350 cells/µL. He is diagnosed with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), and treatment is initiated. Which of the following drug increases the risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP)?
questions.solution:
Proton pump inhibitors are associated with an increased risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) as they can alter the gut microbiota by increasing gastric pH, allowing bacterial overgrowth and translocation, which predisposes patients to infections like SBP.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. Diagnosis is by paracentesis, and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 suggests spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal the pathogenic organisms.

Treatment of SBP is commonly with intravenous third-generation cephalosporin for 5 days. In addition, intravenous albumin has been shown to reduce the risk of renal failure and improve survival. Ciprofloxacin can be given in patients not tolerating cephalosporins. Prophylaxis in the form of oral norfloxacin and oral ciprofloxacin can be given in patients with variceal bleeding and prior episodes of SBP.

questions.text: A newborn presents with vomiting, lethargy, seizures, refusal to feed, and failure to thrive. Blood tests reveal significantly elevated ammonia levels, accompanied by low citrulline and low orotic acid levels. What type of hyperammonemia does this indicate, and which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a newborn with symptoms of hyperammonemia with high ammonia levels, low citrulline levels, and low orotic acid levels in the blood, suggesting Type 1 Hyperammonemia due to Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I deficiency.

In Type 1 Hyperammonemia (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I  deficiency), the symptoms appear during the first few days or even hours of life, and the baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsion, and coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. The child will show low levels of citrulline and low levels of orotic acid in the blood.

In Type 2 Hyperammonemia (Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency), carbamoyl phosphate accumulates, which gets shunted to pyrimidine biosynthesis, resulting in high orotic acid levels in the blood. However, the levels of citrulline in the blood are low. Type 2 hyperammonemia (OTC deficiency) presents with vomiting, lethargy, seizures, respiratory alkalosis, and encephalopathy in neonates. Later onset includes episodic vomiting, protein aversion, behavioral changes, and encephalopathy triggered by metabolic stress.

Feature Type 1 Hyperammonemia Type 2 Hyperammonemia
Defect Deficiency of Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I enzyme Deficiency of Ornithine Transcarbamylase enzyme 
Inheritance  Autosomal recessive X linked recessive
Onset Neonatal  Neonatal or late onset
Plasma Citrulline Very low Low to normal
Plasma Orotic Acid Low Elevated

The 60-year postmenopausal woman diagnosed with osteoporosis five months back and was started on parathyroid hormone analog (eg: Teriperatide), which promotes bone formation by stimulating the maturation of pre-osteoblasts into the osteoblast resulting in an increased osteoblastic activity. questions.text: A college student has repeated episodes of intense fear and a sense of impending doom every semester before his exams. He suffers from palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating during these episodes. Which of these is the drug of choice for the long-term management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient suffering from repeated episodes of intense fear, and sense of impending doom accompanied by palpitations, sweating, and dyspnea is suggestive of panic disorder. The drug of choice for long-term management of panic disorder is paroxetine, which is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort lasting from minutes to hours. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks, at least one of which is associated with 1 month of either persistent concern or worry about additional attacks, or a change in behavior related to the attacks.

An attack often begins with 10 minutes of rapid worsening of symptoms. This includes an extreme fear and a sense of impending doom and death along with tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating. The attack generally lasts for up to half an hour but in some cases may last for more than an hour. Between attacks, the patient may suffer from anticipatory anxiety about the next attack. 

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

A. Recurrent unexpected panic attacks which include ≥4 of the following 

  • Palpitations
  • Trembling
  • Sweating
  • Dyspnea
  • Choking
  • Chest pain
  • Nausea, abdominal distress
  • Chills, heat sensation
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization or depersonalization
  • Fear of losing control
  • Fear of death

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following for >1 month:

  • Anticipatory anxiety - Continuous concern about additional panic attacks
  • Changes in behavior related to attacks (e.g. avoidance of unfamiliar situations)

3. The attack is not attributable to substance abuse or any other medical condition.

4. The attack cannot be explained by any other mental disorder. 

Treatment

Presently, SSRIs are considered the first-line drugs for the treatment of panic disorder. Paroxetine is preferred due to its sedative effects which calm down patients immediately leading to better compliance. Citalopram or sertraline are viable alternatives as well. However, for an acute episode with severe symptoms, benzodiazepines like alprazolam should be started concurrently with SSRIs and slowly tapered off. This is because benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action. Pharmacotherapy should generally continue for 8-12 months when it is found to be effective.

Other than pharmacotherapy, cognitive and behavior therapies are also very effective treatments for panic disorder. These work especially well when used in combination with pharmacotherapy. These help in producing long-lasting remissions of symptoms.

Option B - Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine with a high risk of psychological and physical dependence if used in the long term. Therefore it is used as an adjunct to SSRIs or psychotherapy and not used as a primary treatment.

Option C - Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. MAOIs may require certain dietary restrictions and hence are used less often.

Option D - Imipramine is a tricyclic anti-depressant that can be used for panic disorder as a second-line drug. TCAs are used less often than SSRIs because they are associated with more adverse effects at the dosages required for the treatment of panic disorder.

questions.text: A heart failure patient on a cardiac glycoside was started on azoles for a fungal infection of the lung. Following this, he developed nausea, vomiting, and the following ECG abnormality. The patient is hemodynamically unstable. Which of the following drugs will be used for definitive management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The heart failure patient on cardiac glycoside, digoxin with clinical features and ECG findings of ventricular bigeminy has developed digoxin toxicity following azole administration. Digibind will be used for the definitive management of this patient.

Digoxin is a substrate for p-glycoprotein. Azoles like itraconazole are inhibitors of p-glycoprotein. So, The use of azoles thus leads to increased levels of digoxin and eventually, its toxicity as the therapeutic window of digoxin is very narrow.

Symptoms of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Non-cardiac manifestations: delirium, nausea, vomiting, yellowing of vision.
  • Cardiac manifestations: atrial or ventricular tachyarrythmias, bradyarrhythmias with or without atrioventricular block, hyperkalemia.
  • Ventricular bigeminy (single ectopic or irregular beat, following each regular heartbeat) is common but atrial tachycardia with atrioventricular block is a very specific finding.

Treatment of digoxin toxicity involves: 

  • Administering digoxin-specific antibodies (digibind).
  • Atropine, dopamine, epinephrine, and external cardiac pacing for bradyarrhythmias
  • Magnesium, lidocaine, and phenytoin for ventricular tachyarrythmias. 

Note - Although atropine, lidocaine and dopamine can be used as temporising measures, digibind is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease, acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Betahistine (vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit the vestibular nuclei activity.

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presented to the OPD with fever, cough, anorexia, and lymphadenopathy. He gave a history of trips to Ohio state in the USA. On examination chest X-ray showed focal infiltrates and patchy opacities. A systemic mycoses was suspected and aspiration from lymph nodes showed the presence of intracellular yeast within the macrophages. What will be the appearance of the fungus when seen after culture in BHI agar at 25 ℃?

[BHI agar : Brain Heart Infusion agar]
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of fever, cough, anorexia, lymphadenopathy after trip to Ohio in USA and presence of intracellular yeast within the macrophages on lymph node aspiration points towards Histoplasmosis caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, which on culture at 25℃ shows Tuberculate macroconidia.

Histoplasmosis (Darling’s disease) is a granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic in the USA, in the states bordering the Ohio river valley and the lower Mississippi river.  H. capsulatum is transmitted by inhalation of spores (i.e. microconidia) which usually circulate in the air after the contaminated soil is disturbed. After the spores enter the lungs, they are engulfed by alveolar macrophages and then transform into intracellular yeast within the macrophages.

At 25°C the fungi embark on a mycelial phase that consists of two types of conidia - tuberculate macroconidia (with typical thick walls and finger-like projections which is a characteristic feature) and microconidia( smaller, thin, and smooth-walled). At 37°C it transforms into an intracellular yeast form (creamy white colonies), which is best developed in special media like Kelley’s media.

Other options:

Option A: Barrel-shaped arthrospores are seen in Coccidioidomycosis at 25°C. At 37°C, spherules with endospores are seen in Coccidioidomycosis. Coccidioidomycosis is also called as  "dessert rheumatism" or "California / Valley fever " and presents with erythema nodosum (desert bumps) or erythema multiforme, arthralgias (desert rheumatism).

Option C: Pilot wheel appearance (also called Mickey Mouse appearance) is seen in Paracoccidioidomycosis at  37°C. At 25°C it shows septate hyphae with chlamydospores.  Paracoccidioidomycosis is also called as "South American Blastomycosis".

Option D: Thick-walled yeast with a figure of 8 appearance (broad-based budding ) is seen in Blastomycosis at 37°C. At 25 °C it shows hyphae with small pear-shaped conidia. Blastomycosis is also called as "Chicago/North American/Gilchrist disease" and may present with a verrucous skin lesion (may disseminate to bone).

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a combined immunodeficiency disorder associated with both B-cell and T-cell defects?
questions.solution:
Ataxia telangiectasia is a combined immunodeficiency disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

The disorder is characterised by cerebral ataxia, telangiectasia, ovarian dysgenesis, and chromosomal abnormalities. Telangiectasia usually appears at five or six years of age and involves the face, conjunctiva and other body parts. Death occurs due to sinopulmonary infection in early life or due to malignancy in the second or third decade.

Other options:

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder associated with T-cell deficiency.

Option C: Chediak Higashi syndrome and Tuftsin deficiency are disorders of phagocytosis.

questions.text:
An elderly woman is rushed to the emergency room following an episode of syncope. Her caretaker reports that the patient had multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood investigations and ECG are given below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Serum sodium: 140 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 7.1 mEq/L
Serum chloride: 100 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen creatinine ratio: 26.9
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the ECG showing tall T waves in all the leads and the laboratory investigations showing serum potassium of 7.1 mEq/L are suggestive of hyperkalemia. The next best step in the management is intravenous calcium gluconate.

This patient has acute kidney injury resulting from dehydration. Her BUN: Creatinine ratio is 26.9 which is >20:1 which suggests prerenal azotemia. Acute kidney injury results in impaired excretion of potassium resulting in hyperkalemia.

Although ECG changes are not specific and hyperkalemia may occur without significant ECG changes, the typical changes seen in ECG due to hyperkalemia are sequential and include:

  • Peaking of the T waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Widening of the PR and QRS intervals
  • Sine waves
  • Ventricular fibrillation and asystole

The presence of cardiac toxicity is a serious manifestation of hyperkalemia and requires immediate cardiac stabilization with intravenous calcium gluconate. Calcium gluconate should also be initiated in all patients with serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and patients with muscular weakness.

The recommended dose is 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate infused intravenously over 2–3 min with cardiac monitoring. The dose should be repeated if there is no change in ECG findings or if findings recur after stabilization.

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

Other options:

Option A: Patiromer is a potassium-binding drug that can be used in chronic hyperkalemia. It doesn't play a role in acute hyperkalemia due to acute kidney injury like in this patient. Sodium zirconium cyclosili­cate and sodium polystyrene are other potassium-binding agents.

Option C: Hemodialysis may be needed in patients with acute or chronic renal failure to remove excess potassium, especially in patients who are oliguric. However, it should be undertaken after cardiac stabilization.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a metastasized neuroendocrine tumor and was started on palliative therapy with DOTATOC-labeled lutetium. Which is the receptor that is commonly targeted in this therapy?
questions.solution:
The somatostatin receptor is commonly targeted in the DOTATOC-labeled lutetium therapy which is used for the treatment of inoperable or metastasized neuroendocrine tumors.

DOTATOC is labeled with yttrium-90 or lutetium-177 for palliative outcomes. DOTATOC-labeled lutetium is only FDA-approved for treating Somatostatin receptor-positive Gastropancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (NET). It's use in therapy for malignant pheochromocytomas is still in trials.

Modified somatostatin analog [Tyr3]octreotide is labeled with radioisotopes such as 177lutetium and 90yttrium. These are coupled using a chelator DOTA, thus forming  [DOTA0, Tyr3]octreotate (DOTATATE). This has a higher affinity towards somatostatin receptor subtype 2.

questions.text: You are a medical officer posted in a primary health center (PHC).  During your practice, you examine a child for malnutrition using the following instrument. Which principle of PHC functioning does this action demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Shakir tape, an instrument used to measure mid-arm circumference. The use of a Shakir tape in assessing malnutrition aligns with the PHC principle of appropriate technology which emphasizes the use of simple, effective, and affordable tools that are both, locally adaptable and accepted by local people.

Principles of primary health care (PHC) include: 

  • Equitable distribution: This means health for all people i.e. health services must be shared equally by all people irrespective of their ability to pay, and all (rich or poor, urban or rural) must have access to health services.
  • Community participation:  This includes involvement of the community in the planning and maintenance of health services, and maximum reliance on local resources such as manpower, money, and materials. ASHA workers and trained dais are examples of community participation.
  • Intersectoral coordination: It involves the addition of other sectors like agriculture, animal husbandry, food, industry, education, housing, public works, and communication to provide appropriate primary health care.
  • Appropriate technology: This involves the use of simple, effective, and affordable tools locally adaptable and accepted by local people and can be maintained by the resources within the community viz ORS, VVM, Shakir tape.

Elements of primary health care include:

  • Education concerning prevailing health problems and methods of preventing and controlling them.
  • Promotion of food supply and proper nutrition.
  • An adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation.
  • Maternal and child health care, including family planning.
  • Immunization against major infectious diseases.
  • Prevention and control of locally endemic diseases.
  • Appropriate treatment of common diseases and injuries.
  • Provision of essential drugs.

Note: Comprehensive health care is a term first used by Bhore committee meaning integration of preventive, curative, and promotive health of an individual in a defined geographical area.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the reflex shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows an inverse stretch reflex and it is a disynaptic reflex.

When the tension in the muscle increases and beyond a physiological limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex. The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex.

The inverse stretch reflex is described as:
Excessive Muscle contraction →Golgi tendon organ activation--> Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that releases inhibitory mediator glycine → hyperpolarization (inhibition) of α motor neurons → muscle relaxation.

questions.text: A patient presents with joint pains which are severe when he wakes up in the morning and decreases with activity. His hands are shown in the image given below. He has papulosquamous lesions on his skin which have a silvery scale. What is the most efficacious treatment for his joint pains?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the above picture is psoriatic arthritis. Nail changes are obvious and inflammation of the DIP joints can be observed. The most efficacious treatment for his joint pains is methotrexate.

Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disease with joint and nail manifestations apart from the skin. It has silvery scales. The joint manifestations in psoriasis are referred to as psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and hence it is associated with HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement. The x-ray shows a 'pencil in cup' deformity due to tapering of phalanges with cupping of proximal parts. All the bones of a single digit may be involved, referred to as ray deformity.

CASPAR Criteria is used to diagnose Psoriatic Arthritis. The patient must have the inflammatory articular disease (joint, spine, or entheseal involvement) with ≥3 points from any of the following five categories: 

  • Evidence of current psoriasis, a personal history of psoriasis, or a family history of psoriasis
  • Typical psoriatic nail dystrophy observed on current physical examination
  • A negative test result for rheumatoid factor
  • Either current dactylitis or a history of dactylitis recorded by a rheumatologist 
  • Radiographic evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation in the hand or foot

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A paramedic in the ambulance examines a G2P1 lady, who is in labor. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. The cord is prolapsed outside the vulva. The paramedic places a Foley catheter to fill up the bladder with 500 mL of saline and then clamps it. This method of relief of pressure on the cord is known as ________.
questions.solution:
Vago's method is used in cord prolapse to alleviate pressure on the cord. Vagos method is also known as the bladder-filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

  • If the baby is dead - 
    • Reconfirmation with ultrasound
    • Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed
    • Destructive operations are rarely needed
  • If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 
    • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
    • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
    • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

  • When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible:

    • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
    • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
    • Relieve pressure on the cord by:
      • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.
      • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.
      • Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord.
    • Funic reduction(option B): Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
    • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below: 

Option C: Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with the other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus.

Option D: Burns Marshall method: It is used in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon since the last year. Recently she has started developing skin induration in her fingers. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon preceding the skin fibrosis, and the limitation of skin fibrosis to the distal extremities suggest a diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The antibody seen in this condition is anti-centromere.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is broadly divided into two subsets depending on the pattern of the skin involvement and other associated features:

  • Limited cutaneous (also known as CREST syndrome)
  • Diffuse cutaneous

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, Raynaud's phenomenon is seen earlier and is usually more severe and can lead to critical digital ischemia. The skin lesions develop much later, sometimes years after the development of Raynaud's phenomenon. The visceral organ involvement is slowly progressive and often benign. The prominent complications include pulmonary arterial hypertension, Sjogren syndrome, and primary biliary cirrhosis. Some patients with limited cutaneous SSc develop the all characteristic set of features, known as CREST syndrome:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with HLA B27?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with HLA DR4.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLA):

  • HLA is the name given to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) of the humans
  • The HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6
  • It consists of three clusters of genes:
    • Class I comprises of A, B and C loci. Class I antigens are found on the surface of all nucleated cells
    • Class II or the D region consisting of the DR, DQ and DP loci. Class II antigens are found only on cells of the immune system/antigen-presenting cells
    • Class III or the complement region containing genes. Class III antigens include complement components, heat shock proteins and tumor necrosis factors
  • HLA loci are multiallelic - e.g. 24 alleles have been identified at HLA locus A and 50 at locus B. As each allele determines a distinct product (antigen), the HLA system is very pleomorphic. Hence, HLA compatibility plays an important role in organ transplantation
  • HLA genes are very strongly associated with various autoimmune diseases

questions.text: A 10-year-old child comes to the emergency ward after a fall on an outstretched hand. The x-ray of the left arm is shown below. Which of the following nerves would be commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows a posterior displaced (extension-type) supracondylar fracture of the humerus that commonly affects the anterior interosseous nerve. Supracondylar fracture of the humerus may injure either the median nerve or radial nerves. But, on meta-analysis, it was found that the frequency of nerve injury is as follows: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve

The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) of the median nerve is the commonly injured nerve in supracondylar fractures in children. It presents with the same symptoms as high median nerve injury but without any sensory loss. Patients with anterior interosseous nerve injury have a characteristic pinch defect and are unable to make the OK gesture due to weakness of the flexors of the thumb and the index finger.  

There is loss of abduction of the thumb and paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. So, when asked to make a fist, the patient flexes the ulnar fingers and extends the index finger resulting in the pointing index sign. In an isolated anterior interosseous nerve injury, there is no sensory loss.

questions.text: A forester presents with complaints of fever, lymphadenopathy, and black eschar on the site of the insect bite. The Weil-Felix test was positive and reactive to the OXK antigen. Identify the vector that transmits this disease.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus, and the vector for the disease is the trombiculid mite (image 4).

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. Meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia can be seen in severe cases.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK is agglutinated only in scrub typhus. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for both adults and children.

Option A: Hard tick (image 1) transmits diseases such as Ehrlichia, babesiosis, viral hemorrhagic fevers like Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) and Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), tularemia, and tick paralysis.

Option B: Soft tick (image 2) transmits Q fever, relapsing fever, and Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be caused by a hard tick as well).

Option C: Lice (image 3) are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a recent middle ear infection presents with fever, severe pain behind the ear, and swelling over the mastoid region. The patient is scheduled for a mastoidectomy. Which anatomical structure forms the superior boundary to the area used as a landmark to locate the mastoid antrum during this procedure?

choices.text: Inferior border of the zygomatic arch

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests acute mastoiditis and the patient was scheduled for mastoidectomy. This procedure is accessed through the mastoid antrum. The superior boundary of this area is formed by the supra mastoid crest/ temporal line which is used as a landmark to locate the mastoid antrum.

Cortical mastoidectomy, known as simple or complete mastoidectomy or Schwartz operation. MacEwen’s triangle (supramental triangle) is also an important landmark because it is the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis. In mastoidectomy procedures, it is used only to enter the mastoid antrum. 

Boundaries of MacEwen’s triangle are:

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl with recurrent seizures and hypoglycemia is found to have low plasma and urinary ketones, increased dicarboxylic acid levels, and a family history of sudden infant death. What explains the elevated dicarboxylic acids?

choices.text: Decreased peroxisomal alpha-oxidation of the branched-chain fatty acids
Decreased microsomal alpha-oxidation of the branched-chain fatty acids
Increased mitochondrial omega oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids
Increased microsomal omega oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of a 3 years old child with non-ketotic hypoglycaemia and a history of sibling death suggesting medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD) in which, there is impaired beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids (in the mitochondria), which leads to the accumulation of dicarboxylic acids due to increased microsomal omega oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids.

In MCAD deficiency, there is impaired mitochondrial beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids. This results in decreased ATP and acetyl CoA levels. The low acetyl CoA levels reduce pyruvate carboxylase activity (as acetyl CoA is its allosteric activator), causing decreased gluconeogenesis and fasting hypoglycemia. Additionally, low acetyl CoA levels impair ketone body synthesis, leading to non-ketotic hypoglycemia.
Due to the impaired beta-oxidation, medium-chain fatty acids undergo increased omega-oxidation in the microsomes, leading to the accumulation and subsequent urinary excretion of medium-chain C6-C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids.

Clinical Features:

  • Non-ketotic hypoglycemia, particularly during fasting or metabolic stress.
  • Potential for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) due to severe metabolic derangements.
  • Symptoms of lethargy, vomiting, and seizures during periods of fasting or illness.

Laboratory Findings:

  • Hypoglycemia with low or absent ketone bodies.
  • Elevated levels of dicarboxylic acids (C6-C10) in urine due to omega oxidation.
  • Abnormal acylcarnitine profile { Due to defective Medium-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase, medium-chain fatty acids (C6-C12) cannot undergo beta-oxidation. These fatty acids accumulate and are converted to acylcarnitines, leading to an abnormal acylcarnitine profile characterized by elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines (e.g., C6, C8, C10).}

Management:

  • Prevent fasting: Ensure frequent carbohydrate-rich meals to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • Emergency glucose supplementation: During illness or fasting to prevent metabolic crises.
  • Dietary modification: Avoid medium-chain triglycerides and focus on long-chain fatty acids.

questions.text:
A higher insulin: glucagon ratio will lead to the activation of which of the following?
  1. HSL in the adipose tissues
  2. Glycogen phosphorylase
  3. LPL in the endothelium
  4. HMG CoA reductase
  5. Mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase                                                                               

(HSL: Hormone Sensitive Lipase     
 LPL: Lipoprotein Lipase)
questions.solution:
A higher insulin:glucagon ratio results in the activation of the enzymes lipoprotein lipase (LPL) and HMG CoA reductase. (3,4)

A higher insulin:glucagon ratio leads to:

  • Inhibition of hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) leading to inhibition of lipolysis of the stored triglyceride in adipose tissue. Thus, it inhibits gluconeogenesis.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase is a key enzyme in glycogenolysis. A high ratio inhibits glycogen phosphorylase and activates glycogen synthase → promotes glycogenesis.  (Statement 2)
  • Activate LPL in the endothelium, causing the breakdown of triglycerides present in chylomicrons and VLDL into Free Fatty Acids (FFAs). These FFAs are taken up by adipocytes → Lipogenesis  (Statement 3)
  • Activate HMG CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis, thereby increasing cholesterol synthesis. (Statement 4)
  • Inhibit Mitochondrial HMG CoA Synthase, which is the rate-limiting step for ketone body synthesis, thereby decreasing ketone body production. (Statement 5)

A lower insulin: glucagon ratio will: Activate the HSL present in the adipose tissues. (Statement 1).

Most of the metabolic action of insulin is in anabolic favoring, inhibiting lipolysis and stimulating cholesterol synthesis and glycogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used to identify the contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil?
questions.solution:
Detection of contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil can be done by Nitric acid test.

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil. Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure. Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography (most sensitive test)
  • Nitric acid test 

Phosphatase test (Option A), standard plate count (Option B), and coliform count are used to check whether milk has been pasteurized. A positive test after pasteurization of milk shows contamination after pasteurization.

Methylene blue reduction test (Option D) is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk. The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization to check for gross contamination. It is used for grading raw milk quality prior to pasteurization.

questions.text: Congestive splenomegaly can be caused by all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis does not cause congestive splenomegaly.

Infective endocarditis (IE) leads to the formation of splenic infarcts due to the embolus dislodging and migrating to the splenic vessels which obstruct blood flow to the spleen. The splenic infarction in IE causes septic infarcts, which appear as pale, wedge-shaped infarcts, and suppurative necrosis.

Congestive splenomegaly occurs due to chronic venous obstruction and splenic enlargement. This venous obstruction and blood stasis could be secondary to an intrahepatic cause affecting portal flow or an extrahepatic cause directly obstructing the splenic vein leading to portal or splenic venous hypertension.

Common causes include-

  • Alcoholic cirrhosis
  • Vascular Obstruction (eg Portal Vein Thrombosis, Budd-Chiari Syndrome)
  • Schistosomiasis (Option B)
  • Infiltrating tumors around splenic vein- pancreatic (Option D) and gastric cancers
  • Central venous congestion involving right heart- tricuspid or pulmonary valve disease, chronic cor pulmonale (Option C), left heart failure.

The histopathological examination will show congestion of the red pulp and fibrosis along with Gamna Gandy bodies - hemosiderin and fibroid tissue (shown in the image below with black arrows) and diffusely scattered, brown, granular hemosiderin pigment (yellow arrowheads).

questions.text: A female child is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea and short stature. An ultrasound was done, and it showed a small uterus and streak ovaries. Which of the following cardiac anomaly is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of primary amenorrhea and short stature along with streak ovaries in the ultrasound is suggestive of Turner syndrome. It is frequently associated with left-sided cardiovascular anomalies like bicuspid aortic valves.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

Clinical findings include webbing of the neck, protruding ears, and lymphedema of the hands and feet, short stature. The gonads are streaks of fibrous tissue, known as gonadal dysgenesis. There is primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. Congenital heart anomalies and structural renal anomalies are common.

Cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome: Common defects are bicuspid aortic valves, coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, and mitral valve prolapse. Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most important cause of mortality.

questions.text:
A young married couple is unable to conceive despite 2 years of unprotected sex. The gynaecologist suggested ART to them using the below-depicted method as it was found to be a male factor infertility issue. What is the sperm concentration at which this method of ART is indicated?

[ART: Assisted Reproductive Technology]
questions.solution:
The image depicts the Intra-Cytoplasmic-Sperm-Injection (ICSI) method of ART that is done when the sperm concentration falls below 5 million /mL. 

In the given scenario, a young married couple is unable to conceive despite 2 years of unprotected sex, indicating it is a case of infertility.

Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months (1 year) of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse.

For women 35 years and older:

Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive after 6 months of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse.

The gynecologist asked them to opt for ART using ICSI as it was found to be a male-factor infertility issue. ICSI is a method of ART where a single sperm is injected into the cytoplasm of an oocyte (under a microscope), which is then incubated overnight.

Indications for ICSI are as follows:

  • Sperm count less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous IVF has failed
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona pellucida by sperm as seen in IVF.

Other Options:

Option B: At 5-10 million/mL sperm concentration , IVF (In-Vitro fertilisation) is done. 

Option C: At 10-15 million/mL sperm concentration, IUI (Intra-Uterine Insemination) is done.

Option D: A sperm concentration of 15-20 million/mL means that the sperm concentration in the semen is adequate (>16 million/mL sperm concentration rules out oligospermia). Other causes of infertility, such as obstructive or non-obstructive azoospermia, erectile dysfunction, etc., need to be evaluated.

Related Pearl: Indications for various procedures in Infertility treatment

Indications of artificial insemination with husband's semen:

  • Chronic medical disorder
  • Oligospermia after sperm washout
  • Impotency or ejaculatory failure
  • Premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation
  • Hypospadias
  • Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Frozen sperm: If the husband needs to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy or is not available at the time of ovulation
  • X–Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection, in a genetic and chromosomal abnormality
  • HIV positive male or female

Indications for Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT):

  • Sperm count of less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous failed IVF
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona by sperm as seen in IVF

questions.text: The markers of the tumors with the given histopathological sections are, respectively:
questions.solution:
Image A: Schiller-Duval body characteristic of endodermal sinus tumor. AFP is the tumor marker of these tumors.

Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is the second most common malignant ovarian tumor.

Schiller -Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

The below image shows Schiller- Duval bodies.


Image B: Tumor cells are arranged in sheets punctuated by small follicle-like structures(Call-Exner bodies) characteristic of Granulosa cell tumor. Inhibin is a marker for these tumors.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women.

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call-exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that recall immature follicles. 

The image below shows Call-exner bodies.


Image C: Epithelial ovarian tumors arise from the mesoepithelial cells present on the ovarian and fallopian tubal surfaces. CA-125 is a marker for these tumors.

80% of all ovarian cancers are epithelial cancers. Malignant epithelial cell tumors of the ovary secrete CA-125. It is a glycoprotein and surface cell antigen which is secreted by malignant epithelial tumors of the ovary. A level of more than 35 U/mL suggests a malignant and residual tumor and indicates the need for chemotherapy.

CA-125 is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis and endometriosis. It may not be helpful in the initial diagnosis, once the diagnosis is established, a raised level of CA-125 indicates either persistence or recurrence of the disease in the follow-up.

questions.text: Calculate the expected number of antenatal care registrations of pregnant females by a village health nurse if the crude birth rate in a sub-centre area is 12.
questions.solution:
If the crude birth rate in a sub-centre area is 12, a village health nurse is expected to register 33 pregnant females for antenatal care.

The expected number of live births may be calculated as :

Expected number of live births (Y): Birth rate (per 1000 population) * population of the area/1000

As some pregnancies may not result in a live birth (i.e. abortions and stillbirths), the expected number of live births would be an underestimation of the total number of pregnancies. Hence, a correction factor of 10% is required, i.e. add 10% to the expected number of pregnancies. So, the total number of expected pregnancies:

(Z) = Y + 10% of Y

So, here in this question,

Birth rate = 12/1000 population

Population under the sub-center according to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) = 5000

Therefore, expected number of live births = (12×5000)/1000 = 60 births

The number of live births is equal to the number of probable pregnancies. 

Correction factor (pregnancy wastage) = 10% of 60 births = 6

Thus the total number of expected pregnancies: 60+ 6 = 66

As a thumb rule, At any given time, ANM should register at least half the expected number of pregnancies(50% of the expected pregnancies) 

So, ANC registrations= total number of expected pregnancies/2 

I.e. 66/2 =33

Therefore, the ANM is expected to have 33 pregnancies registered.

He accidentally didn't write the notes for post operative analgesic medication due to which patient suffered from a lot of pain on post operative day 1. Under the “borrowed servant doctrine” who will be typically held liable for the actions of this junior resident?

[H.O.D : Head Of the Department]

choices.text: H.O.D of Neurosurgery as well as H.O.D of General Surgery

questions.solution:
Under the “Borrowed servant doctrine” the borrowing employer i.e. the H.O.D of Neurosurgery is held responsible for the actions of the junior resident.

Here the junior resident is the “borrowed servant” working under the supervision of the H.O.D of Neurosurgery (borrowing employer), and the H.O.D of General Surgery (lending employer) is not liable.

Under the “ borrowed servant doctrine”, liability typically falls on the borrowing employer — the party who has control over the borrowed employee's work at the time of the incident or negligence. Even though the employee is technically employed by the original employer, the borrowed servant doctrine applies when the borrowing employer is directing and controlling the employee's actions.

The lending employer (H.O.D. of General Surgery) temporarily surrenders control over his worker (Junior resident of the Department of General Surgery), and the borrowing employer (H.O.D. of Neurosurgery) takes over control and thereby becomes responsible for all the acts committed under his or her direct supervision and control.

[Note: Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).]

questions.text: Which of the following is the new FDA-approved potassium-competitive acid blocker used to manage erosive esophagitis?
questions.solution:
Vonoprazan is the new FDA-approved potassium-competitive acid blocker used for the management of erosive esophagitis.

Potassium-competitive acid blockers (revaprazan, tegoprazan, and vonoprazan) represent a new class of medication that competitively and reversibly bind to the potassium binding site of H+/K+-ATPase. Due to their large size, these drugs prevent the binding of potassium, effectively blocking the final step in gastric acid secretion. 

They are basic, acid-resistant, and do not require acid activation, allowing them to accumulate to higher concentrations in the canaliculi of parietal cells. The high concentration thus prolongs the acid suppression effect for more than 24 hours after drug administration.

Their faster and longer duration (longer t 1/2) of action, full effect from 1st dose, effective nocturnal acid suppression and ability to bind to both active and inactive forms of H+/K+-ATPase gives them an advantage over conventional PPIs.

These are used for the management of acid peptic diseases, GERD, non-erosive reflux disease, erosive esophagitis, and H. pylori eradication.

Other options:

Option A- Dexlansoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor.

Option B- Dalfampridine is a broad-spectrum potassium channel blocker used in multiple sclerosis.

Option D- Amifampridine is a voltage-gated potassium channel blocker used to treat Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: INTERPOL reports an increase in organized crime groups behind organ trafficking and transplant tourism in past few years.  Which of the following declaration aims to combat these crimes?
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Istanbul combats organ trafficking, transplant tourism, and transplant commercialism. They aim to encourage the adoption of effective and ethical transplantation practices around the world.

Other options:

Option A- The declaration of Geneva also known as the modern Hippocratic oath. It is a declaration of a physician's dedication to the service of humanity.

Option B- The declaration of Sydney describes the determination of death and recovery of organs. Death determination can be made on the basis of the irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, or the irreversible cessation of circulatory and respiratory functions. This determination will be made by a physician based on clinical judgment according to accepted criteria, supplemented, and by standard diagnostic procedures.

Option C- The declaration of Helsinki gives a set of ethical principles directed to the medical community in research involving human subjects. 

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk with respect to a 'Conley's pointer'. What is this pointer related to?
questions.solution:
'Conley's pointer' is related to the tragus of external acoustic canal. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include the following:

  • Conley's pointer/tragal pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow):

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant presents with the following rash with sparing of palms and soles. Wright's stain of the intralesional fluid shows eosinophils. Which of the following will be seen on the culture of the specimen?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the clinical image showing papules on the erythematous base point to a diagnosis of erythema toxicum, where the culture will be sterile and there will be no growth.

Erythema toxicum is a self-limiting lesion that commonly occurs around day two of life and is a normal newborn phenomenon. It appears as firm, yellow-white, 1-2mm papules or pustules with surrounding erythema as shown in the image below. They can be clustered or sparse and usually spare the palms and soles.

The Wright stained smear of the intralesional content shows eosinophils and cultures are sterile. The closest differentials for erythema toxicum can be: 

  • Pyoderma- where the culture may show golden yellow colonies of Staphylococcus (Option C) or mucoid, pinhead colonies of S. pyogens (Option D)
  • Candidiasis- off-white smooth yeast (option A)
  • Herpes simplex - Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis - pustules filled with polymorphonuclear lymphocytes

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)
