DCIS- Ductal carcinoma in-situ
questions.solution:
Linear microcalcifications on mammography and histopathology showing nuclear polymorphism and extensive necrosis are suggestive of the comedo subtype of DCIS.

DCIS is divided into various subtypes based on nuclear grade and the presence of extensive necrosis. It is broadly classified as comedo and non-comedo (solid, cribriform, papillary) DCIS. In the comedo subtype, the continuously growing cells from the ductal lumen obliterate the duct, outgrow their blood supply and become necrotic. Calcium deposition occurs in these necrotic areas, which are seen as areas of calcification in mammography.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1: Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3: Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of the tumor specimen is shown in the below image. This finding indicates which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The given image shows signet ring cells which are seen in Kruckenberg tumors.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma, characterized by the arrangement of large tumor cells in bunches. Lymphocytes and giant cells are seen in between the tumor cells. Infiltration of fibrous septa by lymphocytes is an important diagnostic feature.

 


Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor, which is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

 

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by single columnar epithelium. They are usually unilateral and are found along with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumour ruptures, it may lead to formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea. On colonoscopy, the large intestine has a cobblestone appearance. While reviewing his biochemistry test results, which parameter would you expect to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, fibrinogen being a positive acute phase reactant will be elevated in a Crohn's disease patient (abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea with cobblestone appearance).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman, status post-cataract surgery, presents for follow-up. On examination, mild iridodonesis is observed with shining reflexes. Purkinje image test of this patient is performed. Which statements among the following are true for this condition?
  1. First and second purkinje images form an erect image
  2. Anterior surface of the lens forms an inverted image
  3. Four purkinje images are observed
  4. Third and fourth purkinje images are absent
  5. Fourth purkinje image forms an inverted image
questions.solution:
In this patient, status post-cataract surgery, mild iridodonesis is observed along with shining reflexes, suggestive of pseudophakia (post-intraocular lens implantation).  The correct statements about this condition, based on the Purkinje image test are 1, 3, and 5 (option B).

The term pseudophakia refers to having an artificial lens implanted after removing the natural eye lens. One of the hallmark signs of pseudophakia is iridodonesis, or the tremulousness of the iris, which is often observed along with a shining reflex when light is directed at the pupil. This is a common finding after the implantation of a posterior chamber IOL. Additionally, the anterior chamber is typically deeper than normal, and a surgical scar is usually visible at the limbus.

In the Purkinje image test, four images are observed in pseudophakia, corresponding to reflections from the different surfaces of the eye. The first and second Purkinje images are formed from the cornea (anterior and posterior), and both are erect. The third image is formed from the anterior surface of the lens and is also erect, while the fourth image, which forms from the posterior surface of the lens, is inverted. 

Aphakic eyes (eyes without a lens) only produce two Purkinje images, as the absence of the lens eliminates the reflections from the anterior and posterior lens surfaces. The test helps differentiate pseudophakia from aphakia and is useful for confirming the presence of an IOL. The presence of the 4  images, along with iridodonesis and shining reflexes, confirms the pseudophakic state after cataract surgery.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female college student has a BMI of 16.5kg/m² and has been following a rigorous diet which involves restricting her food intake  “ to look good”. Despite suffering from severe fatigue, she refuses to eat because of the fear of gaining weight and has a history of self-induced vomiting. Which of the following hormones will remain normal in these patients?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario an 18-year-old female student with a BMI of 16.5 kg/m², has been following a rigorous diet where she is restricting her food intake and refuses to eat because of fear of gaining weight and has a history of self-induced vomiting suggesting the diagnosis of Anorexia nervosa where the levels of TSH are normal.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder in which the patient has an intense fear of gaining weight. This fear leads to restriction of calorie intake resulting in significantly reduced body weight. 

The SCOFF (Sick, Control, One, Fat, Food) questionnaire is a screening tool for eating disorders (anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa).

The hormone levels in Anorexia nervosa are as follows : 

Increased Decreased  Normal
Corticotrophin releasing hormone  Somatomedin -C  Thyrotropin-stimulating hormone (TSH)
Plasma Cortisol Follicle Stimulating Hormone  
Growth Hormone Luteinizing Hormone  
Reverse T3 Tri-iodothyronine (T3)  
  C-peptide   

Diagnosis is based on the presence of 3 essential criteria: Poor eating habits leading to significant weight loss for age, fear of gaining weight, a distorted perception of body weight, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms of starvation. 

Types include:

Restrictive type - patients restrict their intake of food by aggressive dieting as well as relentless overactivity to reduce their weight. Athletic injuries may be seen due to this reason. There are no binge episodes seen in this subtype.

Purge/Binge-eating type - history of binging episodes which are followed by purging behavior (self-induced vomiting).

If a patient's weight is 20% less than the expected weight for their height, they should be considered for hospitalization. Psychotherapy is an effective treatment for anorexia and can include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy. While pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment, medications like cyproheptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorpromazine have shown some improvement in anorexia patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset hematemesis. She has been taking COX inhibitors for the past two years. Endoscopy reveals a bleeding gastric ulcer. Which of the following drugs is least likely to be responsible for this ulcer?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a bleeding gastric ulcer is least likely caused by etoricoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor. All selective COX-2 inhibitors are less likely to cause gastric ulcers than nonselective COX inhibitors.

Selective COX-2 inhibitors include drugs like celecoxib, lumiracoxib, etoricoxib, and parecoxib. They have analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory effects similar to those of non-selective NSAIDs but with better gastrointestinal tolerability as COX-1 is not inhibited. COX-1 is present in GIT and converts Arachidonic acid to prostaglandins in the stomach. Prostaglandins maintain the gastric mucosa and prevent its corrosion.

These drugs inhibit COX-2-mediated prostaglandin synthesis in the vascular endothelium --> decreased PGI2 --> unopposed activity of TXA2  --> increased platelet aggregation --> increased cardiovascular risk. [TXA2 production by platelets is dependent on COX-1, PGI2 production is dependent on COX-2]. Therefore, some selective COX-2 inhibitors are withdrawn or restricted in use because of an increase in the risk of cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction, serious skin reactions (valdecoxib), and fatal hepatic failure (lumiracoxib).

Other options:

Aspirin, fenoprofen, and acetaminophen are non-selective COX inhibitors. They inhibit COX-1 --> decreased production of prostaglandins in the stomach --> gastric mucosa gets corroded easily. So, these drugs are more prone to cause gastric ulcers.

Related Pearl: Some Important Points about Selective COX-2 Inhibitors

They are also known as coxibs. They are different from non-selective COX inhibitors as follows:

  • Fewer GI side effects as COX-1 is not inhibited
  • No antiplatelet action as thromboxane A2 production is unaffected.

Adverse effects and contraindications:

  • Myocardial infarction
  • Stroke
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hypertension
  • Renal impairment.

Order of COX-2 selectivity

  • Lumiracoxib > etoricoxib > rofecoxib > valdecoxib > celecoxib.
  • Lumiracoxib - most selective
  • Celecoxib - least selective

The only coxib which can be given parenterally is Parecoxib.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic cough and breathlessness to the outpatient department. His chest X-ray is shown below. The finding marked by the arrows in the X-ray is formed due to hyperinflation of ____________
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray shows the Luftsichel sign seen in some cases of left upper lobe collapse. It is formed due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of left lower lobe interposing itself between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe. 

Luftsichel sign which translates from German as 'air crescent' means sickle of air around the aortic knuckle. It is typically seen in the left upper lobe collapse, resulting in para-mediastinal translucency. The sickle of air represents the hyperinflated left lower lobe i.e., hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, creating a crescent of air between the aortic arch and the medial border of the collapsed left upper lobe.

Differential diagnosis for Luftsichel sign

  • Right lung herniation
  • Medial pneumothorax
  • Pneumomediastinum
  • Lung cancer


Other radiological findings in lobar collapse are:

  • Mediastinal shift to the ipsilateral side
  • Elevation of ipsilateral hemidiaphragm
  • Hyperinflation of the opposite lung


On CT, the collapsed upper lobe is visualized as a wedge-shaped opacity near the paramediastinal lucency.

questions.text: A young man presented with chronic cough and evening rise in body temperature. He has a history of decreased appetite and weight loss. On examination, a mass is found in the right iliac fossa. A barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the barium meal follow-through study showing conical caecum, narrowing of the terminal ileum, and proximal ileal dilation are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. The radiological finding not seen in ileocecal tuberculosis is the apple-core sign. Apple-core or napkin-ring sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows).

 

Intestinal tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and intermittent diarrhea. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa. The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. Other sites involved in the abdomen are the proximal colon and peritoneum.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Fleischner sign- narrow ileum with the thickened ileocecal valve
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Contracted conical caecum
  • Gooseneck deformity - due to contracted, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum
  • String sign - due to persistently narrowed intestinal segment due to inflammation

The image below shows the findings seen in ileocaecal tuberculosis:

  • Yellow arrow- shrunken conical caecum
  • Red arrow- strictures narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction
  • Blue arrow- proximal ileal dilation

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: An infant presents with delayed milestones, irritability, seizures, and weak limb movements. On examination, there is macrocephaly, prominent occiput, and bulging fontanelles.  MRI brain is shown below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?

choices.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore
Developmental failure of roof of fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to Dandy-Walker syndrome, in which developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle is seen. The MRI shows a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa.

Dandy-Walker syndrome is a posterior fossa anomaly that includes cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. The clinical features are macrocephaly, prominent occiput, delayed developmental milestones, and cerebellar ataxia. Features of hydrocephalus such as irritability, brisk deep tendon reflexes, seizures, bulging fontanelle, and spasticity are the other clinical manifestations. It can be due to chromosomal abnormalities, teratogen exposure, or single gene disorders. 

Hydrocephalus is a group of conditions that arise due to impaired circulation or absorption of cerebrospinal fluid. In some cases, it can be due to increased production as seen in choroid plexus papilloma. Other causes include congenital aqueduct stenosis, neural tube defects, and posterior fossa malformations.

The image below depicts the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid.

Acetazolamide and furosemide can be used for the medical management of hydrocephalus temporarily. Extracranial shunts such as ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the definitive management. Complications of shunts include occlusion and infections. 

Other options:

Option A: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore produces anencephaly. There is an absence of cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum. Anencephalic infants usually die within a few days of birth.

Option B: Displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the cervical canal produces type 1 Chiari malformations.  Symptoms include headaches, neck pain, urinary frequency, and spasticity. They usually present during late childhood.

The following image shows type 1 Chiari malformations.

Option C: Failure of pontine flexure development during embryogenesis produces type 2 Chiari malformations. Presenting features during infancy include stridor, weak cry, and apnea. During childhood, it can present with spasticity and incoordination.

questions.text: You are an intern assisting in a cesarian section. Your consultant asks you to pick the instrument and retract the abdominal wall and bladder for a better view. Which among the following instruments would you choose?
questions.solution:
The correct option is Image 2 which is a Doyen's retractor.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder for proper exposure of the lower uterine segment during a cesarean section.

Other options:

Image 1 shows a Deaver’s retractor would be most useful in cholecystectomy as it is specifically designed for holding the liver up and out of the way. It is used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. Some surgeons protect the liver with an abdominal pack before placing the blade on top.

Image 3 shows a Morris retractor is a large retractor useful for providing maximum exposure in large incisions e.g., abdominal incisions. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Image 4 shows Czerny's retractor which is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

questions.text:
A young child presents with muscle weakness and excessive urination. He was initially evaluated at a primary care facility, where hypokalemia was suspected, but his symptoms did not improve despite treatment. Your consultant diagnoses the condition as a channelopathy based on the investigations. This condition presents similar to the chronic use of which of the following drugs?
Investigations Values
Urine calcium Increased
pH 7.55
HCO3- 28
pC02 46
Serum K+ 2.1 mEq/L
Serum Cl- 80 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a child with muscle weakness and polyuria, refractory hypokalemia and lab report showing typical hypercalciuria, hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis is suggestive of Bartter syndrome and this resembles the effects of the long term use of loop diuretics i.e. furosemide. Long term use of loop diuretics also leads to hypocalcemia and hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because loop diuretics inhibit Na+/K+/Cl channel.

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention
  • Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
  • Normotensive

The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of the long term use of loop diuretics as Loop diuretics also act on the Na+/K+/Cl channel. Treatment of Barrter syndrome is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride. NSAIDs like indomethacin are second-line drugs for Barrter syndrome; however, they can reduce renal function.

Bartter syndrome has to be differentiated from gitelman syndrome.

Bartter syndrome Gitelman syndrome
 Affects thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle  Affects Distal convoluted tubule
Hypercalciuria Hypocalciuria
 Normal or mildly decreased magnesium  Hypomagnesemia
 Resembles loop diuretic effects (e.g., furosemide)  Resembles thiazide diuretic effects (e.g. Hydrochlorthiazide)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with hypertension participates in a clinical trial evaluating a new antihypertensive drug. Throughout the study, he becomes more consistent with his medication regimen and adopts healthier habits, such as a better diet and more exercise, because he knows he is being observed. This results in a greater-than-expected improvement in his blood pressure. Which among the following biases is responsible for this improvement?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario where a patient is more consistent with medications and adopts an improved lifestyle because he knows he is under observation is consistent with Hawthorne bias (effect).

The Hawthorne effect describes a change in the behavior of an individual that results from their awareness of being observed.

Other options:

Option B: Berkesonian bias applies to hospital-based case-control studies. This occurs due to differential hospital admission rates of the cases and the controls.

Option C: Neyman bias or prevalence-incidence bias is due to selective survival in prevalent cases. It is usually seen in fatal diseases.

Option D: Surveillance bias occurs when active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA image showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop. Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

Option D: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a bilateral disease affecting people who are above 50 years of age. It can be exudative or non-exudative types. There can be a gradual or sudden loss of vision depending on the type of AMD. Drusens (yellowish-white elevated spots caused by extracellular deposits in the macular region) of various types can be noted. FFA shows punctate hyperfluorescence due to the drusen. questions.text: A neurodegenerative disease causing UMN as well as LMN weakness, affecting the green areas on the spinal cord is shown in the image. Which of the following gene mutation is responsible for the disease?
questions.solution:
The given image and clinical scenario is of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, which is caused due to SOD 1 gene mutation. The image has the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the corticospinal tracts highlighted in green, representing the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologs in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. The hereditary forms of ALS have mutations in the genes encoding for superoxide dismutase (SOD 1) present on chromosome 21.

Patients with ALS present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity.

The involvement of the corticobulbar fibers leads to exaggerated expressions of emotion, such as excessive weeping or laughing. This is called the pseudobulbar affect. Some patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, sensory, bowel, and bladder functions and cognition are preserved, even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: SMN1 mutation- Spinal muscular atrophy: The SMN1 (Survival Motor Neuron 1) gene produces a protein crucial for motor neuron survival. Mutations in this gene result in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and atrophy due to loss of motor neurons in the spinal cord.

Option C: APP mutation- Alzheimer's disease: The APP (Amyloid Precursor Protein) gene is associated with Alzheimer’s disease. Mutations in this gene can lead to the abnormal accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques in the brain, which are hallmarks of Alzheimer’s and contribute to neurodegeneration and cognitive decline.

Option D: ATM mutation- Cancer protection gene: The ATM (Ataxia-Telangiectasia Mutated) gene plays a role in DNA repair and cellular response to damage. Mutations in this gene are linked to ataxia-telangiectasia, a condition with increased cancer risk.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with non-scarring patchy hair loss as shown in the given image. Fine stippled pitting of the nails was also seen. Which of the following is the initial treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a person having non-scarring smooth patchy hair loss suggesting the diagnosis of Alopecia areata, where intralesional steroids are the initial treatment of choice. 

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hair strands are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases, including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.  

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair color, called going white overnight.  Classically, alopecia areata causes fine stippled pitting of the nails, but some cases show less well‐defined roughening of the nail plate (trachyonychia) or non‐specific atrophic dystrophy. 

Intralesional corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice for Patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid (hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/mL or triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/mL), administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis. In patients with rapidly progressive or extensive alopecia areata, Oral corticosteroids may be helpful.

Option A: Topical minoxidil is used in male pattern and female pattern baldness.

Option B: Oral corticosteroids are used as second-line treatment if the initial treatment fails. Contact immunotherapy is the third-line treatment and it is the most effective and best-documented method for alopecia areata.  Severe and long-standing alopecia areata require oral corticosteroids.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: To study the basics of the concentration of urine by countercurrent mechanism, a researcher compares the specific gravity of the urine of a bodybuilder (A) and a sedentary worker (B). The difference in concentration between the two subjects would be due to:

choices.text: Permeability of water through the descending loop
Impermeability of urea through ascending loop

questions.solution:
The difference in the urine concentrations between the two subjects is due to the presence of high urea in subject A, who is a bodybuilder. The impermeability of urea through the ascending loop makes the urine more concentrated. Individuals consuming a high-protein diet, like bodybuilders, produce more urea as nitrogenous waste than ordinary individuals. This increased urea plays a role in further increasing urine concentration.

Urea is permeable in the descending limb of the loop of Henle and is impermeable in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. If this urea is reabsorbed via the descending limb of the loop of Henle without any control, it will result in life-threatening dehydration due to loss of osmolality in the renal medullary interstitium. Therefore, higher concentrations of urea in the renal medullary interstitium are maintained by the Vasa recta.

Urea from the interstitium is taken up by the descending limb of the vasa recta, and the urea is given out by the ascending limb of the vasa recta. This ensures that high concentrations of urea remain in the medullary interstitium. This is called the counter-current exchange mechanism. Also, there is facilitated diffusion of urea from the inner medullary collecting duct into the renal medullary interstitium via specific urea transporters UT-A1 and UT-A3. One of these transporter, UT-A3 transporter, is activated by ADH.

Factors which increase ADH secretion are:

  • Increased Osmotic pressure
  • Decreased ECF (Extra-cellular fluid) volume
  • pain
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Angiotensin 2
  • SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion)

Other Options:

Option A: The descending limb of the loop of Henle is more permeable to water and the differential permeability to water is not the reason for the difference in urine osmolality in this case. 

Option C: The clinical stem in the above question has no pointers toward factors that can increase ADH secretion (described above). Note that, increased ADH can increase urine osmolality, but it is not the reason for increased urine osmolality in the given question. 

Option D: In Central Diabetes Insipidus, wherein the posterior pituitary fails to produce ADH, and in Peripheral Diabetes Insipidus, the kidneys are not able to respond to ADH. In both these cases, low levels of ADH result in poorly diluted urine due to both reduced absorption of free water and inactivation of the UT-A3 urea transporter. The question stem does not mention any features of Diabetes Insipidus or low ADH levels.

Note: Malnourished individuals with low protein consumption will have low urea and, hence, low osmolality urine. The below image demonstrates the counter-current mechanism.

questions.text: A preterm newborn delivered at 30 weeks of gestation does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. On further evaluation, the heart rate is 104 beats/min but laboured breathing is observed. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of a preterm neonate with a heart rate >100 beats/minute and laboured breathing, is oxygen supplementation via continuous positive airway pressure(CPAP). 
In preterms, due to deficiency of lung surfactants, there is a higher chance of alveolar collapse. CPAP increases pressure in the airway and keeps the alveoli open.
In term neonates, oxygen supplementation via nasal prongs or oxygen hood is recommended. Oxygen saturation should be regularly monitored and supplemental oxygen should be titrated to achieve the targeted saturations.
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the baby is apneic, has gasping breathing or heart rate <100 beats/min, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is provided with a bag and mask. SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is <60 beats/min, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1.
  • IV epinephrine is given via the umbilical vein, if the heart rate still remains < 60 beats/min, despite effective compressions and ventilation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to you with painful midline swelling in the neck. Thyroid carcinoma is suspected and staged as T1aN0M0 after evaluation. A biopsy image of the swelling is given below. What is the management?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection
Hemithyroidectomy with central and modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central and modified radical neck dissection

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman suspected of thyroid carcinoma of stage T1aN0M0 and biopsy image showing amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma(MTC) and the management is Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection. 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTCs are sporadic, but they may be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. All the inherited variants are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients are 50–60 year old women. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminase, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Clinical Features of MTC include:

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis

Diagnosis is made through careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and a fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass. The biopsy image shows sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid-rich stroma with nests of polygonal cells.  Immunohistochemistry for calcitonin is commonly used as a diagnostic tumor marker. All new patients with MTC should be screened for RET point mutations, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. If a pheochromocytoma is found, it must be treated first.
 

Management of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is as follows:

Extent of cancer  Surgery
MTC without LN involvement (N0) Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection(prophylactic) 
MTC + central neck nodes involved or tumor size ≥1.5 cm  Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (therapeutic) + Ipsilateral Modified radical neck dissection (prophylactic) 
MTC + other LNs involved  Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection + Bilateral Modified radical neck dissection (therapeutic) 
Metastatic disease 

Debulking thyroidectomy 

Chemotherapy

  • Vandetanib (multi-kinase inhibitor) - drug of choice
  • Labetuzumab (anti-CEA)

External beam radiotherapy 

Other Thyroid Carcinomas:

Papillary thyroid Carcinomas are seen in 3rd and 4th decade more common in females than males. It can be distinguished on histology based on psammoma bodies and orphan Annie eye nuclei.

Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma usually presents around the age of 50 years. Histologically, it can be distinguished by a trust biopsy, which shows encapsulation and the presence of uniform sheets of cells devoid of colloid.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and sinus pain over the last few months. His endoscopy findings are in the image below and it seems to arise from the non-olfactory mucosa of the nasal cavity. Which of the following viruses is most commonly associated with the development of this nasal lesion?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, the endoscopic findings and the fact that they arise from the nonolfactory mucosa are suggestive of an inverted papilloma, and the most common viral association is the Human papillomavirus (HPV).

Inverted papillomas are benign but locally aggressive tumors. These benign epithelial tumors most commonly arise from the Schneiderian membrane (the non-olfactory mucosa of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses). 

They typically present with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and sinus-related pain. The tumour is unilateral in most cases and locally aggressive. It can potentially involve the sinuses and extend into the orbit, leading to complications like proptosis and diplopia in some cases.

On endoscopic examination, it presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps (as shown in the image above). CT and MRI imaging are used to assess the extent of the lesion and its involvement with surrounding structures. MRI provides additional help to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.

Histologically(as shown below), they are characterized by the inversion of epithelial cells into the underlying stroma rather than exophytic growth. HPV, particularly types 6 and 11, has been strongly implicated in the pathogenesis of inverted papillomas. The viral DNA is often found in normal-appearing adjacent tissue, which may explain the high rates of recurrence, even after surgical excision.

The treatment of choice for an inverted papilloma is medial maxillectomy, typically via an endoscopic approach. Although radiotherapy is sometimes considered for residual disease, it is not commonly recommended due to the risk of inducing malignancy. Regular follow-up is essential due to the tumor’s potential for recurrence and malignant transformation in up to 10-15% of cases.

Other options:
Option A: Herpes simplex virus causes herpetic gingivostomatitis.
Option C Epstein-Barr (EB) virus is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer, infectious mononucleosis, hairy leukoplakia, and non-Hodgkins lymphoma.
Option D: Cytomegalovirus primarily affects immunosuppressed transplant patients. Clinically, it mimics infectious mononucleosis, but the heterophil antibody test is negative.

questions.text: A 20-month-old child is noted to have weight-for-height <3SD, MUAC < 11.5cm, and bipedal edema. In the management of this child, which of the following is not supplemented in the stabilization phase?
questions.solution:
A child with weight-for-height <3SD, MUAC < 11.5cm, and bipedal edema, satisfies the WHO criteria for being diagnosed with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and requires hospital management. In the management of this child, micronutrients are supplemented in the stabilization phase, but iron is not supplemented during this phase.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

  1. Initial stabilization phase (Week 1): It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.
  2. Rehabilitation phase (Weeks 2-6): It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Micronutrient deficiency correction begins in the stabilization phase, but iron supplementation begins in the rehabilitation phase as excess iron leads to free radical injury.

The 10 steps in SAM management are outlined below:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. (Option A)
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1) (Option B)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day) (Option C)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Per speculum examination of the vagina is done as shown below. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes an oral medication. What is the likely mechanism of action of the given medication?

choices.text: Forms pores in the fungal cell wall

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is fluconazole which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Therapeutic uses of fluconazole-

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be treated with fluconazole by taking 100–200 mg a day for 7–14 days. Uncomplicated vaginal candidiasis can be effectively treated with a single 150 mg dose. Treatment of candidemia in nonimmunosuppressed patients involves a loading dosage of 800 mg, followed by 400 mg daily.
  • For the first eight weeks of the consolidation phase of the therapy of cryptococcal meningitis in individuals with AIDS, fluconazole is administered.
  • Due to its excellent CSF penetration and significantly lower morbidity than intrathecal amphotericin B, fluconazole is the medication of choice for treating coccidioidal meningitis. Fluconazole is similar to itraconazole in treating various types of coccidioidomycosis.

Other options

Option A- Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane. It has also been found that it forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid bilayers, leading to fungal cell death. It is indicated in invasive mucormycosis, fungal endophthalmitis following pars plana vitrectomy, and induction therapy in cryptococcal meningitis. 

Option B- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is also effective in treating ringworm of glabrous skin, tinea cruris, tinea corprosis, tinea pedis, and tinea of the hands and beard. 

Option C- Terbinafine acts by inhibiting epoxidation of fungal squalene that reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. It is helpful for treating nail onychomycosis in adults and tinea capitis.

questions.text: A female patient with twin pregnancies underwent an abdominal ultrasound. It showed that the upper part of the body of one fetus was absent and the other fetus was normal. The echo of the normal fetus was suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP).

TRAP is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Here, the recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore, in the recipient twin, only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Developmental abnormality in the recipient twin:

  • No identifiable structures - Acardius amorphous
  • Failure of head growth - Acardius acephalus
  • Partially developed head with identifiable limbs - Acardius myelacephalus

Other options: 

Option A- Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. After oxygenation, the blood is taken up by the recipient twin. The donor twin will have anemia and appears pale, while the recipient twin will have polycythemia and features of heart failure.

Option B- Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is pale and anemic, whereas the recipient twin is polycythemic. However, unlike the case with TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

Option D- Twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS) is seen in TTTS. The donor fetus becomes oliguric due to hypovolemia, and the recipient fetus develops increased urine output due to hypervolemia. This results in oligohydramnios in the donor and hydramnios in the recipient fetus.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male with a history of head trauma 6 months ago presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination for two months. Blood tests revealed urine osmolality <300 mosm/L, and basal AVP was less than 1pg/ ml. An MRI showed an absent pituitary bright spot. As a part of the management—the drug administered targets which receptor to restore water balance?

AVP- Arginine vasopressin levels
DCT- Distal convoluted tubule
CD- Collecting duct
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of polyuria, history of head trauma, urine osmolality <300 mosm/L, basal AVP <1pg/ ml with an absence of a pituitary bright spot on the MRI brain is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The drug of choice for this condition is desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist.

Desmopressin stimulates the V2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of the principal cells in the collecting tubules. This increases the insertion of water channels (aquaporin 2) into the apical membrane, leading to increased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts. The activation of V2 receptors also increases the permeability of urea.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic).

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml. Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired.

Other options:

Option A: V1 receptor agonism (Terlipressin): This primarily causes vasoconstriction and has minimal effect on water reabsorption and is used in bleeding varices

Option C: Na+Cl- channel in DCT: This channel is involved in sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule and is the mechanism of action of thiazides which are primarily drug of choice in nephrogenic diabetes inspidus.

Option D: ENaC channels in CD: Drugs acting on these channels like amiloride and triamterene regulate sodium reabsorption in the collecting ducts but do not directly address water reabsorption.

questions.text: A patient with jaundice was suspected to have hepatitis infection. On serological investigation, his IgM anti-HBc and IgM anti-HDV were elevated suggesting coinfection of Hepatitis B with Hepatitis “Delta” virus. Which of the following is correct regarding Hepatitis “Delta” virus?

choices.text: Vaccination against hepatitis B cannot prevent infection with this virus
Its genome has circular, negative-sense single-stranded RNA
It can rarely cause fulminant disease

questions.solution:
The given scenario involves a patient with coinfection with hepatitis B and hepatitis D (Hepatitis delta virus). The Hepatitis D virus has circular, negative-sense single-stranded RNA.

The Hepatitis D virus is taxonomically unclassified but it is placed in the Deltavirus genus. It is the smallest of known human pathogens and resembles subviral plant pathogens (ie. viroids). The genome of the Hepatitis D virus consists of circular, negative-sense single-stranded RNA. No homology exists with the HBV genome. HDAg is the only protein coded for by HDV RNA and is distinct from the antigenic determinants of HBV. 

The Hepatitis D virus has a very small particle size of 35–37 nm and is surrounded by an envelope protein derived from HBsAg of the hepatitis B virus. Hence, it is called “defective virus” as it cannot replicate independently and needs the HBsAg coat for transmission. Hepatitis D virus infection frequently can progress to a fulminant disease. (Statement C).

Co-infection occurs when a person is exposed simultaneously to serum containing both HDV and HBV . Hepatitis B virus infection sets in first so that HBsAg becomes available for HDV. This is usually a transient and self-limited condition; clinically indistinguishable from acute hepatitis B infection. Vaccination against hepatitis B can prevent against Hepatitis D Virus. (Statement A).

Superinfection with hepatitis D (HDV) can also occur in individuals already infected with hepatitis B (HBV), often leading to more severe and chronic liver disease and increasing the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug that acts at site 1, as shown below. During follow-up, he has complaints of erectile dysfunction. The physician decided to switch to another drug belonging to the same class. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Potassium-sparing diuretics act on site 1 shown in the image i.e. the distal tubule and collecting duct. Finrenone belongs to the same class but has a lower chance of causing anti-androgenic side effects like erectile dysfunction and can be used in this patient.

Potassium-sparing diuretics such as spironolactone, eplerenone, and finerenone act on site 1 i.e. distal tubule and collecting duct. These areas have high concentration of mineralocorticoid receptors for the binding of aldosterone. Thus, K-sparing diuretics act as antagonists at these receptors and are called aldosterone antagonists.

Spironolactone additionally has an affinity towards progesterone and androgen receptors exerting anti-androgenic effects like gynaecomastia, menstrual irregularities, and erectile dysfunction. 

Eplerenone and finerenone (non-steroidal MR antagonists) have low affinity for progesterone and androgen receptors and hence have lesser anti-androgenic side effects.

Other options:

Option B-  Dichlorphenamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and acts on the proximal tubule.

Option C- Ethacrynic acid is a loop diuretic acting on the Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter present on the thick ascending loop of Henle.

Option D- Metolazone is a thiazide diuretic acting on the Na+- Cl- symporter of the distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents to the surgery outpatient unit with dilated, tortuous veins in the right leg. The skin finding seen on examination is given in the image below. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP (Clinical- etiology- anatomy- pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders) classification?
questions.solution:
The clinical description is suggestive of varicose veins. The given image shows venous eczema which belongs to the C4a stage of the CEAP classification.

Varicose veins refer to subcutaneous dilated veins of more than 3 mm in diameter. 

Risk factors:

  • Females>males
  • Increasing age
  • Increasing body mass and height
  • Pregnancy
  • Family history
  • Smokers 
  • Occupations involving prolonged periods of standing

Clinical classification according to CEAP is:  

  • C0- no signs of venous disease
  • C1- telangiectasia (<1 mm dilatation) or reticular veins (1 mm - 2.9 mm dilatation)
  • C2- varicose vein (>3 mm dilatation)
    • C2r- recurrent varicose veins
  • C3-  edema
  • C4- changes in the skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease
    • C4a- pigmentation or eczema
    • C4b- lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
    • C4c- corona phlebectatica
  • C5- healed ulcer
  • C6- active venous ulcer
    • C6r- recurrent active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further sub-categorized into symptomatic (S) and asymptomatic (A).

Image A - tortuous dilated veins - C2

Image B - Atrophie blanche - C4b

Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia - C4c

The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers respectively.

Investigations: 

  • Clinical examination
  • Venous duplex ultrasound of 7.5-13MHz probe intensity which tells about:
    • the site of reflux
    • size of vein
    • location of perforators
    • presence of obstruction in deep venous system
    • indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction
  • MR venography
  • Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management:

  • Endovascular procedures
    • Endovascular laser ablation
    • Radiofrequency ablation
    • Ultrasound guided foam sclerotherapy
    • Catheter directed sclerotherapy and mechanochemical ablation
    • Endovenous glue
  • Open surgeries
    • Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous vein stripping
    • Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous vein stripping
  • Non-Surgical procedures
    • Compression stockings

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to the orthopedic OPD with complaint of left shoulder pain. The patient gave a history of a sustained blow to the arm while playing football 4 years back which led to left anterior shoulder dislocation, following which he has had recurrent anterior shoulder dislocations. An X-ray of the left shoulder was done. What is the likely lesion seen on the X-ray?

choices.text: Bankart lesion due to avulsion of posteroinferior part of glenoid labrum
Hill-Sach lesion due to excavation on the posterolateral surface of the head of  humerus
Bankart lesion due to avulsion of anteroinferior part of glenoid labrum
Hill-Sach lesion due to excavation on the anteromedial surface of the head of humerus

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a 25-year-old male with a history of recurrent left anterior shoulder dislocations presented with left shoulder pain and the X-ray shows avulsion of the anteroinferior part of glenoid labrum indicating a Bankart lesion. 

It is the most common lesion associated with anterior shoulder dislocation. Recurrent anterior dislocation causes stripping or avulsion of the glenoid labrum and the periosteum from the anterior inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck. In some cases, a small fragment of bone from the glenoid rim can also be avulsed. This is known as the “Bony Bankart”  lesion. X-ray shows the overlapping shadows of the humeral head and glenoid fossa.

Shoulder dislocations can be anterior, posterior, or inferior, but anterior dislocation is more common. It occurs due to falling on an outstretched hand when the shoulder joint is abducted and externally rotated. 

Other options : 

Option A:  Reverse Bankart lesion is due to avulsion of glenoid labrum from the posteroinferior part. It is most commonly seen in posterior shoulder dislocation.

Option B: Hill-Sach lesion is a defect or excavation on the posterolateral surface of the head of the humerus, due to repeated impact of the head of humerus against the anterior glenoid rim in recurrent dislocations.

Option D: Reverse Hill-Sach lesion is a defect or excavation on the anteromedial surface of the head of humerus. It is seen in posterior shoulder dislocation. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: Which mechanism best explains the resistance of Staphylococcus aureus to vancomycin as seen in Vancomycin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA)?

choices.text: Increased cell wall synthesis and alterations in the cell wall structure
Acquisition of van A gene and mec A gene
Efflux of vancomycin by efflux pumps

questions.solution:
In Vancomycin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA) the mechanism best explaining the resistance of S. aureus to vancomycin is the acquisition of van A gene and mec A gene. Vancomycin-resistant S. aureus (VRSA) strains have the vancomycin resistance gene van A which is derived from enterococci and the methicillin resistance gene mec A. Vancomycin resistance in S. aureus is of major concern worldwide. VRSA remains susceptible to linezolid.

Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that prevents the synthesis of cell walls in susceptible bacteria by binding to the cell wall's d-alanyl-d-alanine portion. Vancomycin resistance in Gram-positive bacteria, particularly S aureus, is mediated by the vanA operon --> replaces D-Ala-D-Ala with D-Ala-D-Lac, rendering the cell wall resistant to vancomycin. 

Other options : 

Option A: The Vancomycin-intermediate S. aureus (VISA) strains (MIC is 4-8 μg/mL) are usually seen in patients with complex infections who have received prolonged vancomycin therapy. The mechanism of resistance is associated with increased cell wall synthesis and alterations in the cell wall and is not caused by the van genes found in enterococci. 
Option C: S.aureus by producing β-lactamase can cleave the β-lactam ring and make the organisms resistant to many penicillins like penicillin G, ampicillin, and piperacillin.
Option D: Efflux pumps are not a mechanism of drug resistance seen in S. aureus.

[Note: Staphylococcus aureus is considered susceptible to vancomycin if the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is ≤ 2 μg/mL, of intermediate susceptibility if the MIC is 4–8 μg/mL, and resistant if the MIC is ≥16 μg/mL.]

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text:
A child presented with impaired cognitive function. Detailed history and observation revealed multiple types of seizures and his EEG showed slow (<3Hz) spike and wave discharges. A diagnosed of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome was arrived at. Which among the following options is a first-line drug for his condition?

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate is a first-line drug for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

Valproate is an broad spectrum antiseziure drug. It is used in:

  • Partial seizures
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seziures (GTCS)
  • Absence seziures
  • Myoclonic seziures 
  • Atonic seziures

Valproate act via multiple mechanisms like:

  • Prolonged sodium channel inactivation
  • Attenuation of calcium-mediated 'T' current 
  • Enhanced release of  inhibitory transmitter GABA due to inhibition of its degradation and increasing its synthesis from glutamic acid
  • Inhibition of excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare severe form of childhood epilepsy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Multiple types of seizures including GTCS, atonic, myoclonic, atypical absence seizures
  • <3Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG
  • Impaired cognitive function

They are predominantly seen in early childhood between the age group of 1 to 7 years peaking at around 3 years of age. Intellectual impairment in the form of developmental delay starts usually after the occurrence of seizures.

An EEG of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Zonisamide is an antiepileptic drug used as adjuvant therapy of focal seizures in adults. It can also be used as an add-on in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. 

Option B: Levetiracetam is also effective in most of the seizures present in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

Option D: Vigabatrin is also effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

 

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs
