questions.text: A 4-month-old girl presented to the emergency with fever of 38.3 ℃ (101 ℉) and persistent crying for the past 2 days. On examination, there was redness and swelling around the left hip and severe pain on passive movement. The hip X-ray shows complete destruction of the head and neck of the femur. Joint arthrocentesis revealed purulent fluid and the presence of bacteria. Which of the following will be seen in the left lower limb of this child?

choices.text: There will be reduced mobility at the left hip joint
Left lower limb lengthening will be seen

questions.solution:
This is a condition of septic arthritis of the left hip joint in an infant, called Tom Smith’s arthritis. The telescopy test is positive for the affected limb.

In the given clinical scenario, a 4-month-old girl has a fever of 38.3 ℃ (101 ℉), persistent crying for the past 2 days with redness and swelling around the left hip. The X-ray of the hip shows complete destruction of the head and neck of the femur, and joint arthrocentesis revealed purulent fluid and the presence of bacteria, suggesting the diagnosis of Tom-Smith's arthritis.

Tom Smith's arthritis is septic arthritis of the hip seen in infancy. At this age, the capital femoral epiphysis is cartilaginous and completely destroyed by the pyogenic process, leading to chondrolysis.  There is a complete destruction of the femoral head and neck as it is cartilaginous at this age. This results in limb shortening and increased mobility in all directions at the affected hip joint, leading to an unstable gait. (Option A and C)

Telescopy test is positive here. It is a provocative test, which involves applying traction to an infant's legs while they are lying down. Since the head of the femur is completely destroyed here the limb can “telescope” into the acetabulum. A positive test indicates hip instability and dislocation.

On X-ray, it shows destruction of the head and neck of the femur. Immediate surgery is done to preserve the hip function. 

[Note: One of the closest differential diagnoses is Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip(DDH), which also presents at the same age. The complete absence of the head and neck of the femur and a normally developed round acetabulum (Option D) can differentiate Tom-Smith arthritis from the DDH in which the acetabulum is shallower.] 

An example of an X-ray in a pediatric child showing complete destruction of the head and neck of the femur (as in septic arthritis) is given below.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with a mass on his right thigh. The mass seems to arise from the deep soft tissues. Histopathological examination shows abundant basophilic myxoid matrix, arborizing capillaries, primitive cells at various stages of adipocyte differentiation resembling fetal fat and molecular analysis shows t(12;16). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a mass on the thigh arising from deeper soft tissues and showing abundant basophilic myxoid matrix, arborizing capillaries, primitive cells at various stages of adipocyte differentiation resembling fetal fat and t(12;16) is suggestive of liposarcoma, of the myxoid subtype. 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults. The usual sites are the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and the retroperitoneum. It usually occurs in the sixth and seventh decades of life. Liposarcoma has been divided into 3 types depending on the histology and the underlying genetic abnormality.

Well-differentiated liposarcomas are composed of mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. They harbor amplifications of chromosome 12q13, which includes the p53 inhibitor MDM2. Myxoid liposarcoma shows an abundant myxoid matrix that appears basophilic, arborizing capillaries, and primitive adipocytes in various stages of maturation, resembling fetal fat. The genetic abnormality seen in myxoid liposarcoma is t(12;16). Pleomorphic liposarcomas show sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei along with immature adipocytes known as lipoblasts. The genetic abnormalities of pleomorphic liposarcoma are highly variable.

Liposarcomas frequently recur locally and require adequate excision. While the well-differentiated tumors are slow-progression, the poorly-differentiated ones can be aggressive and metastasize.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of a well-differentiated liposarcoma showing mature adipocytes with scattered spindle cells. 

 

Other options:

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. The embryonal type shows primitive round and spindle cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of the embryonal type that develops in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures such as nasopharynx. Alveolar variant of rhabdomyosarcoma has a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters, thus imparting a resemblance to alveoli of the lung. Rhabdomyosarcomas show t(1;13) or t(2;13), are aggressive tumors and require surgical resection and chemotherapy. 

Option C: Synovial sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm. Biphasic type can also contain gland-like structures. The characteristic chromosomal abnormality which is seen is t(x;18). Despite the name, synovial sarcomas don't originate from the synoviocytes and can present in locations which lack synovium. 

Option D: Deep fibromatosis (Desmoid tumor) are large infiltrative masses that usually occur on the abdominal wall and have a tendency to reoccur. They are gray-white, rubbery, and tough on gross examination. On microscopy, they show bland fibroblasts arranged in long and parallel fascicles and infiltrate the surrounding muscle, nerve and fat. Desmoid tumors show APC or β-catenin mutations.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with headache and vomiting for 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. He had intermittent bloody stools for the past 6 months. He has a family history of colon carcinoma. An MRI of his brain is given below. Colonoscopy and biopsy revealed numerous adenomatous polyps in the rectum and the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a brain tumour as seen in the MRI. Hence the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Turcot's syndrome is characterised by malignant tumours of the central nervous system in association with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (option A) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic of FAP. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Gardner's syndrome (option C) is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have osteomas of the mandible or skull, epidermal cysts and soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

In Peutz-Jegher's syndrome, (option D) there is pigmentation of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines. It is an autosomal dominant disease.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, after inserting the Veress needle, which of the following findings would indicate that the needle remains in an extraperitoneal location?

choices.text: The hanging drop test shows the drop remains in the hub of the needle
Free flow of saline into the cavity
Abdominal pressure reading of less than 10 mmHg

questions.solution:
The correct option (A) suggests that the Veress needle is still extraperitoneal. Veress Needle Insertion is commonly used to create a pneumoperitoneum by introducing carbon dioxide into the peritoneal cavity for laparoscopic procedures. Hanging drop test is used to confirm the location of the needle. In the hanging drop test, a small drop of saline is placed on the hub of the Veress needle.

  • If the needle is intraperitoneal, the drop will be sucked into the needle because of the negative pressure in the peritoneal cavity, indicating that the needle is in the right location.
  • If the needle is in an extraperitoneal location, there is no negative pressure to draw in the saline, so the drop will remain in the hub of the needle. This is a key sign that the needle is not inside the peritoneal cavity but rather in a false space.

Confirmation of intraperitoneal placement of needle:

  • In the hanging drop method, wherein a drop of water is placed in the hub of the needle; on elevating the abdominal wall the resultant loss of intra-abdominal pressure would result in the drop emptying into the abdominal cavity.
  • Free flow of saline into the peritoneal cavity and no return of bowel content or no blood on aspiration.
  • Abdominal pressure reading of less than 10 mmHg.

There are two methods for establishing abdominal access during laparoscopic surgeries:

  • Direct puncture using a Veress needle
  • Direct peritoneal access (Hasson's technique)

Veress needle is most commonly inserted at the palmer point (3 cm below the left coastal margin in the mid-clavicular line). It allows safe entry into the abdominal cavity by injecting CO₂, to inflate the abdomen, creating space for surgical instruments while minimizing the risk of injury to internal organs. Maximum pressure for the gas is typically in the range of 14-15 mm Hg. Once adequate pressure is reached, the needle is removed. The following image depicts a Veress needle:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. 

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • Myelosuppression 
  • Cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and perianal itching for the last 3 days. The scotch tape method demonstrated the following eggs as shown in the image. What is the likely habitat of the adult form of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the likely causative organism is Enterobius vermicularis (Pinworm), and colorless, non-bile stained, planoconvex eggs are seen on the scotch tape method. Adult worms of Enterobius vermicularis are found in the cecum, appendix, and adjacent portion of the ascending colon, but migrate to the rectum and anal canal to lay eggs at night.

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. Infection is acquired by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection.

At night, the gravid female worm migrates from the colon to the rectum and anal canal to deposit eggs on the perianal and perineal skin, causing perianal itching. This nocturnal egg-laying behavior is a hallmark of the infection.

The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Adult worms of Enterobius vermicularis are found in the cecum, appendix, and adjacent portion of the ascending colon. 

The eggs can be demonstrated by the NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) method or Scotch tape method or by examining the dirt collected beneath the fingernails of affected children. The eggs are rarely released in feces hence a fecal examination is not useful for diagnosis. 

In scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with a sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope. The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in the saturated salt solution. Eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

NIH swab method consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically. 

Note: Non-bile stained eggs are: (NEHA)
       NEMATODES
   a) Necator americanus
   b) Ancyclostoma duodenale
   c) Enterobios vermicularis 
       CESTODES
   d) Hymenolepis nana

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 29-year-old man came with a history of jerky and hyperkinetic movements involving all parts of the body. His MRI shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. There is a significant family history with successive generations having symptoms at earlier ages of onset. The pedigree chart is given below. Identify this genetic phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario, with the family pedigree chart showing autosomal dominant inheritance points towards Huntington’s disease, and the genetic phenomenon seen here is anticipation. Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. 

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the striate neurons. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene located on chromosome 4. This results in jerky, hyperkinetic movements called chorea and dementia. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. Motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia. The HTT gene, on chromosome 4 encodes a protein called huntingtin. It has a stretch of repeats of the trinucleotide CAG. When the number of repeats is increased beyond normal, it is associated with Huntington's disease. More the repeats, earlier is its onset.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, and cortex. The lateral and 3rd ventricles may be dilated. There is a loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus on microscopic examination. The medium-sized, spiny neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter, along with enkephalin, dynorphin, and substance P are affected. Protein aggregates containing huntingtin can be seen in the neurons of the striatum and cerebral cortex. The chorea can be treated with dopamine-blocking agents like tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option A: Each mitochondrion contains many copies of mtDNA, where deleterious mutations of mtDNA may affect a few, but not all the copies of mtDNA. Hence, individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA. This is known as heteroplasmy. Thus, when a cell containing both normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in the daughter cells is variable. This explains why the expression of disorders resulting from mtDNA mutations is variable.

Option B: Genetic heterogeneity refers to the phenomenon where mutations at several different loci produce the same trait.

Option C: Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. Eg: varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).

questions.text: You are asked to calculate a fertility indicator for statistical purposes. The formula for the calculation is given below. The correct indicator would be:
questions.solution:
The given formula showing the ratio of number of daughters a newborn girl will bear in her entire life (assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate) to mid-year population of females in reproductive age group in the same area and same year is Net reproduction rate (NRR).

NRR is a demographic indicator. It is the only fertility indicator which takes mortality into account. It is the best indicator to evaluate the national family planning program.

An NRR of 1 is considered equivalent to the "two-child norm," representing a replacement-level fertility rate, where each generation replaces itself. If the NRR falls below 1, it indicates that the population's reproductive performance is inadequate, suggesting that the population is not reproducing at a rate sufficient to replace itself in the long term. A couple protection rate of 60% is required to achieve the NRR of 1.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with complaints of slow, progressive swelling in the upper abdomen, colicky abdominal pain, episodes of bilious vomiting, and constipation. Inspection of the abdomen is as shown below. Which of the following is correct regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Occurs due to  a defect in the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis
Howship-Romberg sign can be demonstrated on examination
Recurrence is due to missing a second defect during the original repair
These hernia are easily reducible because of the wider neck

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male presenting with abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and constipation along with a swelling in the midline suggests an epigastric hernia. After surgical management, epigastric hernias usually reoccur due to a second defect missed during the original repair. So, Option C is correct.

An epigastric hernia is characterized by midline raphe defects (linea alba). It usually protrudes between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus. The patients are often fit, healthy men, but they may be seen in older, overweight men and women, especially after multiple pregnancies. These hernias are often small in size and associated with multiple defects. It is a sacless hernia. It presents with:

  • Swelling in the Upper midline - Extraperitoneal fat protrudes through the defect as a fatty hernia of the linea alba
  • Impulse on coughing; defects in the epigastric region are also found. Irreducibility, obstruction, and strangulation as seen in any other hernia, can also occur in epigastric hernia
  • Pain in the epigastric region - as it is often associated with peptic ulcers.

Epigastric hernias with intestinal obstruction can be detected with XRAY Abdomen. CT scan can be used to confirm the diagnosis. Epigastric hernias are usually not reducible because of a narrow neck (Option D). The entrapment of fatty tissue, in small hernias, can result in considerable pain due to partial strangulation. The usual cause of ‘recurrence’ of an epigastric hernia is failure to identify a second defect during the original repair. Epigastric hernias are usually managed conservatively. Small to moderate-sized hernias without a peritoneal sac can be left untreated, and surgical repair is indicated only in symptomatic patients. Hernias containing the bowel should always be repaired.

Other options:

Option A: Spigelian Hernia is a type of interparietal hernia that occurs at the level of the arcuate line through the Spigelian point. The hernial sac lies deep into the internal oblique or between the external and internal oblique muscles. Meanwhile, an Epigastric Hernia is deep into the external oblique aponeurosis. 

Option B: The Howship-Romberg sign is demonstrated in an obturator hernia in which the obturator nerve compression causes pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh, which is relieved by flexion of the thigh.

questions.text: A young man presents with a history of head injury. On examination, his pulse rate is 52/minute, blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 10/min. Which among the following options is responsible for the raised blood pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated BP in a patient with a head injury is the Cushing reflex. The Cushing reflex is a triad of:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea).

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised. This leads to local hypoxia and hypercapnia which in turn increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors located on the ventrolateral medullary surface. This activation causes a rise in blood pressure which then restores the blood flow to the medulla. However, the arterial baroreceptors sense this increase in the systemic blood pressure and cause a reflex decrease in the heart rate. 

Other options-

Option A: J Reflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which causes a reflex increase in respiratory rate and dyspnea. 

Option B: Bainbridge reflex is the reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option C: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery). This is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: Which of the following structures are embryologically derived from the Meckel’s Cartilage ?
questions.solution:
Malleus is derived from Meckel's Cartilage which is the cartilage present in the ventral portion of first pharyngeal arch .

The first pharyngeal arch consists of a dorsal portion (the maxillary process) which extends forward beneath the region of the eye, and a ventral portion (the mandibular process) which contains Meckel’s cartilage. The Meckel cartilage disappears during development except for two small portions at its dorsal end that persist and form the incus and malleus . 

Mesenchyme of the maxillary process gives rise to the pre-maxilla, maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone through membranous ossification. In addition, the first arch contributes to formation of the bones of the middle ear, part of the external ear, and the external auditory meatus.

Musculature of the first pharyngeal arch includes the muscles of mastication (temporalis,masseter, and pterygoids), anterior belly of the digastric, mylohyoid, tensor tympani, and tensor palatini.

The nerve supply to the muscles of the first arch is provided by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. The mesenchyme from the first arch contributes to the dermis of the face, sensory supply to the skin of the face and is supplied by ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Other options :

Option B: Stapes arises from the cartilage of the second pharyngeal arch (called as Reichert cartilage) which also gives rise to styloid process of the temporal bone, stylohyoid ligament, and ventrally, the lesser horn and upper part of the body of the hyoid bone . 

Option C: The mandible is formed by membranous ossification of mesenchymal tissue surrounding Meckel’s cartilage. Hence, mandible is not formed from meckel’s cartilage but is moulded around it by membranous ossification of surrounding mesenchyme.

Option D: The lesser horn and upper part of the body of the hyoid bone is from the second pharyngeal arch while the cartilage of the third pharyngeal arch forms the lower part of the body and the greater horn of the hyoid bone .

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient with breathlessness who is admitted to the emergency department. His BP is 90/56 mmHg. Which clinical finding is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), which are indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Among the given options, pericardial knock is not a clinical feature of cardiac tamponade. It is a sign of constrictive pericarditis. 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to the impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include the following:

  • Pulsus paradoxus - This is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) on inspiration. In tamponade, the increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart causes the interventricular septum to bow towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing the left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 
  • Beck's triad - This is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of hypotension (90/56 mmHg), muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure. Features of JVP in tamponade include prominent x descent and absent y descent. 
  • ECG - ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electrical alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, the amplitude deflection on the ECG is increased; in contrast, when the heart moves away from the chest wall, the amplitude deflection is lower.

Management of cardiac tamponade - In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Note - Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by a progressive fibrotic change in the pericardium that causes it to thicken and calcify. This leads to impaired cardiac contraction and filling. This gives rise to fatigue, elevated JVP (rapid y descent), ascites, and pulsus paradoxus.

A notable finding on cardiac auscultation is the pericardial knock, which is an early diastolic sound. It is best appreciated over the left sternal border and/or the cardiac apex. It represents early and abrupt discontinuation of ventricular filling. 

ECG findings in constrictive pericarditis consist of non-specific T-wave abnormalities.

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

Other options:

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

Option C: Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with no other known comorbidities presented with intermittent facial pain, nasal congestion, and a history of dental fillings, and has mild mucosal swelling in the right maxillary sinus on nasal endoscopy. A CT scan shows a heterogeneous mass with calcifications and erosion of the inner sinus wall, but no air-fluid level. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient with a history of dental treatment with imaging revealing a heterogeneous mass in the right maxillary sinus with calcifications and erosion of the inner wall but no air-fluid level, suggests a diagnosis of a fungal ball of the sinus and the most appropriate management is Functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

A fungal ball (mycetoma) typically presents as a noninvasive fungal mass in a sinus, often in immunocompetent individuals. It is commonly associated with previous dental treatments (e.g., root canal procedures) due to the presence of dental materials like zinc oxide that can promote fungal growth. Imaging findings such as calcification, erosion of the sinus wall, and a heterogeneous mass without an air-fluid level help differentiate it from other forms of sinusitis, such as bacterial or fungal invasive infections.

The treatment of fungal balls is predominantly surgical. FESS is used to remove the fungal material and any contributing factors, such as dental fillings. FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses. This improves sinus ventilation and allows access to topical medications.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic Antifungals: Used in invasive fungal sinusitis (like mucormycosis), especially in immunocompromised patients.

Option B: Systemic Antibiotics: These would be used in complicated bacterial sinusitis or Oral cellulitis.

Option C: Surgical debridement: Invasive removal of the affected tissue, used in invasive fungal infections alongside systemic antifungals.

Related Pearl: Indications of FESS

Indications

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis)
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polypi
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Endoscopic septoplasty

Advanced nasal endoscopic techniques

  • Removal of benign tumours, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas.
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, weight loss, and fever. A peripheral blood smear was done and showed the following findings. Which among the following will indicate a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the bone marrow histology suggest a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Presence of a t(12;21) indicates a good prognosis.

ALL patients present with symptoms of impaired marrow function like anemia, infections secondary to neutropenia, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Other symptoms include bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, testicular enlargement, headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies.

Prognostic factors are identified in every patient to stratify them into risk groups that help in deciding the treatment. Minimal residual disease (MRD) is the most important prognostic factor during therapy. MRD refers to the detection of residual leukemic cells that are not recognizable by light microscopy after the therapy. MRD is a reflection of the response to treatment. 

Treatment of ALL

  • Induction: L-Asparaginase, vincristine, prednisolone, and anthracycline
  • CNS prophylaxis with intrathecal methotrexate
  • Consolidation: Methotrexate, cytarabine 
  • Maintenance: 6-Mercaptopurine, methotrexate plus intrathecal therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with the lesion shown below. On examination, a firm plaque with serpiginous finger-like projection with central atrophy was noted. She is a known case of tuberculosis and has completed the treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the likely diagnosis is tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. It is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. Lesions appear at the site of inoculation. They appear as verrucous plaque which extends with a serpiginous outline with finger‐like projections. The center of the lesion may have a white atrophic scar.

It is also known as anatomist’s warts, prosector’s warts and verruca necrogenica.  It occurs in a person who is already sensitized by previous exposure to TB. Thus it is a form of post-primary TB. Patients having this condition have good immunity against TB. Because of good immunity, they are effective in clearing the TB bacilli and thus, the lesion is paucibacillary. This condition is treated with anti-tubercular drugs. 

Other options- 

Option A- Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion gradually extend in some areas and heal with scarring in others. In India, the buttocks, and trunk are more frequently involved. Apple jelly nodules are demonstrated on diascopy.

The below image shows Lupus vulgaris: 

Option C- Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It occurs due to hypersensitivity to the active tubercular infection. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. The lesions are usually skin coloured and are often perifollicular. The papule may have an adherent crust or small pustule.

The below image shows Lichen scrofulosorum. 

Option D- Scrofuloderma results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from an underlying contiguous tuberculous focus. It commonly occurs in children. It begins as bluish-red subcutaneous swellings, which ulcerate to form discharging sinuses.

The below image shows Scrofuloderma.

questions.text: Which of the following respiratory sounds is correctly matched with the cause?

choices.text: Stridor - Obstruction of larynx or trachea

questions.solution:
Stridor is produced due to the obstruction of the larynx or trachea. 

Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx. 

The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract. Extrathoracic airway obstruction produces inspiratory sounds, intrathoracic major airway produces inspiratory as well as expiratory sounds and distal airway obstruction produces predominantly expiratory sounds.

Acute stridor may be seen in the epiglottis and croup while chronic stridor may be seen in laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Option A: Snoring is caused by oropharyngeal obstruction and is a low-pitched irregular inspiratory sound. It may be accompanied by hoarseness, dyspnea, retractions of the chest during inspiration, and use of accessory muscles of respiration. 

Option B: Wheeze is a continuous high-pitched expiratory musical sound produced due to lower airway obstruction such as partial obstruction of the bronchi and bronchioles. A wheeze can be heard in bronchial asthma, bronchiolitis, and viral infection of the lower respiratory tract.

Option D: Grunting is an expiratory sound produced due to partial closure of the glottis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text:
What is the mechanism of action of the poison obtained from the seeds shown in the image below?

VAMP- Vesicle-associated membrane protein

GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid

ACh- Acetylcholine

choices.text: Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors
Blocking glycine receptors in the ventral horn

questions.solution:
The seeds of Strychnos nux vomica are shown in the given image. The poison obtained from these seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem.

Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features. These include:

  • Tonic-clonic seizures
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension)
  • Risus sardonicus
  • Other less common postures that can be seen are emprosthotonus (body bent forward as if bowing) and pleurosthotonus (body bent sideward). 

Strychnos nux vomica seeds are toxic only when chewed/ crushed prior to swallowing. Intact seeds, if swallowed, will not result in any further symptoms. Treatment involves an initial stomach wash and the use of activated charcoal to absorb the ingested poison. The patient should be treated with benzodiazepines or barbiturates to control seizures, and they should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions.

Other options: 

Option (A)- Blocking peripheral postsynaptic ACh receptors can be seen in curare poisoning. It can cause progressive flaccid paralysis, ultimately leading to respiratory failure. It was used as an arrow poison during wars in the past.

Option (B)- Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors can be seen in datura poisoning. It acts by competitive antagonism. All the parts of the datura plant are poisonous. It shows predominantly peripheral anticholinergic effects like flushed face, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils, delirium, urinary retention, etc. with central effects like psychosis and delirium.

Option (C)- VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein) cleavage in GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) neurons at the ventral horn of the spinal cord, is the mechanism of action of toxins in tetanus infections. VAMP is normally responsible for the release of GABA, hence VAMP cleavage results in unopposed muscular contractions. The resulting clinical features are very similar to that of strychnine poisoning. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Investigations show low C4 levels and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following will be abnormal in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Serum cryoglobulin levels will be abnormal in this condition.

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures, leading to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. This syndrome is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens.

Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Other options:

Option A: ANCA antibodies are positive in granulomatous vasculitis like granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's syndrome) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option C: Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are positive in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody directed against integrin, used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin.

Natalizumab is highly effective and reduces the attack rate of multiple sclerosis thus improving the severity of the disease (both clinical and MRI). Natalizumab is given as an injectable preparation. 

The major concern of natalizumab is the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is also a life-threatening condition developed from the JC virus infection. The risk of developing PML is higher in patients taking natalizumab associated with JC antibody positive. Therefore, natalizumab is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients.

Other options:

Option A: Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate inhibitor. It reduces the attack rate and improves the disease severity in multiple sclerosis. It is given as oral preparation. The patients on fingolimod are at risk of developing macular edema and disseminated varicella-zoster infection.

Option B: Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. It is given as oral preparation. The adverse effect includes Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It has teratogenicity and is considered a category X drug. 

Option C: Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells. It is given as an intravenous preparation. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancy like breast cancer and infusion reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli is best perceived by Ruffini corpuscles?

choices.text: Point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter

questions.solution:
Ruffini corpuscles detect stretch and joint rotation. Ruffini corpuscles are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly adapting receptors. The image below shows a Ruffini corpuscle.

Meissner's corpuscles are present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is well developed. They have small receptive fields which help in two­ point discrimination. Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that sense point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter. These are encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve (Aβ type). The image shows the histology of Meissner's corpuscle in the dermis.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers. The image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Merkel discs are seen in the epidermis of glabrous skin. They are slowly adapting receptors and have very small receptive fields. These receptors detect vertical indentations of the skin. They are expanded dendritic endings. The image below shows a Merkel disc.

Pain and temperature sensations arise from receptors located on unmyelinated sensory neurons present throughout the glabrous skin, hairy skin, and deep tissue. Impulses from nociceptors are transmitted via thinly myelinated Aδ fibres and unmyelinated C fibres.

Activation of Aδ fibres is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain). It is a rapid response and helps in the discrimination of pain or the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus. It is mediated by the release of glutamate. An example is a pinprick.

Activation of C fibres is responsible for delayed second pain (also called slow pain). It is a dull, intense, diffuse, and unpleasant feeling associated with a noxious stimulus. Second pain is mediated by the release of a combination of glutamate and substance P. Example is visceral pain.

Types of nociceptors :

  • Mechanical nociceptors respond to strong pressure (eg, from a sharp object). 
  • Thermal nociceptors are activated by skin temperatures above 45°C or by severe cold (<20°C).
  • Chemically sensitive nociceptors respond to chemicals such as bradykinin, histamine, high acidity, and environmental irritants.
  • Polymodal nociceptors respond to combinations of these stimuli.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Investigations revealed hemoglobin levels of 9 g/dL and orotic acid crystalluria. Peripheral blood smear showed a large number of hypochromic macrocytes. Other red cells were microcytic and hypochromic. Serum folate, B12 levels, and blood ammonia levels appeared normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia with orotic acid crystalluria is consistent with orotic aciduria, a disorder of pyrimidine metabolism.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Treatment includes, administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/partial gastrectomy, ileal resection, Crohn's disease
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

Other options:
Option (A): B12 metabolic defect is unlikely since B12 and folate levels are normal.
Option (B): Urea cycle defect is also unlikely because the blood ammonia levels are normal.
Option (C): Purine metabolism disorders include gouty arthritis, adenosine deaminase deficiency, and purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms would not give a similar positive reaction as shown in the image below?
  1. Streptococci
  2. Neisseria

  4. Vibrio
  5. Enterococci
questions.solution:
The given image shows a slide with a positive catalase test. Streptococci and enterococci are catalase-negative, and hence do not exhibit this reaction. 

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles.

Clinical application:

People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

The test is particularly useful in the differentiation of staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative).

questions.text: A patient with a snake bite is admitted to the ICU and is being treated for acute renal failure. He has ptosis along with generalized muscle weakness. His blood reports show raised serum creatinine kinase and potassium levels and the urine analysis shows raised myoglobin levels. Which snake is likely to have bitten this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of a snake bite patient who has raised serum creatinine kinase and serum potassium levels along with myoglobinuria suggests rhabdomyolysis which can be seen due to the myotoxin released from the bite of a Sea-Snake.

The Sea Snake venom is myotoxic which causes muscle damage, which leads to the release of potassium, myoglobin, and muscle enzymes like serum creatinine kinase in the blood. The myoglobinuria that occurs can lead to acute renal failure. The Hydrophidae family comprises sea snakes, whose bites cause little or no local reaction but the myotoxic venom leads to marked polymyositis with a limb-girdle distribution.

Some common symptoms include headache, thirst, generalized muscle ache, stiffness, and tenderness. Trismus is an early symptom and is followed by generalized flaccid paralysis (which begins with ptosis) similar to elapid neurotoxicity. The muscle weakness persists for months in these patients. Death can occur in these patients due to sudden cardiac arrest or paralysis of respiratory muscles.

Other options :

Option A: Viper venom is vasculotoxic and their bite leads to hemostatic abnormalities like persistent bleeding from the wound site where fangs have punctured, spontaneous systemic hemorrhage, gingival bleeding, epistaxis, hematemesis, hemoptysis, subconjunctival, retroperitoneal, and intracranial hemorrhages. In severe cases, shock is seen. Renal failure is a frequent complication. Death is usually due to shock and hemorrhage.

Option B and C: Cobra and Krait venom is neurotoxic, symptoms begin with ptosis followed by gradual muscle weakness to the limbs and trunk, facial muscles, palate, jaw, vocal cords, and neck muscles, ultimately leading to death due to respiratory muscle paralysis. Unlike the sea snake bite, there is no rise in the serum creatinine kinase levels or myoglobinuria seen in neurotoxic snake bites.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed if there is an injury to the nucleus underlying the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. 

The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) then emerges from the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullares
  • Striae medullaris divides rhomboid fossa into 2 parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

Other Options:

Option A: The genioglossus muscle is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) arising from the hypoglossal nucleus in the medulla.

Option B: The orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). 

Option D: The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient taking Allopurinol for chronic gout had complaints of pain in the flanks and recurrent urinary tract infections. On urine examination, xanthine crystals were present. Which of the following minerals is the cofactor of the enzyme being inhibited by Allopurinol?
questions.solution:
The patient of chronic gout is on Allopurinol and has xanthine crystals in his urine suggesting the inhibition of the Xanthine Oxidase enzyme by allopurinol. The cofactor of Xanthine Oxidase is Molybdenum.

Xanthine Oxidase converts Hypoxanthine to Xanthine and Xanthine to Uric Acid in the purine degradation pathway. Inhibition of Xanthine oxidase by allopurinol leads to very high levels of Xanthine which can accumulate in the kidney causing kidney stones leading to renal colic and recurrent UTI. These stones can impair kidney function and ultimately cause kidney failure. 

Molybdenum is the cofactor for the following three enzymes : 

  • Xanthine oxidase: Oxidizes Hypoxanthine to Xanthine and Xanthine to Uric Acid in the purine degradation. 
  • Sulfite oxidase: Converts sulfite to sulfate in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, methionine and cysteine.
  • Aldehyde oxidase: Metabolizes drugs.  

Other options : 

Option B: Selenium is present as a cofactor in enzymes like Glutathione peroxidase, Deiodinase, and Thioredoxin reductase.

Option C: Iron is present in enzymes like Succinate dehydrogenase and Prolyl Hydroxylase as well as in proteins like hemoglobin and myoglobin.

Option D: Cobalt acts as a component of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) which is required as methylcobalamin in the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine or adenosylcobalamin in the isomerization of methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA.

questions.text: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is associated with Liver Hemangioma. Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is characterized by consumption coagulopathy in very large hemangiomas where platelets and other clotting factors are being used up within the tumor. This results in thrombocytopenia and disseminated intravascular coagulation causing abdominal pain and bleeding.

Liver Hemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the Liver and is more common in females. They are usually diagnosed incidentally. LFT and tumor markers are normal in a hemangioma. Large hemangiomas in children can result in congestive heart failure secondary to arteriovenous shunting and they require medical attention. Most hemangiomas are managed conservatively and observation is preferred in asymptomatic liver hemangiomas that are less than 5cm because they may show spontaneous regression. Patients with symptomatic liver hemangiomas are managed with embolization and enucleation with arterial inflow control.

Other Options:

Option A: Hepatic Adenoma - Benign liver tumor. Associated with Oral contraceptive use (OCPs). May undergo spontaneous resolution.

Option B: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia - Benign liver tumor. Usually occurs in females. Characterized by Central Stellate Scar (central scar with radiating septa). Mostly asymptomatic, diagnosed incidentally.

Option D: Hepatoblastoma - Most common primary liver tumor in children. Associated with familial polyposis syndrome.

  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text:
Match the following tests used for the assessment of colour vision:
  1. Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart
  2. Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  3. City University test
  4. Naegel's anamoloscope
questions.solution:
The correct matching of tests used for assessing colour vision is option D: 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.
This corresponds to:

Colour vision tests are designed to assess different aspects of colour deficiency: 

  • to screen for defective colour vision
  • to classify the type of colour blindness (protan, deutan, or tritan defects)
  • to quantify the degree of deficiency (mild, moderate, or severe). 

The most common and widely used tests are based on pseudoisochromatic plates, such as the Ishihara plates, which are used for screening red-green colour defects (protan and deutan defects, respectively). These tests show a pattern of coloured and grey dots that reveal different patterns to normal individuals and to those with colour vision deficiencies. 

For qualitative classification of colour vision defects, the Hardy-Rand-Rittler test (HRR) is used. This test is more sensitive than the Ishihara plates because it can detect all three types of congenital defects (protan, deutan, and tritan). The HRR test also uses a series of plates with coloured patterns to help identify the specific type of colour blindness. 

The City University colour vision test is a spectroscopic test where a central coloured plate is matched to surrounding hues on several plates, making it useful for diagnosing colour vision defects.

The Naegels anamoloscope is a more advanced diagnostic tool for quantitative analysis of colour vision, especially for red-green deficiencies. It works by having the subject mix red and green light until it matches a yellow standard, providing information about the degree of the colour deficiency. It is especially useful for distinguishing the severity of red-green defects.

questions.text: A neonate presented with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body with hypoplasia of all limbs. An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy. An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital varicella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this infant with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body, hypoplasia of all limbs, and chorioretinitis.

Varicella zoster virus (VZV) is found to have in-utero transmission. Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by abnormalities in the newborn infant. The abnormalities are:

  • Cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like distribution
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Central nervous system abnormalities: ventriculomegaly, cortical atrophy, seizures, and mental retardation
  • Chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataracts
  • Renal system abnormalities: hydroureter and hydronephrosis,
  • Autonomic nervous system abnormalities: neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia
  • Low birth weight.
Diagnosis:
A history of gestational varicella and the presence of characteristic abnormalities in the newborn infant is mainly required for the diagnosis of congenital varicella syndrome. PCR can be used to identify VZV DNA in vesicular fluid or scabs from zoster lesions. VZV-specific IgM antibodies from cord blood can be used to diagnose. In the asymptomatic child, a positive VZV IgG antibody titer at 12-18 months of age is a reliable indicator of prenatal infection.

Other options:

Option A- Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is hearing loss. Diagnosis can be made by detection of CMV DNA in PCR obtained within 2-4 weeks of birth. IgM antibodies for CMV can also be used for diagnosis.

Option B- Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is due to the rubella virus. The most common finding among infants with CRS is nerve deafness. The most serious eye-finding is unilateral or bilateral cataracts. Cardiac abnormalities like patent ductus arteriosus (most commonly reported cardiac abnormality), lesions of pulmonary arteries, and valvular diseases are also seen. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option C- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose (depression of the nasal root) are some late findings.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to inflate the bulb of the instrument given in the following image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a three-way irrigation Foley catheter. The balloon in the Foley catheter is inflated using sterile water. questions.text: A primigravida at 33 weeks gestation presents to the OPD for her antenatal checkup. On examination, her BP is 150/96 mmHg and the urine dipstick reveals +1 proteinuria. Umbilical artery Doppler results are shown below. What is the ideal management for this patient?

choices.text: IV labetalol and induction of labour

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation with BP of 150/96 mmHg, and proteinuria indicates mild preeclampsia. Reverse end-diastolic flow on Umbilical artery doppler is suggestive of impending fetal death and it should ideally be managed by IV dexamethasone followed by a C-section.

Reverse end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal compromise. At 33 weeks, IV dexamethasone is given to enhance fetal lung maturity, and an immediate C-section should be done without any trial of labor.

Umbilical artery vessels are characterized by forward, low-resistance flow. As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases. S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases (S represents the peak systolic flow or velocity, and D indicates the end-diastolic flow or velocity). Abnormal flow patterns on the umbilical artery doppler:

  • Reduced end-diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency
  • Absent end-diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if gestational age is >34 weeks)
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age ideally 31-32 weeks)

Other options:

Option A: IV labetalol and induction of labour: Since blood pressure readings are below 170/100 mmHg, there is no need of IV labetalol and induction of labour would not be the preferred option as there is high fetal risk due to presence of reversed end diastolic flow. 

Option C: IV MgSO4 and bed rest: Magnesium sulfate is used for severe preeclampsia or eclampsia, but bed rest and conservative management are not sufficient for this case with evidence of fetal compromise i.e. reverse end diastolic flow.

Option D: Oral labetalol and repeat Doppler: Oral antihypertensives can be used for mild preeclampsia, but with signs of fetal distress (reverse end-diastolic flow), immediate action (steroids and C-section) is required.

questions.text: What is the method of sterilization used for Loeffler's serum?
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation involves the application of a temperature of 80-85° C for half an hour for three consecutive days in an inspissator. This method is used for the sterilization of media containing eggs or serum. Another medium for which this method is used is the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as it contains egg. 

Other Options:

Autoclaving: Heat at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15 psi (most commonly used).

Tyndallization: This method is used for media containing sugars or gelatin. It involves steaming at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days. This method may not kill the spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles. 

Plasma sterilization is a new method of sterilising heat-sensitive articles. Radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field. Into this, hydrogen peroxide vapours are introduced, which generates a plasma state containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. This state renders the articles sterile by denaturing all microorganisms. Arthroscopes, urethroscopes, etc., are sterilised by plasma sterilisation.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered "tail-gaiting"?

choices.text: Head-on collision of a motorcycle with a truck
Side collision of a truck and motorcycle
A motorcyclist drives into the back of a truck
A pedestrian is run over by a truck

questions.solution:
“Tail-gating” also known as "under-running" is when a motorcyclist drives into the back of a truck.

“Tail-gating” or “Under-running” is a type of accident where a motorcyclist may drive into the back of a truck. The bike passes underneath, but the head of the motorcyclist impacts the tail-board.

Tail-gating may occur due to the sudden and unexpected stoppage of the truck or when the motorcyclist is driving at high speed in the darkness. In such cases, the motorcyclist's head and shoulders are smashed against the tailboard. In extreme cases, decapitation may occur. It may also happen to motor cars when the rear of the truck smashes into the windscreen of the car.

Tail-gating also occasionally occurs with cars driving into the back of large trucks. In such cases, the windscreen and front of the passenger compartment are smashed with severe injuries to the head and shoulders and, in some cases, decapitation of the occupants of the front seat.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the casualty after he was arrested at a rave party. He is unusually talkative and appears to have increased energy, excessive sweating, dilated pupils, and elevated blood pressure. He was found to be selling his urine samples at the party. Which of the following is likely to be present in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that the man is suffering from amphetamine overdose and paranoid hallucinations are commonly found in amphetamine intoxication.

Symptoms of acute amphetamine poisoning vary from mild restlessness, talkativeness, insomnia, and dilated pupils to severe delirium, hyperpyrexia, convulsions, and arrhythmias. In moderate cases, individuals may experience confusion, hypertension, tachycardia, and hallucinations. Acute amphetamine intoxication can often present with Paranoid hallucinations, which closely resemble paranoid schizophrenia. The treatment of choice for amphetamine-induced psychotic disorder is the short-term use of an antipsychotic medication such as haloperidol.

40% of amphetamine is excreted unchanged in the urine and "liquid gold" is a slang term for urine for amphetamine addicts which is collected and sold. Amphetamines increase the synaptic levels of dopamine and norepinephrine by blocking their reuptake and increasing catecholamine release, which can cause toxicity similar to cocaine. Designer amphetamines like  MDMA {3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine} are commonly used in rave parties. They have neurochemical effects on both serotonergic and dopaminergic systems resulting in amphetamine-like and hallucinogen-like behavioral effects.

Other options :

Option A: Bad Trips are associated with  Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) intoxication.

Option C: Nystagmus is associated with Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication.

Option D: Increased appetite is associated with Marijuana (THC, Cannabis) intoxication.

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child is currently under evaluation for supra-valvular aortic stenosis and mental retardation. A characteristic facies is present as shown in the image below. Her karyotype reveals 46XX and her blood investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of mental retardation, elfin facies, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis is strongly suggestive of Williams' syndrome.

The image shows a young girl with an elfin face with a round face, full cheeks, broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, thick lips, and a large mouth that is usually left open. They also have short palpebral fissures, prominent ears, and a small mandible. 

It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple congenital development defects, including supra-valvular aortic stenosis, mental retardation, and an elfin facies, in association with hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D with elevated levels of 1,25(OH)2D ranging from 150 to 500 pg/mL.

Williams' syndrome is caused due to genetic mutations involving microdeletions at the elastin locus on chromosome 7. 

Other options-

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. The characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia, deletion 22q11.2.

The following image shows a child with DiGeorge syndrome:

 

Option C: Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. There is a wide range of presentations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissues, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

 

Option D: Edward syndrome is a trisomy of chromosome 18. It is characterized by microcephaly, microphthalmia, prominent nasal bridge, coloboma of iris, microretrognathia, cleft lip, cleft palate, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and severe growth retardation. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Edward syndrome, note the clenched fist with overlapping fingers:

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image are suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue. Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis
