questions.text: A 21-year-old college student is brought to the doctor by his family because he was repeatedly caught trying to peep into female dressing rooms. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act of observing women getting undressed. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a person deriving sexual pleasure by observing women getting undressed is highly suggestive of scoptophilia.

Scoptophilia, or voyeurism, is a type of sexual perversion where the person derives sexual pleasure by observing unsuspecting victims while they are naked, getting dressed, or engaging in sexual activity. A person who frequently has such cravings or behaviours is known as a voyeur/peeping Tom.

The victim is typically a total stranger. Sexual pleasure is typically derived from masturbation, either while witnessing the act or later when one remembers the incident. This kind of perversion usually occurs in the case of severe sociopathic personality disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Frotteurism refers to the sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person. This behaviour often occurs in busy and crowded places. It is predominantly described in men.

Option C: Exhibitionism is the urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.

Option D: Algolagnia is sexual pleasure derived from inflicting pain (active algolagnia) or enduring pain (passive algolagnia).

questions.text: Suicide inhibition is a mechanism where the drug enzyme intermediate eventually attacks the enzyme. This mechanism is not seen in which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Suicide inhibition is not seen in nitroglycerine. 

Nitroglycerin (NTG) converts into nitric oxide (NO), which activates guanylate cyclase and increases cGMP. This reduces intracellular calcium, causing smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. NTG primarily dilates veins, reducing preload (venous return to the heart), lowering myocardial oxygen demand, and improving coronary blood flow. Thus, it helps treat angina and heart failure.

Suicide inhibition is a type of mechanism-based irreversible inhibition where the enzyme recognizes the inhibitor as a substrate, but during the transition state of catalysis, the inhibitors are converted to intermediates that can attack the enzyme. Examples of suicide inhibitors include cyclooxygenase (COX)-1 inhibition by aspirin, allopurinol inhibiting xanthine oxidase, Organophosphates inhibiting acetylcholinesterase (Option D), Omeprazole inhibiting gastric H+/K+ ATPase (Option B), difuoromethylornitine inhibiting ornithine decarboxylase (Option C).

Drugs utilizing enzymes as targets could be broadly divided as follows:

  • Reversible inhibitors bind to the enzyme reversibly (on and off rate). They could be competitive, non-competitive, or uncompetitive.
    • Competitive inhibitors- most reversible inhibitors are competitive inhibitors where both the inhibitor and the substrate compete to bind to the enzyme’s active site, and their binding is mutually exclusive.
    • Non-competitive inhibitors: The inhibitor binds to the enzyme irrespective of the bound substrate at a site different from the substrate site.
    • Uncompetitive inhibitors- such inhibitors bind to the enzyme-substrate complex
  • Irreversible inhibitors- these bind to the enzyme irreversibly forming covalent linkages and derange the catalytic ability of the enzyme.

questions.text: An obese male patient has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hypertension. He is started on atorvastatin. Which of the following additional medication can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker and an anti-hypertensive medication that can be safely prescribed along with statins like atorvastatin because atenolol does not have much interaction with statin metabolism.

Statins are hypolipidemic drugs that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This allows for a compensatory increase in LDL receptors in the liver and thereby increases LDL catabolism. 

They are well tolerated. However, they can cause notable side effects such as myopathy and liver injury. They occur commonly when statins are concurrently given with nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors such as:

  • Macrolide antibiotics (erythromycin/clarithromycin)
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cyclosporine
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Warfarin
  • Digoxin
  • Azole antifungals
  • Amiodarone

Other options: 

Option A: Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that inhibits the hepatic uptake of statins by the organic anion transporter OATP1B1 and prevents its metabolism, thereby increasing its bioavailability. Thus, the risk of toxicity of statins increases. Concurrent use of gemfibrozil with statins most commonly causes myopathy (rhabdomyolysis). 

Option C: Digoxin used concurrently with a statin can increase the risk of myopathy.

Option D: Nicotinic acid (Niacin) used concurrently with statins can cause myopathy due to inhibition of skeletal muscle cholesterol synthesis. 

Related Pearl: Metabolism of drugs

Drugs metabolized by cyp3A4 enzymes:

  • Protease inhibitors
  • Statins
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Amiodarone
  • Estrogen
  • Erythromycin

questions.text: The following result in the graph, which plots the rate of diffusion against the substrate concentration to facilitate the movement of substances along the concentration gradient, will be exhibited by which of the following transporters?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the graph shows saturation kinetics for the movement of substance along the concentration gradient with an increase in the diffusion rate until it reaches the maximum value (Vmax) and then plateaus is seen in facilitated diffusion exhibited by the GLUT4 (Glucose Transporter Type 4).

Facilitated diffusion utilizes a carrier protein to transport substances across the membrane. The substance that binds to the carrier protein causes a conformational or chemical change in the carrier protein leading to the opening of a new pore on the opposite side.

The rate of transport reaches the maximum until all the transporters are occupied after which the rate cannot increase further due to a lack of free transporters and the rate attains a plateau irrespective of the concentration of substances.

All GLUT proteins transport monosaccharides via facilitated diffusion. Although GLUT4 is insulin-dependent, insulin merely activates GLUT4 and increases the rate of facilitated diffusion by 10- 20 times.

SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 2), SCN (Sodium Channel, Voltage-Gated, Neuronal), and ABCC3 (ATP-Binding Cassette Subfamily C Member 3) are examples of active transport that show saturation as seen in facilitated diffusion, but the substances move against the concentration gradient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of low-grade fever, irritability, headache, and neck rigidity for the past 1 week. Examination reveals papilledema and abducens nerve palsy. MRI shows dilated ventricles and significant basal exudates. Which of the following would most likely be seen in the CSF?
questions.solution:
The features and imaging findings are suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. CSF analysis would most likely show lymphocytosis, low glucose level, and high protein level. 

Tuberculous meningitis presents as a subacute infection and has a longer course than bacterial meningitis. Ocular nerve palsy is a common association as there is marked meningeal involvement at the base of the brain. The patient can also develop hydrocephalus.

The clinical triad of fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity is common to all types of meningitis. Nuchal rigidity is the resistance of the neck to passive flexion and is pathognomonic of meningeal irritation. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are other features of meningeal irritation. Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is a complication that presents as papilledema, disorientation, or dilated poorly reactive pupils.

If the CSF is allowed to stand, a 'spider’s web clot' or 'cobweb' coagulum may form due to the high level of protein. There is usually lymphocytic leukocytosis, low glucose concentration, and elevated levels of proteins. Acid-fast bacilli are not frequently seen on the direct smear of the CSF sediment. CSF culture remains the gold standard for diagnosis. However, CB-NAAT (a type of nucleic acid amplification method) is the initial diagnostic test of choice because of its high sensitivity and quicker results compared to culture.

Imaging studies (CT and MRI) may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

questions.text: During your internship, an ophthalmic resident asks you to observe the structures visible on gonioscopy while evaluating a glaucoma patient having Shaffers grade 2 angle width. You would be able to observe which of the following structures?

choices.text: Scleral spur and Anterior part  of Ciliary body

questions.solution:
Trabecular meshwork and Schwalbe’s line can be visualized on gonioscopy examination of glaucoma patient having Shaffers grade 2 angle width.

The angle of the anterior chamber plays an important role in the process of aqueous drainage. It is formed by,

  • Schwalbe’s line (SL)
  • Trabecular meshwork (TM)
  • Scleral spur (SS),
  • Anterior part Ciliary body (CB),
  • Root of the iris.

Clinically, these structures can be visualized by gonioscopic examination.

Shaffer’s system is most commonly used for Gonioscopic grading of the angle width.

questions.text:
Which of the following represents the correct match among the following types of shock and their corresponding characteristics?
  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance
A Low Low High
B Low High High
C Low High High
D High Low Low

choices.text: A - Obstructive; B - Hypovolaemic; C - Distributive; D - Cardiogenic
A - Hypovolaemic; B - Obstructive; C - Cardiogenic; D - Distributive
A - Obstructive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Hypovolaemic; D - Distributive
A - Distributive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Obstructive; D - Hypovolaemic

questions.solution:
The correct match is as below:

  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance Mixed venous saturation Base deficit
Hypovolemic Low Low High Low High
Obstructive Low High High Low High
Cardiogenic Low High High Low High
Distributive High Low Low High High

Hypovolemic shock - 
It is due to reduced circulating volume. Causes include hemorrhage, dehydration, vomiting, third spacing.

Obstructive Shock -
Leads to a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus, or air embolus.

Cardiogenic shock - 
Due to the failure of the heart to pump blood to tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury, and cardiomyopathy

Distributive shock - 
Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance leading to vasodilation. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include spinal shock, anaphylaxis, and septic shock.
